"Can you provide more information? What version of HBase are you using? Are there concurrent writes to that row? It might be that version 12345678L gets successfully stored, but you have system provided timestamps that are newer than 12345678L. Try getting all versions of that row and checking whether 12345678L is there."	HBase			
HBase 0.92.1. There is only one version of that row (I've set max versions number in get and checked).				
"Could you paste the output of ""hbase> describe 't1'"" (HBase Shell) for your table t1 (whatever name it has)? This will give us information about the column families you are trying to write to. There might be issues such as Time To Live for the families. Also try writing to an empty row, you should definitely get the timestamp you want, since there should be no other version."				
"{NAME => 'TestTableName', FAMILIES => [{NAME => 'Family1', BLOOMFILTER => 'NONE', REPLICATION_SCOPE => '0', VERSIONS => '3', COMPRESSION => 'NONE', MIN_VERSIONS => '0', TTL => '2147483647', BLOCKSIZE => '65536', IN_MEMORY => 'false', BLOCKCACHE => 'true'}, {NAME => 'Family2', BLOOMFILTER => 'NONE', REPLIC                              ATION_SCOPE => '0', VERSIONS => '3', COMPRESSION =>'NONE', MIN_VERSIONS => '0', TTL => '2147483647', BLOCKSIZE => '65536', IN_MEMORY => 'false', BLOCKCACHE => 'true'}]}"				
"In official hbase book ,hbase.apache.org/book/versions.html,  it is said  ""Doing a put always creates a new version of a cell, at a certain timestamp. By default the system uses the server's currentTimeMillis, but you can specify the version (= the long integer) yourself, on a per-column level. This means you could assign a time in the past or the future, or use the long value for non-time purposes."""	cell			
"Yes, but the version with maximum timestamp will be shown if you use get(),  unless you use setMaxVersions() to get the 'older' (i.e, with lower timestamp) versions. So if there already exist the same cell with timestamp > 12345678, then that one will be shown."				
I've already tried setting max versions number to 10 - there is only one version of this row.

"In fact, there is no need for the version to be in the URL at all, unless you plan to deploy multiple versions within the same .war file.  Remember, each .war file is required to have a unique context root;  they cannot have overlapping URLs, ever."	war			
"Keep version, if you, software needs updates and sometimes you can't make the backward compatible, version help you keep old client running while developing for new ones. "Yes, you are right. I have found in many articles that Java World Wind SDK has API-centric architecture, I put it there, but actually have never thought what it really means. From what I read now I concluded that SDK built on API-centric architecture allows us to integrate it very easily to different applications. For example, if I want to add World Wind technology into my own application, I just need something like 5 lines of the code and it is. I guess this could be the explanation."	JavaWorld

Your assumption is wrong.				
"developer.android.com/reference/android/app , According to that, you can get the total memory accessible by the kernel and the available memory to the system. Therefore, any memory not reported is not available to use by anything user or kernel."	that			
And I totally agree with that comment but my question is: how can I find 0ut through code what this not reported memory adds up to?				
"The short answer - you cannot - at least through the android api (at this point in time). You might be able to write device native code that can query the memory controller directly and get that information, but you'd need to write that code on a device by device basis. (Also voted up your question because I see no reason for it to have been voted down)."				
"Axel, I am trying to find out a way to programmatically obtain the total memory (512 or 1024 or whatever the device has) because it will be different in every device my program will be running."	1024			
"I think there is no way because it's limited by the hardware. Your device has 512mb physically, but the hardware splits it up between gpu and memory available to the system. You could perhaps find out about the memory available to the gpu and add that to the value the system reports. But I don't know if there's a way to find out if the gpu memory is on the same physical chip. Of course if both add up to a power of 2 when either of them is no power of 2, that would be a strong hint because AFAIK, all RAM modules ship with a memory amount that is a power of 2."	RAM			
"This kind of solves my problem in a very intelligent way :). I will be doing a lookup table with all the power of 2 and find the nearest value to the ""OS memory"". In case no one will post a programmatic way of retrieving the exact value I will mark you as the correct answer."	lookup

"To Jesper I understand the usage at ,class, & ,interface, level, to program with interfaces. But ,here, at jar level, I did not include api jar. Things worked with implementation jar only, because implementation jar has both api(mostly java ,interface,) & it's implementation class."				
"See ,youtube.com/watch?v=aAb7hSCtvGw"	youtube.com/watchv=aAb7hSCtvGw			
"I think you gave the definition of framework vs library, in this answer, wrt delegating code"	library			
"first revision: ""I could write anal setters"". Wow ... whatever way you want to swing with your setters I won't judge."				
"Thanks for the reply. Some follow up questions:  (1) Actually my interfaces don't end in 'Interface' usually but do start with 'I'. Is there a standard naming convention for interfaces in Java? I always thought it was a matter of preference but would happily change if a convention exists.  (2) The '_' for member variables I also assumed was a matter of coding style. If it doesn't affect the getter/setter names I thought it was ok.  (3) If I was to use constructor injection, I would remove the setParent() method and allow a null parent reference in the constructor (no default constructor). OK?"	setParent()			
And thanks for taking the time to give me a very detailed answer.				
"(1)The Java convention is to name interfaces with just a name (as you should be using the interface more than the implementation) and name implementations something different, usually something like ,ThingImpl,, ,DefaultThing,, or ,AbstractThing,.  The ,IThing, convention is more of a C#/.Net thing."				
"(2)The ,_field, naming - in Java it's pretty standard to do ,this.field, instead... though you're right it doesn't bleed into the external interface.  You may run into some issues if you decide to use APIs that uses reflection or annotations to figure out properties... most of them are pretty good at figuring out the property through the public API, but you may run into some cases where you set an annotation on the field and it can't find the methods that map to it because it's looking for ,set_myField(),/,get_myField(), or wants to map the field to a ,_myField, database column or something."	You			
"(3) So 'parentage' is really an immutable property?  A component won't be able to move around the hierarchy?  I still don't like using ,null, as a ""magic"" parameter in the public API... If anything, I'd make at least 3 classes - an abstract implementation that allows ,null, as a parent parameter, a top level implementation that provides a default constructor and calls ,super(null),, and another (possibly abstract) implementation that's used for child components that provides only the constructor that takes a parent, and throws an exception if ,null, is passed to it, to make it clear."				
Is it bad IOC practise to not supply a default constructor at all (therefore to enforce the interface version of the constructor)?	practise			
To Chris - don't think you can call it good or bad practice.  It depends on the way you've designed your classes to be wired.				
"Actually, I was considering asking this as part of the original question but glad to see that you've answered it anyway.  I wouldn't be enthusiastic about adding Spring-Specific annotations to the code. My feeling is that the interface itself should be responsible for prohibiting non-intended use so that the protection is afforded to all usage vectors of the API (Spring/Java/PicoContainer/etc.)."	Spring-Specificannotations			
"You don't need to add annotations to use Spring.  I use XML config files exclusively in my projects.  Also, I would be surprised if you figure out something that works well across a range of DI systems."	config			
"Also, I'm not sure you can control the order in which the Spring wiring frameworks calls your bean's setters."				
"While this is sound advice, I think his question was about proving that Weblogic will invalidate session EJBs when their methods throw uncaught exceptions."

And how appservers treat these error conditions. i want to rip all the bad throwable error handling out. but people can't be easily convinced here. hope you know what i mean. cheers"

"+1 - As terrible as it sounds, I think ""implement your own"" is a good option here. If you are regularly adding and removing observers, the EventProducer can be optimized by modeling it after the thread safe event multicasting logic used in java.awt.AWTEve"	java.awt.AWTEventMulticaster			
"Edited to fix parsing of &lt;s. To Tim, I agree that ""implementing your own"" for such a common pattern sounds terrible. In the absence of a standard, a single in-house implementation is better than many, different per-class implementations (speaking from some unfortunate experience). I've never encountered a situation where adding/removing listeners needs to be optimized. AWTEventMulticaster pre-dates the Java concurrency package and CopyOnWriteArrayListener, which allows a simple, readable thread-safe implementation."				
"Note that it goes against Java coding guidelines to put an ,I, in front of interface names."	I			
"Any issues in deciding between (1) and (2)?  It looks like (2) is a whole lot more complicated than (1).  Thus, I am thinking, just make ,getData(), blocking, or poll the API, where I can get away with it."	getData()

"I guess it doesn't matter much overall. I tried sending 10-15 requests with different sized thread pools each time, but the response time never showed any improvement/changes. Also, right now, I can see that my use of Futures to get results back after submitting tasks does make this application blocking. I'll look into it to see if I can make it non-blocking."	Futures			
"To Jarrod Roberson: ,the 4 hyperthreads usually make things worse on CPU bound apps, [sic]... And ,""on a laptop threading isn't going to get you much"", [sic]... Regarding the first quote, links would be much welcome.  Regarding the second quote, I've repeatedly witnessed the exact opposite: using a ,producer/consumers, scheme to crunch data, I get better throughput when adapting the number of consumer threads to the number of CPUs (already noticeable on old Core 2 Duo Mac laptops, for example).  Are you really advocating single-threaded producer/consumer in this day and age of multi-core CPUs?"	single-threaded			
"not advocating single threaded producer/consumer, I am saying that incorrect attempts at throwing threads at problems causes more problems that are much harder to solve. Core iX processors don't degrade gracefully under high CPU load. Example: Compiling software without using the hyperthreaded threads is faster than with them. On an i3 setting threads = 2 or i7 threads = 4 is about 25% faster than including all the ""threads"" when compiling. But without a proper async / non-blocking design threading is a moot point, because it isn't going to be concurrent anyway."	threading			
"To TacticalCoder you are arguing with yourself, I have never said any of the things you are arguing about. But to your point, if I have a serialized process and workflow using more than 1 thread will have no effect to a negative effect and never a positive effect. Compiling on an i7 with threads = 8 is much much slower than with threads = 4. The context switching and cache misses are very degenerate, especially on Windows!"	i7			
"You need to set ,Content-Type,. Something like this  ,Jsoup.connect(url).header(""Content-Type"",""application/xml"")"

"Too many questions! You might want to ask multiple questions, you've not just asked about primitives in API design."	primitives			
"There's no easy solution for this in Java: either you duplicate or  use code generators (that's how, say, Trove has fast TIntLongHashMap, which are only using primitives [and hence much faster than the default Java HashMap]) or you use objects, and live with the huge performance penalty. Auto-(un)boxing millions of primitives and generating millions of needless objects is a sure way to kill the perfs. Which is why for big collections of primitives the default Java API and stuff based on clean OO simply doesn't cut it. That's when you use things like Trove. It comes down to your requirements."	TIntLongHashMap			
Iterable is a nice one! Thank you!	you

"It's a nice pattern, but the downside is that I think it would confuse some people.  I updated my post to show results of a few tests that show that cloning and then iterating is OK performance wise.  But you're right that cloning isn't really super-fast, because if it was then there'd be no problem with repeatedly cloning in the loop.  And the tests show that clearly that has horrible results."	cloning

"To CodyMcCarty: but ,Person, is also just a ""plain object"" (with only these properties, i created (only) to make it compilable) of course: ..you'd have to instantiate/obtain one of ,your.domain...Person,."	(only)			
"They are in the ,org.omg, package (and other packages with that prefix). Most likely they are implementation classes, and they are not actually part of the Java API."	org.omg			
"""Generally it a convention to use ""_"" in variables name to indicate that they're instance variable or for some other special purpose"": Not in Java. A convention of this kind is required in C++ because of the constructor syntax for member variables. There is no such requirement in Java, hence it is rarely used, and only by people who think they're still programming in C++. The classes you mention were all defined by OMG in the early 1990s according to the naming restriction imposed by CORBA IDL, which again have nothing to do with Java."	_			
"To EJP: I see you're just like me, posting too much as a comment. More often than not you're giving a perfectly valid answer."				
To Gimby Thanks. It started out as a comment but grew like Topsy. I've posted it as an answer now.	Thanks			
"To VenkateshAchanta anything under the ,org.omg, package hierarchy is CORBA related and will use CORBA naming conventions rather than the usual Java ones."	org.omg			
"I use the underscore prefix in C#, because - while frowned upon occassionally - it does function as a convention and I've seen it in high quality source code, for instance in Entity Framework. Not so in Java, hence I don't. In Rome do as the Romans do. Interestingly though, in Android Studio, when you add a new activity, the skeleton code that gets generated for you uses ,m, prefix for class members (,mSectionsPagerAdapter, and the like), which I always thought of as a no-no, even worse than the underscore."	(mSectionsPagerAdapter			
"Half this table consists of merely repeating the rules of Java, which you ,can't, break. No 'should' about them."	them			
"When you say ""The Local?types are generic, not applying to any locality, having no time zone or offset-from-UTC."" What about if we set the JVM timezone to UTC so we can use our ,Local..., types with some serenity. Every time I have to work with dates this is what I do, I set the JVM to UTC, because the ,Local..., types are easier to use."	Local?			
"To akuma8 (A) Setting the current default time zone of you JVM has no effect on a ,LocalDateTime,. A ,LocalDateTime, has no concept of offset, so whether the default offset is zero or fourteen hours ahead or eight hours behind UTC does not change the meaning. (B) Any thread of any app within the JVM can change the current default time zone at any moment. So relying on the current default is unreliable. And changing the default time zone  immediately affects all threads of all apps within that JVM. So changing the default should be done only as a desperate last resort."	JVM			
"I did some tests see here: ,stackoverflow.com/a/54695987/6643803, and ,LocalDateTime,is well affected by the JVM time zone"				
"Joda-Time has not been included in Java-8 (same author but different products) and is officially supposed to be replaced by new ,java.time,-package."	java.time-package

May I ask why do you want to do that? Is it because you have legacy library code written in java? In the long term it would probably be better to have all your code in python(or C with which it interfaces very well) rather than a python/java mix. Having used matlab I understand why you'd want to call into non-matlab code for some tasks(given that matlab is horrendous for general purpose programming) but you won't have that problem if you're using python				
"PS: Jython won't work. Check this faq answer: ,scipy.github.com/faq.html#id23, In general, programs written in Jython won't have access to C-extensions written for CPython. Given that most(if not all) scientific libraries for python have their core functionality written in C, well, that won't work out so well"	Jython			
"Thanks, nor do I clearly.  I guess my problem with Jython is that it seems like it'll always be a step behind Python and not necessarily fully compatible.  Is that a legitimate concern?"	Jython

Is there a way to select a different AuthPolicy (e.g. SPNEGO) instead modifying the code?	code			
"To Njol Yeah that is just the example, I would hold a reference in the class. I can update"				
I'd go for the first one as you probably want to keep your API as clean and easy to use as possible. You should however document that internally WeakReferences are used to manage listeners.	API			
"""I had to also keep a reference to that listener elsewhere just to stop it getting GC"" Keeping another reference to the listener? Doesn't it make the WeakReference senseless then?"	listener			
Yes. That's why I removed the weak references. However there are cases where it might be useful. If you have business objects that are being used elsewhere and are also listeners then you might want to add them to listen to things but still have them GCd. Even that isn't ideal though as you could drop all references to something but it would still be receiving events for an unknown time afterwards and wasting resources. Basically in the end I decided that weak references just aren't useful for listeners.

"I remember we recently had something similar. You need to make sure your AWS IAM AccessKey/Secret are from the same region as you are making the request. So if you are calling sellingpartnerapi-eu.amazon.com then region is eu-west1. All credentials need also be eu-west1. The keyword ""Credential Scope"" was important in our case and this section of the documentation helped: ,github.com/amzn/selling-partner-api-docs/blob/main/guides/en-US "	keywordCredential

I keep getting a square and a rectangle that intersect. What could be causing this? perhaps the final ints? idk.				
"I just hand drew this scenario on graph paper and they do intersect. 0,0,1,1 means that the center of the rectangle is at (0,0). 1 is the width, and 1 is the height. This gives a square whose upper right corner is at (.5,.5). A rectangle centered at (2,2) with a width and height of four means that its lower left corner is at (0,0)."

"To EricStalnik well, this is of course completely abstract, so it's hard to say anything specific, but often, the protocol itself defines a number of data structures and common operations, which can all be defined in one common class. The encoder and decoder can then just use those data structures and call those operations, while presenting a simplified ""encoder"" or ""decoder"" interface."	encoder			
"Yes, I'm aware you're saying it's possible. What I'm asking is how the heck do you do it? What kind of design pattern would be used. I'm clueless."				
"To EricStalnik what do you mean? I just described how I would do it. You don't need a design pattern, it is possible to just write code which does what you need in the way that you want."				
"I would not decide based on that alone, as the implementation could be composed and just delegate to different classes implementing only the encoding and decoding respectively."

"Actually, REST says to treat URLs as opaque. There's no such thing as a ""RESTful URL"". Please don't conflate hackable URL best practices with REST constraints."	URLs			
"Eric, have you read ,Fieldings dissertation,. I don't think he agrees with you."	Fieldings			
"I have, in fact. Please point out where in the dissertation it suggests that REST URLs should contain semantically meaningful information for the client? I would also refer you to the horse's mouth: ,roy.gbiv.com/untangled/2008/rest-apis-must-be-hypertext-driven"	REST			
"I've already provided a link to the section which discusses this. It states plainly 'The key abstraction of information in REST is a resource. Any information that can be named can be a resource: a document or image, a temporal service (e.g. ""today's weather in Los Angeles""), a collection of other resources, a non-virtual object (e.g. a person), and so on. In other words, any concept that might be the target of an author's hypertext reference must fit within the definition of a resource. A resource is a conceptual mapping to a set of entities...'"	REST			
"The section you're quoting provides no guidance on what a URL should look like. Neither does anyplace else in the dissertation. REST, as defined by Fielding, means you're using HATEOAS and following links, not hacking URLs. Hackable URLs are a convenience for developers. They may or may not be good design, but they are not REST."	URL			
Thanks for the help. Problem was that the class was not set	help

"Word sense disambiguation is ,hard,.  Generic word sense disambiguation (i.e. not limited to a specific domain) is ,particularly hard,.  In many cases humans can't agree on which is ,the, appropriate sense in a given context, or even if there is one... Searching for ""java word sense disambiguation"" will give you a number of possibilities to start from, but whatever you use you'll probably need to customize in some form or re-train on your own data to get anything useful out of it."

One more help please. How not to load the system queue names?				
I don't think you can set filter a for not listing SYSTEM.* queues because the queue name parameter can't have a filter. You can specify a absolute or generic names only. But you can consider filtering out SYSTEM.* queues after listing.	SYSTEM.*

"i don't understand what you are trying to accomplish.  are you trying to get the build to break if incompatible versions are required?  or, are you trying to get maven to resolve the older version...?"	maven			
The build should fail if two dependencies are present that use incompatible versions of the same library.				
it would be impossible to include both dependency .jar files on the classpath and only the first one would be used anyway. What you are asking for isn't possible regardless of Maven behavior.				
"Gentoo has solved this by introducing the concepts of slots ,devmanual.gentoo.org/general-concepts/slotting/index.html"	slots			
You want the OP to change the artifact ID of an object when its major version changes? That seems extreme...	OP			
I'm not suggesting doing this for every artifact. Only those that break the API from one version to the next.  It's also not necessarily an ERROR to use two different APIs so long as they don't conflict internally.	API

"If the server is running Plugin.jar, you can create public methods inside its classes and allow devs to use them, importing them in their project. So you can have a ,PluginAPI, class with the method ,apiMethod(), inside Plugin.jar and it'll work as an API (you said that people will need your plugin running anyway)"	apiMethod()			
"The issue is that devs will not have access to the main Plugin.jar, which is why a separate PluginAPI JAR is essential."	PluginAPI			
"But Plugin.jar will be running on the server? If that's true, they already have access to the main Plugin.jar"				
"I can't use the same jar as the API, though. Plugin.jar is proprietary and not handed out to Developers, but we need a way for them to interact with it. I've seen it done the way I mentioned in my question before, but I can't remember where."	Plugin.jar

How does this have anything to do with the question?	question			
In order to diagnose possible causes of a crash during the execution of an application is a good practice start looking at the logs. Nevertheless they aren't very accessible while developing applications for Android. Using an application such as the one I mentioned it's handy.	logs			
"You can publish the API in an interface and make all implementations package local, for instance. Also, this is not true that a Java source file requires a public class: your class can be package local. You can declare ,class XX {}, in XX.java. This means XX will only be accessible from the same pacakge."	Java			
"With regard to nested classes you should consider also when to use non-static nested classes (inner classes) and when to use static nested classes. You may like reading this SOF question: ,stackoverflow.com/questions/70324 "	nested			
"As a programmer who relies excessively upon autocomplete, I don't agree with your last point - documentation won't achieve this. The best way to achieve conceptual simplicity is to limit choices."	autocomplete			
"Good answer. Hiding information is good in general, but can be a major pain inside a library that will surely have unforeseen use-cases."	general			
"Your mention of ,""the users with complex requirements, who will want to modify the API's behavior (at least) by inheritance, which a lot of 'hidden' stuff will successfully prevent"", is ringing very true right now for me - All I wanted to do was to extend a class in Google's HTTP client library, but due to things being ,private, I'm having to import the entire library source code as a local module that I can modify....."				
"Indeed, there is nothing bad when everything that is exposed is used! I just say: only expose what you want to be used. Otherwise users will see that their code stops working because some public ""internals"" in the lib changed."				
"Also see the open closed principle: a lib should be closed for modification, but open for extensions. ,oodesign.com/open-close-principle.html"	lib			
"I second that; especially the 'extensibility' part, of course :) - However, it seems to me that many programmers fail to (fore-)see why and how users will want to extend their code - and a single method or field carelessly declared ,private, (or even lazily 'declared' package-private) can exclude a whole lot of useful extensibility. Thus, I endorse ,careful, and reflected use of visibilites; and in that, I think, we agree after all."	visibilites			
"If a class is not carefully designed to be extendable, and is not intended to be extended, it should be final. That's another recommendation of Josh Bloch, IIRC. But extending a framework or API can be done (and, most of the time, should be done) without extending any class, but by wrapping them and using delegation instead of inheritance."				
"Question, does this only fetch a cert for existing users? Because how does a user you create have permission to for example use an Autologin profile if they haven't been created yet?"				
Only for system labels. User generated labels have unique IDs				
"It helps to further note that ,HashSet, has API on its own as well. For example it has constructors which are never a part of the API defined by implemented interfaces."	HashSet

"However, since the number of such tasks at a time could be more than 1(normally 4 or 5), the memory and performance issues come."				
"If there are data types in the profile that you didn't know about previously, chances are you're using a 3rd party library for something. There could be a possible culprit for leaking memory!"				
"Explicit GC is a bad idea. But -XX:+DisableExplicitGC will remove that problem. Instead, monitor the GC statistics using ""jstat"" or more advanced tools. Adjust the new vs old ratio, adjust the eden vs survior ratio."

To Andrew By removing the generic parameters and adding a warning suppression. Does a minor compiler error invalidate the answer to how a pattern for this could look?				
writing a pipe class with all the variants will not help me to make it generic. Instead I would be interested to write a wrapper over execute method.	wrapper			
"To anz Well, you know your problem space best. A wrapper over execute is fine, but what will it return? The next request, or the next ""out"" data? To chain them, you need both."	request			
"I was planning to create an executor which will consume a data structure (probably stack) with request sequence(s). And the wrapper is called recursively which will take request object and response object as arguments. Based on my request preference, wrapper will extract the necessary data from response and set in request then eventually call execute method. And end of the execution, final response from executor will contain complete response."	executor			
"This is not chaining as you are doing a redirect with every additional api call; API Chaining uses a FORWARD so as to reuse the token and headers and the original request. See the definition of API Chaining here : ,orubel.github.io/Beapi-API-Framework/advanced.html#section-3"	API

"To Roman: by ,""processes performed by my program"", do you mean all the threads your Java program is running or did your program spawn, say, other executables (Un*x shell processes, .exe, other Java program running in their VM, whatever)?"	processes			
"To WizardOfOdds, I mean ""all threads my Java program is running""."				
"How is your program invoked? Is some method of it called by an already running Java program, so effectively the two become one program? Or is the other program making a system call to start a new Java VM with your program?"	Java			
The answer I gave below describes how to terminate threads properly - not processes. I hope you find it helpful.				
"To stacker, do you mean that ,System.exit(0), will shut all threads down including thread of the external software (which started my program)."	System.exit(0)			
"It will kill the JVM.  So if the external software started your program by spawning a Java process, it will be fine.  If the external software is Java code that simply creates an instance of your class(es) and runs them, then that external code will be killed too."				
"In this case, I would say all exceptions caught are unlikely to happen. Therefore I would go for wrapping them in a more general exception - a custom exception.  I won't allow them to catch different level of exception since API users won't have access to the implementation details and won't be able to fix the problem. Hence, one exception to catch them all."				
"The API must not bleed implementation details. Therefore I agree with you regarding waraping all exceptions in one main exception.  Also, I think IllegalStateException is not an appropriate exception and I should go for something like OperationNotPerformedException which would indicate that the function cannot do its job properly due to some exceptional circumstances (detailed in the exception message)."	OperationNotPerformedException

"Does every consumer use every single field? If a consumer doesn't use or care about a field, then don't include it in the pact file. This enables a provider to see immediately which consumers would be affected by a change to that field when they run their verification specs. If you actually have 40 consumers of an API, then perhaps they could be using a shared client library, and the pact would just be between the client library and the API."	This

"How does ,NodeProxy, delegate to ,NodeImpl,? ,NodeProxy, does not use ,NodeImpl, in any way. It's the other way around - ,NodeImpl, uses ,NodeProxy,."	NodeImpl			
"Not sure what the benefits are because I know absolutely nothing about the framework you're looking at, but sounds like NodeProxy acts much like a service locator of a kind."	NodeProxy			
"It is called ,Bridge pattern"	pattern			
"To Cirkel Can't upvote enough, thanks for your answer!"				
"To Cirkel would yo mind to make your comment an answer, so that I can accept it?"				
"Sure but NodeProxy depends on Node as well, so instead of having one object dependent of Node, we now have an Object dependent on NodeImpl and Node and one dependent on Node - hard to see the advantage, but probably they have to work around some strange limitations/requisites we don't know of"	NodeProxy

"I would validate them in the REST service before passing them down. So validate in the service. If validation fails return some JSON object containing e.g. an error property. If it succeeds, call the DB, get data, return it back and set the error property to empty string. Sounds quite clean design to me. I recently built a REST API, quite similar, just not with MongoDB."	REST

Ive updated my example. Made the use case a bit simpler.				
Is there some extra information you were looking for on this question?				
"The issue is that is that for the user to be able to login, the developer of the app needs to provide their API too. Without this anyone can login from anywhere and there is no tracking of what apps are doing what. That would also mean that a user could not deauthorize a specific app."				
"If you want to try and restrict what app people are using to connect to your service, I think the best you can do is store a global secret in the app and use that to 'authenticate' that the request comes from a specific app. Anyone who is determined could extract that secret and then log in from anywhere (or publish the secret allowing anyone to log in from anywhere)."				
"Yeah that is the issue i am having. The fact that anyone can access the API key in the APK file. Guess it will have to do. There is not much they can do with it, to be able to perform any editing actions they still need to authenticate as a user, which they can only do with username and password (Probably get rid of that in the future)"				
There is no way to avoid the API key being readable - it is functioning as an encryption key and not as a hashable password	API			
"I had to build a complex scheduling system with the Java Calendar API a couple years ago. I will admit it is powerful and sophisticated but mainly, it is a big pain in the ass. It is way to complicated for your average date/time calculations. I just can't believe others are looking for a similar API for different languages."	Java			
"That's a calendar widget, not a library for performing computations involving dates and times."				
"To Mike Samuel - Agree, added a link which has many answers playing with date in js.."				
"I looked through the FAQ and Terms of Use for information about multiple accounts.  Multiple accounts don't appear to be forbidden.  However, the ToU says that you can't hide or mask your service's identity, so if you have multiple accounts it would probably be easy for them to figure that out - in case they were to crack down on that."				
"Ah, I need to be more thorough! I was looking at the SOAP Search API FAQ, not the AJAX one. Sorry about that."	SOAP

"The ""table view"" that you are showing is the result of running a BehaviorSpace experiment. Unless you're trying to do something unusual, this is not something you would use the controlling API to produce: just use BehaviorSpace directly instead. "In Java it considered to be a good design practice to have immutable objects, therefore having method which will change the state of the passed object might be considered as a code smell."	immutable			
thanks. You mean throwing exceptions captured by caller has the same effect of returning int value in C.	C			
"To frogcdcn Throwing exceptions allows much more flexible handling than the int status return strategy. You can put a sequence of related operations in the same try block, and deal with all the exceptions in its catch clauses. That makes the normal flow much cleaner than explicitly testing a return value after each call."	Throwing

"the link I've provided you shows that you have to download the javamail implementation :-) see step #4 ""download the java mail API"""	javamail			
"Leo is correct.  The JavaMail API can be implemented by other projects, but most people use the JavaMail Reference Implementation.  The GNU project has it's own implementation of the JavaMail API.  The JavaMail spec also allows you to plug in ""protocol providers"" that do the work of talking to mail servers.  The JavaMail Reference Implementation comes with protocol providers for SMTP, IMAP, and POP3.  See the ,JavaMail FAQ, for more details."

"I'm accepting this answer because I mentioned I want it published as an enum and there is no other way of doing it. Although I went on a different path because I wanted to expose some of the additional functionality (but not all), and obviously it is undesirable to duplicate the additional functionality. Instead I exposed the enums as interfaces where the additional functionality that I want to publish are part of the interface, and enum constants are also listed as interface constants. This solution also avoids having to make conversions and implementation changes."	enum			
"The enum is used from multiple packages of the library, so I cannot reduce visibility. This implies the composition is also not a good solution (because it uses restricted access)."				
"The problem with this as mentioned in the question is that the enum is used from multiple packages of the library, so the visibility of additional attributes and methods cannot be reduced."	enum			
"Maybe instead of this you can try to expose attributes with getter methods and even returning defensive copies to defend yourself from misuse?  If this is not possible, then I am afraid that you will need to redesign your library with a strict division between private logic and public DTOs visible to the API user."

"If my starting point was on the vertex of one of the Polygons and travels to another vertex on the same Polygon, then only checking the border does not catch this intersection right? Since each Polygon is a solid object, my path would not be able to travel through it and only checking the borders would result in a false positive. However, if I checked any combination of lines between the points of the Polygon, it would correctly catch this error."				
"Okey, so by intersect you mean that this line must start outside the polygon, goes through it, and end again outside?"	polygon			
"Ohh... I understand - you think about the situation when one vertex of your line lays exactly at border of polygon, yes?"				
"No, I mean it is not allowed to intersect the polygon as it is a solid shape. So your solution works well if the starting point it outside of the polygon since the borders will catch any intersection. However, if the starting point is on the polygon itself and the ending point is also on the polygon, then the border will not necessarily catch an intersection. This would mean that a line was able to travel through the polygon when it should not have been allowed to do that."	polygon			
"Hmmm, now i understand perfectly what you mean  but is this steal means that line intersect polygon or just that polygon contains a line?"	polygon			
"I'm actually considering this solution at the moment as it seems to make sense in my head. I'm just imagining how this scenario plays out with a large amount of shapes. It seems like with each move from vertex to vertex, which is what my program will be doing, I would have to check every combination of points within each shape to see if it intersects with my path. I was looking for a more graceful solution, but if this is the best out there then I may have to play around with this suggestion."				
You check for intersection until you find one that does intersect. You can stop at that point. There are definitely ways to optimize this.	this			
If polygon will be created by lines connecting every two points it will be a chaos not a polygon	polygon

"What are you actually trying to achieve? Do something at regular intervals on the server, or actually make an HTTP request to your server periodically?"

"Then start forgetting about doing it with a servlet. A servlet's only goal is to serve HTTP requests. You don't want to deal with HTTP requests, here. All you want is to do something at regular intervals on your server. Look at ,docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent , and ,docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/api/javax/servlet "	servlet

"Never never never use ,Timer, in a Java EE application!"	Timer			
To BalusC sir: Why we dont want to use timer in java EE application?				
"See linked duplicate. In short: it doesn't fit in the ""lifetime long running"" nature of a Java EE application. E.g. if an exception is thrown within a timer thread, the timer is effectively dead. It basically won't run anymore until you restart the whole server. This just doesn't make sense."	Java			
What error do you get?

So you don't think the name is to long?	long			
"A method name should convey meaning.  If it requires a few extra characters to do that I feel its ok.  I get frustrated when I see method names kept intentionally short just to save a few keystrokes.  These names deviate from the main goal of a method name, which is to tell you what the heck the method does.  If your to lazy to press a few extra keys, you have bigger problems than the method name."				
"To Bob I wasn't calling you lazy.  I have just had experiences where developers have completely misrepresented the named of a method because it was easy to type.  For example one piece of code I looked at had a method named nice().  It ran some js that added styling to certain elements.  How are you supposed to know what nice() actually does by looking at a method call, especially in JS where intellisense is lacking in most ides"	nice()			
"To Bob I'd use ,get, prefix. Because what you do is getting records. ,all, can mean realy ,anything, - for example ""append argument to all records and return them""."	get

"No, it won't compile.  The OP is confusing the compile time exception that would be thrown by the above example with a run time exception that is mentioned by the map API.  As To Affe has pointed out, the run time exception mentioned by the API should only be thrown if the new Map implementation has a special requirement that is not met (eg if the new Map requires a positive key and a negative key is specified)."	Map

"There are, but I would argue that you should understand the ideas underlying the widgets before you begin producing things with a widget library.  HTML/CSS have enough wrinkles (thinking about browser-compatibility, here) that eventually you're going to hit something that the widget library does stupidly--and if you can't work with the HTML/CSS directly, you're dead in the water.  Understanding the DOM is also necessary for any kind of UI coding you need to do... and it's easier to just learn it than to fob it off on a secondary library."	widgets			
"I'm not disagreeing, just pointing out that there are abstractions to html and css"	css

"It reads ""an octet of data"" (octet = 8 bits) from the source .. in this case the data would be from an opened File as it is a RandomAccessFile implementation .. (the return type is an ,int, merely so it can return ,-1, on EOF, otherwise it will be ,[0, 256),)"	RandomAccessFile			
"+1,  i wasn't sure what does a byte means in terms of reading from a file; but the size of the byte is (8 bit) and range -128 to 127"				
"Yup.  In Java, a ,byte, is a signed value from -128 to 127.  Other languages have an unsigned version with a range of 0 to 255. In English, a ""byte"" is any 8-bit value, usually in memory or storage; such a value in the process of being transmitted is often called an ""octet"" instead. And in really old (pre-1980, at least) papers you can find ""byte"" used to refer to the native word size of a machine, no matter how many bits that is."	byte

"My rule of thumb is never to return a null from my methods, but an empty object."				
To zuckerburg Does that mean you return an object in invalid state instead of null?				
"To Torben It means to create something like ,public static final Foo EMPTY = new Foo(), and let the method return ,FOO,."	Foo			
"To avoid Null checks and NPE Optional feature was introduced. Take a look at ,oracle.com/technetwork/articles/java "	oracle.com/technetwork/articles/java			
"To zuckerburg It sounds to me that you've taken the legitimate empty-list-instead-of-null practise and extended it to where it doesn't belong. Returning an empoty and invalid object instead of null still requires you to make the check. If you forget that check (which will necessarily be more complicated than ""== null"") you pass the invalid object to a method that doesn't allow nulls and the error is potentinally sent way further down the call stack (and made more obscure). I'd strongly advise against empty objects (other than collections)."	empty-list-instead-of-null			
"When you're not sure if something ,could, return null, then the API is broken and must be fixed so you're sure it can return null. Then... when you're sure it can return null you document it by returning an Optional instead of a direct, nullable, object reference."				
"I was not talking about in the case of not knowing what an API method could return, but rather, in the case of having possible values passed to a method that will return null. Consider having a List<X> containing 'null' at index 4, and you call list.get(4), returning a null value for data you might've expected to be non-null. In this case, you would require a null-check because you're not sure if the method will return null. It doesn't imply a broken method; it implies an unexpected error that should be accounted for. Using an Optional, or anything similar, would be effectively the same."	list.get(4)			
Seems like your SDK version is off.	SDK			
"DejanRistic is right. Just bear in mind that ,jsonObject.put(""xyz"", new JSONArray(Arrays.asList(floatArray))), will give you an array containing your e.g. float array (,{ ""xyz"": [[1.0, 2.0, 3.0]] },), while ,JSONArray arr = new JSONArray(); for (float value : floatArray) { arr.put(value); }; jsonObject.put(""xyz"", arr), would in turn provide you just with an array, as you'd expect (,{ ""xyz"": [1.0, 2.0, 3.0] },)."	JSONArray(Arrays.asList(floatArray)))

To pzaenger it was one of the approaches we discussed	pzaenger			
"While mapping HTTP operations to simple CRUD operations might sound like a good idea, HTTP operations in genearal are to general to support such a mapping blindly. I.e. ,DELETE, only gurantees that the connection between the URL and the resource is removed but leaves the client clueless whether the server also removes the data belonging to the resource as well. A client in general is usually not interested in such internal decisions anyway as long as the resource state isn't retrievable any longer."	HTTP			
"Further, the spec leaves room for interpretation. DELETE i.e. only states that certain response codes should be returned if the operation actually removed something but not what should happen if i.e. the resource was not available at all. Here it is more or less individual preference. All a client wants is that a certain URI shouldn't return a resource's state after the invocation. A 404 tells the client the the resource didn't exist before while a 200 response informs a client that no representation for the requeted URI is available any further. ..."	i.e			
"... The effect, however, are pretty similar that invoking the URL doesn't return any resource's state further. It is therefore more or less an implementation detail not that important to clients"	URL			
"Oh, sure. But I can conclude that something was wrong within the Requested-URI"	Requested-URI			
"Well yes but ""something wrong with the requested URI"" is not something that necessarily caries ,business, meaning and your question ,was quite particularly, about ""should represent ,business, failures"".  You do want to distinguish ""business-level"" failures from the other ones."	business-level

"I would add that the ""concurrent"" package is a colleciton of utils for building concurrent applications.  the utils are all ""thread-safe"".  Some are more intrinsically ""concurrent"" than others."	concurrent

"Well, it is not 1 January 2016. Where I am, it is 6 October 2016. Hence, you will not get ,2016-01-01 00:00:00,, unless you changed your device/emulator to set the date to 1 January 2016. And the ,00:00:00, part will vary depending on the time that you execute the code."

"why do some OO languages not even have the equivalent of Java's ,class,?  In a clean OO design, the only thing that matter is the abstraction.  Concrete and abstract Java classes are implementation details: people use them because they seek to avoid ""code reuse"" (not realizing that they can achieve what they think they need to achieve extending Java classes using, say, delegation and composition). Implementation details do ,not, exist at the OOA/OOD level. In addition to that, Java interfaces allows multiple inheritance, which matters when doing an OOA/OOD to OOP translation."	Java			
"Btw a question like this: ,stackoverflow.com/questions/90851 , just shows how clueless most answerers and upvoters are on SO.  Take SO with a huge grain of salt, for it is not the stronghold of OO-savvy developers ;)"	stackoverflow.com/questions/90851			
"Although a very good reason, it doesn't apply to the OP's example. Stellent isn't built for 3rd party implemenations."	OP's

"Do you mean that for the basic, return option 1, and for the extra, return option 2?"				
"We don't know exact context. If you create API you should clearly understand what you should get as an result. For example, if you have some UI and you would like to fill some table with columns ""id"", ""name"", ""description"", ""price"", ""stock"" and this is only one thing for which you need API endpoint I would suggest option 3 with endpoint ,/cars/1,, but JSON: ,{     id: 1,     name: ""Honda Civic"",     description: ""The best car of Honda"",     price: 25000,     stock: 24 },. About null value, there is a rule ""Don't show more information than needed"" or at least show ,{}, instead of null."				
"personally, I maintain API request params also in the response. So that front end can decide and parse response accordingly. like   ,{ params: { info: true, extraInfo: false }, data: { id: 1, name: ""Honda Civic"", desc: ""blah blah"", meta: {price: 25000, stock: 24 }}}"				
"I like that option too. However, in terms of maintainability, if some day we want to add the parameter info=extraPrices, we can't extend from CarExtra, as in JPA is not that easy. We would have to create a CarExtraPrices that extends from Car again, duplicating the extra fields already present in CarExtra."	CarExtraPrices

"Just a note to people Googling the Facebook error 'Key hash ** does not match any stored key hashes', the error log gives you the hash to paste into your Facebook developer console. "There is no ,setSize, method and collections are not beans so ,size, is perfectly fine."	size			
"possible duplicate of ,Why doesn't ArrayList have getSize() instead of size()?"	getSize()			
"Hu. This shouldn't be closed as ""primarily opinion based"", since there  exists a description of the rationale for this by the designers of the Java collection framework -- no opinion involved here (except of those of the designers). But it should be closed as ""duplicate of"" (sorry, didn't check before answering). Anyway, closed is closed."				
":L Never realised how lazy Oracle was. If something is to stay on the same line it generally refers to the physical screen's size, no? And plus, what difference does it make? Even if it fits nicely on the same line it doesn't have the ... umph(?) that a core Java class should have. Shun Oracle, shun."				
"Also think about it like this, yes it's shorter to write but if you try writing getSize() first (as many would agree would be logical) and then you need to change it to size() you lose all the benefits of 3 letter shorter word. This still happens to me all the time and I have been programming in Java for 4-5 years, I guess it happens even to people with more experience."	size()

"thanks for your reply. The reason for having camera as static variable is because I had problems in passing it from activity to activity as normal object. Static seemed as easiest solution. Now, could you explain though why this static variable is returning null? I'm sure there is simple explanation that will embarass me horribly but I would love to know."				
"Well, it's just a supposition (I've never seen this situation), but bear in mind applications keep being paused and resumed, created and destroyed lots of times during its execution. It could be that your application lost track of when the camera was first created (probably inside ,MyFirstAppActivity,), so your best chance here is to ensure you have your camera ready by checking it before (just like To TranquilMarmot suggested). Those lines are worth the exception you avoid."	MyFirstAppActivity)			
"Checking for null and assigning new Camera solved my problem, thanks for suggestion."	Camera

How to configure pool limit? Have not found answer in docs.				
"Hi Ferdynand: this is an implementation detail - so there is no ""official"" documentation. As a matter of fact there is actualy no such thing as ""the connection pool"". The HttpClient supports both HTTP/1.1 and HTTP/2 and so it has two pools - which are handled differently because of the specifics of each protocol. My answer above concerns only the HTTP/1.1 connection pool. By default it is unbounded, and connections in that pool are kept alive for 1200 seconds, unless closed by the server side."	HttpClient			
"what about this: ,github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob , ?  all the properties seem to be documented here: ,docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/core "	thisgithub.com/openjdk/jdk/blob

"What do you mean by it ,""requires a MapAdapter from Java, as passing parameter"",? You are invoking a SOAP web service which expects an XML message. All you have to do is send it a properly structured XML request. You don't have to deal with anything Java in your Python code. Maybe edit your question to add more details about it and make it clear what the issue is."	MapAdapter			
"zeep allows you to call the web service methods with Python code and Python data to send to those methods. Zeep then marshals all of that into XML form and transforms your Python method call into a SOAP call to the web service. There is no Java class. There might be on the web service side if the service is written in Java, but you don't care about that as the client invoking  the service from Python. I asked for more details because your question doesn't really make sense in the way SOAP web services work."	zeep			
"The web service code is written in Java, that's right. My question is a little bit complicated, because the API is only checking, if the object is iterable, so it's sending a positive response.  In my opinion the error is behind the API, that the interface accesses functions if the ,MapAdapter,and here the error occurs, which I cannot read out."	MapAdapterand			
So what result are you getting? An error message? An empty result? How did you find out about the MapAdapter issue?	MapAdapter

as is not allowed post answers in questions marked as duplicate i will make it here cause spent huge amount of time to figure out how to do it  You can make RestTemplate make GET requests with body by using it over apache http client with some tuning:	RestTemplate			
class HttpGetWithBody extends HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase {             HttpGetWithBody(final URI uri) {                 setURI(uri);             }             To Override             public String getMethod() {                 return HttpGet.METHOD_NAME;             }         }	HttpGetWithBody			
"HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory requestFactory = new HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory(){             To Override             protected HttpUriRequest createHttpUriRequest(HttpMethod httpMethod, URI uri) {                 if (httpMethod == HttpMethod.GET) {                     return new HttpGetWithBody(uri);                 }                  return super.createHttpUriRequest(httpMethod, uri);             }         };"	HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory			
RestTemplate restTemplate = new RestTemplate(requestFactory);	RestTemplate

"Exception in thread ""main"" java.lang.RuntimeException: Failed : HTTP error code : 200 	at TST.main(TST.java:29)"				
"That is actually a success code. ,200, means OK. In your code you check only for ""HTTP_CREATED"", which is ,201,. Every ,2xx, code is actually a success response, so you shouldn't throw an exception for them. Some more info here: ,en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_HTTP_status_codes"				
Yes this resolve my issue i have commented the code which actually throws exception but if i want to throw exception other than 2xx then what should i do.	2xx

"First tells you if the Object is going to be the method handling your request. Second can be null if the annotation IpRestrictred is not present among ""download()"" method annotations. For example if you don't want all methods are restricted by ip you will configure the annotation only on methods requiring it."				
For example it can be a org.springframework.web.socket.server.support.WebSocketHttpRequestHandler	org.springframework.web.socket.server.support.WebSocketHttpRequestHandler

"You have two options. Either you use Annotations (example: To PreAuthorize(""hasIpAddress('127.0.0.1')""), or put together a ""security.xml"" config file."	PreAuthorize(hasIpAddress('127.0.0.1'))

"Well, the most common reason of Spring Security not working I think is the filter not being registered at all. Please check this: ,stackoverflow.com/a/10427242/821786, ."	Spring			
"It will work, yes. Spring security is a flexible library, but being a library it is obviously more complex. If you are not planning to do further improvements on your authentication in this app, then it is completely ok to use the homemade annotation."	annotation

"Keep in mind this isn't a real problem. Using ,BasicNameValuePair, as I suggested that mean you don't send json string to server, so this header caused confusion for the server because server accept header ,application/x-www-form-urlencoded,. You should read ,HttpPost, document ,en.wikipedia.org/wiki/POST_(HTTP),  for more detail. Therefore, your data send to server should look like this: ,Field17=Some+Value"

"What do you think about checking the postcondition as suggested in my edits? I have already changed the API, but have to debug, because somehow something doesn't work anymore (most unit tests fail ;-)). However I don't think it's too much of a burden to use ,trx.up().get().right().get().right().get(),, but ok, it seems a bit ugly. Maybe your approach is better. What do others think?"	postcondition			
"As for the NullNode, it could be done as implementation for the lenient part, but I'd strongly prefer to throw on each problem by default. I wouldn't use ,Optional,, as I can't see any case here when it brings any advantage. In your above chain you had to write ,get(), three times -- that would be acceptable but only if you could write something meaningful without those many ""gets"". Can you?"	Optional			
"To Johannes: Nearly everything can be done with lenient, e.g. ,trx.lenient().right().lastNonFailed(), moves to the right if possible, but again, I'm pretty sure that what's needed most of time is the strict fail-fast behavior. Lenient just allows you to have both."	behavior			
"Actually I think it's more a question of that I really need both cases (boolean return value and the transaction instance, not so much about fail fast or not). Otherwise I can't use moveToX()-methods in loops and other statements."	moveToX()-methods

"Aside from looking into the links that everyone else has posted, I would recommend googling tutorials on ""whatever you're trying to do"" and getting an idea of how it works.  You can do just about anything, so you have to have some starting point. Are you working witha  database? trying to draw a circle? writing a web server? etc. etc. You need to have an objective and then just google ""how do I ______ in Java"". It will be a process of trial and error from there, but you'll definitely learn about the multitudes of libraries and APIs available to you."	googling

"So you're suggesting to use the client side invocation for performances reasons, I thought this was one of the key point.."				
"I was working with the AJAX search library. My first implementation, had GWT send the request to the server, the server ran the search and then return the results to the client. There was a noticeable delay of a few seconds for this round trip. Using the client library, the results are almost instantaneous. Of course your mileage may vary..."

Is it simply because I'm directly allocating a new array rather than letting the ArrayList create one through some kind of reflective mechanism (which is slightly more efficient in modern jvms)? "Note that according to ,shipilev.net/blog/2016/arrays-wisdom-ancients/#_conclusion, ""toArray(new T[0]) seems faster, safer, and contractually cleaner, and therefore should be the default choice now""."	T[0])			
Why are you using primitive arrays instead of lists? Just curious	lists			
"Primitive arrays are lots faster and more memory-efficient (think of operations on huge number matrices) ;)     But to be able to generalize certain functionality, I also need boxed arrays."				
"I see. Probably using an initial size in the List big enough would make it as fast and efficient as bare arrays. After all, ,ArrayList, for instance uses arrays as underlaying store."				
"Yes, it would be probably similarly fast, but not as memory efficient: boxed types are objects, each one of them has an overhead (compared to primitive types). Also, think of garbage collection: what is faster, freeing a fixed primitive array, or millions of objects? ,(I would guess, it's quite a difference)."

"The fact that your returning a value from some and not others screams that these implementations are representing two different concepts/operations.  Maybe if you give an idea of what these classes do, we can make better suggestions. Constantly checking for a subinterface and downcasting can get messy, as well as always checking for a null result."				
"These classes are for handling the processing of commands recieved from command line. Each class is having the specific logic for the type of command it handles. The interface provides a common api through which you can handle any type of command at runtime. And suddenly there is a usecase where some commands will need to return something( not just display the result), so that this return value can be used for some other purposes. Basically, trying to reuse the existing code."	These

"Thank you for answer I understand your point. The problem I have is that I have two operations, that are completely asynchronous and there is ,no way, I can make them synchronous. I have an ,inputstream, from which I block-read incoming data for as long as the connection is alive and an ,outputstream, from which I write data to send. So  when I ,requestMyData(), I am effectively writing bytes ,out, and when the answer comes ,in,, the block-read releases and returns the result then starts block-reading again for next requests. So, two async operations, how can I ,join, them ?"	block-read			
"Meanwhile, the solution I found is starting a second chain with a ,SingleSubject, that triggers when the data is ready. SingleSubject

"You sound a little confused; ROC curves, by default, are calculated across all possible threshold values, and not for specific ones - see ,stackoverflow.com/questions/47104129 , for some explanation"				
"Thanks for your reply To desertnaut . Yes, I am little confused about how exactly I can calculate TPR and FPR for different threshold values. I want to calculate  TPR and FPR like as precision and recall using Java Code (see Source Code)."	TPR			
"ROC is pointless with classification methods, as the decision has already been made by the algorithm and there is no threshold to vary any longer. You need to get access to the class probabilities or some raw, quantitative score. I don't know how you'd do that with weka. Maybe try to find a regression algorithm instead."	probabilities

Isn't that the point of a predicated list that you only want things in the list that adhere to the conditions defined for it?    Why not just use an ordinary list?	predicated			
"Yes, it is the point of a predicated list. But I want it to quiety ignore things that don't match the predicate, i.e. do the predicate check, but don't complain if it doesn't match."	predicated			
"That's logically the same behavior as an ordinary list, since you don't care about the predicate check informing you that an element didn't pass."	list			
"No it isn't the same. You can add null to a standard ArrayList as many times as you want. They go in as individual elements. So do ""l.add(null); l.add(null); l.size();"". l.size() will return 2. I don't want the nulls to be added to the list, hence why I want to use something like a PredicatedList."	PredicatedList

Hmm the question now talks about Threads... weird edit.	Threads			
Java is a very old language that has gone through many iterations and they try like hell to be backward compatible. This is akin to Python < 3.0. Java unfortunately does not have a benevolent dictator like Ruby and Python so changes that break stuff are very hard to get placed in the language (we have an evil fat/lazy dictator named oracle). If it really bothers you I recommend you look at Scala (which has the opposite problem of changing everything every release).	Java

"To Devs not really, that question is about how to package code as an API, this question is more about what a good API looks like."	API			
"the ,setName(), method can check the name or you can add the ,checkName() ,method to the People class. would that help?"				
"Thanks, or should I just use the interface and let it implement the interface, but remove the static from all checking method. So, if others want to use my API, they just instantiate the interface, and use instance.checkName() to call method ? is that a good way ?"	interface			
"Shouldn't the object itself be self validating?  That's kind of the point of OO.  A procedural language would have functions for validating other ""structures"", but an OO language should focus on self contained units of work - IMHO. Not to say you wouldn't have business logic that wouldn't do extra checking though"				
"Thanks very much for your elaborated and useful feedback. I actually know how the people class is going to be checked.  but just the people class may be changed and I also need to make some change on my checking function. But, I know how the people class is going to change and how I should change my check function.  The consumer of my checking function dont need to change their code for existing checking function like check name, and they need to add new function call for newly added checking function like checkingAddress.  Yes, I should make the ppl class final cause I just read it not write"	ppl			
"For the case is like the comment above, should I still use this registering way to build this API  ? or static method.  How about making all checking funcion the public (non static) method, and define an interface including all these checking function. caller just need to instantiate this interface (e.g., checkingfunctions), and call the function like:   checkingfunctions.checkName(ppl);  is this also feasible ?  For this interface one and class including static methods, which one is recommended ? Thanks"				
"If only you alone ever need to change the checking function but your users are never supposed to change them, then I would definitely use public static methods for these functions. But if somehow possible, I'd consider adding a single default checking method instead of multiple ones. E.g. just ,public static check(People),. This default method could then call the more specific functions like ,checkName,, ,checkAddress, etc. as appropriate. This way your users would perhaps not need to change their code each time you add a new checking function to your code."	checkName			
I wouldn't provide an interface to the public api if you know that there is only ever going to be a single class that extends this interface...				
"Thanks, yes, that is what I did. I create a method call checkPeople including all related method like checkName, checkAge. but the caller told me they also need to access some specific method like checkName individually. Thus, it need to open all checking methods to them. I can use the static method.  BTW, I am the only owner of this checking service and no one else can change it."

That obviously might not be your problem, but it's hard to tell what's going on without seeing how you're using the key."	key

"There are many ways to consume RESTful APIs - typically, you need to know what version of the API you are going to use.  When the API changes (ie. a different version is exposed) you need to decide if the new functionality is worth migrating your application(s) to the latest and greatest or not... It always requires some effort to migrate to new APIs"				
"To ochi that could be an answer, adding the fact that WHEN there is different API versions to use. I have seen companies that just change without let the old one available. I know, terrible but it happens"	use			
"To JorgeCampos definitely happens; I've seen it too... serious companies with interests in keeping their consumers happy know not to do that :) - even then, eventually they might drop support for old/deprecated APIs (with enough warning, communication to the consumers, of course) - per your suggestion, adding it as an answer"	course)

Then I want to consume APIs from Weather.com to integrate weather info into my app. From my understanding I can consume it in 2 ways: 1) Using Javascript to call the API and display result in the browser 2) Call API on the server side (my app's server side) and then send result to my app's client (ie: browser)  Is this correct?	API

"HI Ochi. Can you be more specific about ""many ways"". For each way, can you list out the steps like I do. Thanks"	many			
"To hdang the steps you listed are correct.  Overall, if you want to manipulate the response in Java, you would need to map them to your Employee entity.  However, imagine that if your JSON response is flat (i.e. only key/value pairs) you may not want to bother with an Employee entity and instead use a Map.  Or if your JSON response is mostly an array of flat objects you can create an array of Map objects.  Using GSON (or similar) is the way to go for most cases"				
"Also consider if you need to map them in Java at all - if they are going to be displayed in the UI only, why not pass the JSON response directly to the UI and let JS do the sorting/mapping - Yes, you need to adjust your UI/JS accordingly every time the JSON format changes but your Java side of things will remain the same."				
Thanks Ochi. These explanations helps	These

"In principle, the transaction mechanism is designed for this purpose. What further requirements you have that you consider transaction rollback as  ,unpleasant side effects in the DB, ?"				
"Yeah, the problem is that different DBs have different behaviour for such kind of events. In my case I got some kind of blocking because of complex replication structure. I generally don't want to catch and receive any kind of such exceptions from the DB, I want to prevent their appearance."				
I am right or wrong. I don't know as per my knowledge we can do one thing just check the data is available in db or not like getFooById(id); if you get the data than you can delete same data otherwise you can throw the exception that data is not there	wrong			
"The problem that this approach doesn't cover my current hassles. Several multiple requests of DELETE of same raw in heavy loaded DB causes kind of blocking, so all this multiple requests fail with 504 timeout error. Certainly all delete methods themself  are performed in transactional level. But it doesn't cover case when DB itself behaves in improper way."				
"504 timeout error on delete requests is generaly a symptom of not being able to get a (pessimistic) lock. But this a the hard part of optimizing the database accesses and it heavily depends on the database itself and the major use cases. I'm sorry, but I am afraid I cannot say much more. Maybe you could try to replace pessimistic locks with optimistic ones to exchange 504 timeout errors with messages like ,System was busy and could not complete your request, please try again.."				
"That's not suitable. As I wrote in my question, the direct way will be introduce synchronisation on particular entities's ids. This will simply prevent DB from being locked, so it will be no any hassles with timeout exceptions - sequentially executed DELETE methods will quickly return OK, as deleting of an absent entity in my API is legal operation. My question was about: is it possible or not, use existent capabilities of Spring MVC framework to do the same trick on more higher level."	synchronisation			
"To Andremoniy: I'm not aware of anything apart from transaction at Spring level. And at the Web level, nothing better that an interceptor..."				
"Using only one retrofit url, I injected Retrofit instances in my data manager. You can see it in EDIT. I did not use To Inject annotation and it worked without it"

"See how you provide ,Firebase, instance in your module. You have annotated it with ,To Named(FIREBASE),, it means you have to annotate it in the constructor parameter also."	Firebase

You can't tell a server you are sending json and expect it to be able to parse something that is not json. A 400 is a step in the right direction. It tells you your request body is either missing something or not formatted correctly.  It might help if you read the response body.	json			
There is no ideal format. It depends on what the server accepts. Most servers accept form-urlencoded but that is no guarantee.

Send a post request using apache HTTP client and get the token from the response and concat Bearer and a space on start of the token Put this token in the header of the 2nd post request and send the post request to your API and get the required response back	HTTP

"we can use the header in API when getting the response. In the Header, we use a key then the condition is PHP code where the key is the change you cannot get a response.if someone knows your key then getting a response. This trick is to protect your response data."	API			
so anybody has unconditional access to version control system and can do changes? It doesn't make sense to develop protection if you can't control who can do changes in code.				
How can I change the setting of the repository such that no one else is allowed to update the code?.....You mean having private repo??	repo			
"To Arivazhagan no, it could be public. But you can define who contributes to the project. If you do not allow any one else as a contributor to the project, then no one would be able to commit any changes in the main repository. They could still fork a public repository and make changes in their local machine. But since there are not allowed to merge their changes to the main repository it will not go to production. If you want no one to see your code, then you need to make it private."	project			
"Usually in an organization, only the senior folks would have the access to update the code. So junior folks would make updates in the code from their local machine and put a ,merge request, (gitlab term). This merge request needs to be approved by someone who has the right to make updates. Only if it is approved, the code would reach main repository."

"Yes, this does look strange. Nothing audio-related would be sampling at these speeds anyway."				
The number of frames per second also makes no sense. Have you tried running it?				
"Our ears top out at around 20kHz, but the Nyquist theorem states that to avoid aliasing, the sampling rate must be 2 x bandwidth.  This is the main reason the CD standard was designed with a sampling rate of 44.1kHz.  The numbers you have still make no sense of course."	CD			
"To z7sg血 I started freaking out when I read the question, and your comment really scared me. Then, I realized that the word was ""top"", not ""pop"". I'm sure glad my ears don't pop out at around 20kHz."	question

"There's a standard solution to that problem.  Say the file is called ,config.txt,.  Create a copy of this file, ,config.txt.template,.  Replace all of the configuration data (including the API key) with placeholder example data in this template file.  Then add ,config.txt, to the ,.gitignore, file.  Now, you can commit the template file without adding any real and/or sensitive data to the repository.  To set up a new clone, you just have to copy all of the ,foo.template, files to ,foo, and edit their contents appropriately."	config.txt			
"I figured out a way to do it by adding the header manually:         ,connection = Connector.newConnection(sfConfig);       QName headerName = new QName(""urn:enterprise.soap.sforce.com"", ""CallOptions"");   XmlObject header = new XmlObject(headerName, null);   header.addField(""client"", clientId);   connection.addExtraHeader(headerName, header);"	manually

"It depends on the number of the languages you need to support. Are there a few and fixed languages? (for example English, French and German?). "You will have to get the whole string that contains all the names in all languages (separated by "","") and then select only the n-th substring of that string."	)			
"For example, if language is English, select the first substring (until the first "",""), if the language is French, select the second substring (between the first and the second "","")."
