"I have no experience with Vert.x, but I am interested in it. I thought it was a gateway application. In that case it would be used for service registration/load balancing and aggregation. So, the underlying services would have the same verticals. If it is very good at aggregation then in the case that it makes sense to provide an API that gives results from multiple underlying services then Vert.x should be able to combine asynchronous results from individual vertical services. Again, no experience with Vert.x directly. This question is too broad for this forum. Perhaps a google group?"	Vert.x			
"HAL is just one format. The objective is to be able to discover/navigate the API through links. So it doesn't have to be in the HAL format, as long as you can fulfill the objective. I personally don't like the HAL format, but I do find having links to related objects very beneficial."	API			
"To PaulSamsotha, I agree with you, HAL is not a must and is often a matter of taste, but in case of HATEOAS is it necessary for a private API with a single and defined client(for now)? Are there any benefits other than depriving the front-end client of having to build links to access specific endpoints? As we can verbally communicate about which endpoint to access for specific actions."				
"Links make the API self documenting, which makes it overall easier for the developer to use, internal or not. When exploring an API, I would rather see links to everything associated with the customer, than have to switch over to looking at some external docs."	API			
"You should apply REST principles whenever you don't want server changes to break clients. REST is just a generalization of the Web where browsers remain stable whenever a server changes i.e. URIs of certain resources or adds new content. When you don't need such properties (i.e. your server and client always changes together and there is only ever one version available) then just don't go for the REST-train, but don't fall into the marketing trap and simply don't call it REST API/client then"	REST			
"If you think about how the Web evolved to its current state you might agree that its success was probably provided due to its robustness and its freedom it gave to webservers providing web content. Besides HTML pages a ton of additional content is exchanged, like images, videos and what not. Plenty of features where added over the years through extensions or plugins. Instead of a browser expecting a certain link to return a PNG image, the client tells the sever what format it is capable of and the server will provide (ideally) a representation the client understands."	Web			
"This is exactly what REST tries to provide to other application than the browser based Web. Most of the so called REST APIs out there are RPC just with a marketing label ""REST"" put on them. I don't think that aiming for REST is therefore a shot into ones own foot. I rather try to see the meaning into exposing the DB layer through an additional model layer and convert that to JSON through CRUD operations instead of directly exposing the DB itself, especially for an internal application. Plenty of stuff is already provided by DB, like views or user restrictions."	REST			
"ERP systems usually understand different formats. Some of them are standardized like ,application/edifact, some others follow a custom specification or XML/CSV dialect. Currently the API dictates which formats (and which fields) a client receives when it would be more benefitial if the client would just send the media-types it knows how to process and the API would return those. Also, link relations and their accompanying URIs could be utilized to guide clients into up- or downloading documents and retrieve their state or geneate an archive of the past month."				
"The point I'm trying to make clear is, you can't forsee the future and even an internal API/tool might get public over the years. If you are in a situation where you have plenty of clients using your API (internal or external doesn't matter really) and you need to change something you have basically 3 options. If you already have a REST architecture you should be fine otherwise you either need to patch the changes somehow into your application or redesign it from scratch. Option 2 (patch), however, leads to either a hard to use API or hard to maintain code (or both) over the years"				
"Since this question is closed, I am considering moving it (and the answer by Pawe?Dyda) to Community Wiki. Can someone please help me with this?"	Community			
"To peller: I am certainly not, so if you can point me to docs that contradicts my theory, that would be great. Thanks."				
"dojotoolkit.org/documentation/tutorials/1.6/i18n,  All resource bundles for a particuilar locale used on a page can be combined into a single file, or a single HTTP hit to retrieve them, similar to how the tool concatenates Javascript and CSS.  From that point, you're just accessing properties on an object in the browser.    The build tools were replaced with AMD-aware build tools in v1.7+ which will achieve similar results."	particuilar

how does the server identify the response type if it is /*/*? Any default to be specified? any configurations to be done?				
"To Seshadri this depends on the JAX-RS implementation of the server. You can't assume that all servers return the same content type on receipt of the ,Accept: */*, header, e.g. the Jersey framework could return a totally different content type than the RESTEasy framework. I'm not aware of a way to configure this behavior."	server			
There's no standard structure.	structure			
"There is no standard or convention for where to place your Spring components.  What you've defined seems to make sense, you'll probably find yourself adding a few more as you code along (exception, handler, etc). One recommendation I'd make is to drop the 's' off the package names, they're implied plural."	's'

"Within your ,public void startElement, method you have ,System.out.print(attributes.getValue(""r"") + "" - ""); , commented out. If you would look what it is printing, you would see cell references like ,A1,, ,B1,, ,C1,, ... in row 1 and so on in other rows. So if only column ,C, is needed, check whether ,attributes.getValue(""r""), starts with ""C"" and only if so, then take the values. To be clear: ,Excel,stores the table row by row. So getting a column without looping over all rows is not possible."

"What is ,invalid incoming API requests,?"	What			
"Please clarify phrase: ""The services I use wrapps spring configs"", Anyway you use ,DispatcherServlet,, otherwise ,RequestMapping, annotations will not work. There are few ways to define ,DispatcherServlet, one of ways is ,web.xml, and starting from Servlet 3.0, ,DispatcherServlet, can be configured programmatically by implementing or extending classes: ,WebAppInitializer,, ,AbstractDispatcherServletInitializer,, ,AbstractAnnotationConfigDispatcherServletInitializer,. Please check in witch way ,DispatcherServlet, is configured in your project."	DispatcherServlet			
"Your implemented ,ExceptionHandler, (as you mentioned above) doesn't work, because ,DispatcherServlet, doesn't throw exception, there is only one way to process unmapped urls, you should find place where is ,DispatcherServlet, defined and add attribute for throwing exceptions"				
"you're right, it's done"	done

Save the values by using putString method.	putStringmethod			
"Option #1 is a reasonable option. Should I attempt to execute all the 4 operations non transactionally ? Meaning: if I encounter a problem inserting to table Foo, I remember the error and continue on to all the other tasks. Or should I short circuit and abort ? Note that except for the queue operation, all tasks are idempotent because the DB tables and LDAP server will not accept duplicate entries."				
"This depends on your application. If you need all the task to be done under one transaction then you need to rollback all changed to subsystems if any error occurs. In this scenario just make to rollback and throw Exception with the problem. On the other hand, if it's OK just to update the DB and LDAP and indicate the client that the JMS call failed then do not run transactions just remember each error and notify the user via Exception."	Exception			
I clarified my question above. I do log the exceptions.	exceptions

And again, Java has JavaFX. Just switch or don't :)"	don't

"How could it be more secure to distribute all the data to every client?  A secure API that provides only the required data on demand seems much better.  There is no (,working,) technology to give a client data then tell him he can't use it.  No amount of keys changes this fundamental fact.  As far as concurrency, you might start with ,this question,."	it			
"The data ,can, be extracted from a DLL.  If it hasn't already been reverse-engineered, that just means the developers are lucky.  I still think the best you can do is a network API."	DLL			
"I do not claim this is the best solutions ever - it's obvious that the DB should be outside the system for reasonable security level. But to fulfil the requirements that may be OK.  Pure JDBC would be faster than, for instance, ORM solution (for example, Hibernate) in most cases. We're not talking about C here."	C

"Those aren't jobs, those are processes running in the background."	background			
"That seems to only be for the currently running process. From his/her question, it seems they want to know about a process with an arbitrary PID."				
"As far as I know, there is no built-in API for querying process by PID. But since you can invoke shell task like 'ps' and get the output, it should not be that hard to archive it in Java."				
"My concern is only because Java tries to be cross platform, they would make something like this intentionally hard, because process management is very dependent on the underlying platform."	Java

"Good answer. However for the sack of precision, you need to add ,#, at the beginning of your MEL expression. It is used to ask Mule to evaluate the given expression, and not use it as a string."	#			
There are no hard and fast rules - just document what the API needs/expects.				
If you tell the user not to give you a null pointer then it's not your responsibility but theirs.				
quoting Scott Meyers : Make your interfaces(API) easy to use correctly and hard to use incorrectly.				
There are numerous (and conflicting) guidelines on API design. Search and read and make up your own opinion.	API

"Microsoft provides APIs for C# and Javascript. Perhaps you could try same calls via Javascript and see what happens. Two things that stand out: 1) User agent differences (shouldn't matter, but who knows) and 2) Postman-Token: some-token. ,PowerBI.Api, simply wraps Http calls, you should be able to debug and capture details and then try to build the same request in Postman. If nothing helps, you can route via Fidler, to inspect differences."	Fidler

"1. Since i was getting 400 from my application i used fiddler to inspect the differences and construct the api call on Postman where i got the same result . The header information posted in the question is a PowerBI SDK call and other is a Postman constructed call respectively ,both are sniffed results out of fiddler .Also , User agent is nothing but which application is making the request  first is Application using powerBI SDK and second is Postman."	fiddler

"I work a lot with external APIs, and I usually avoid hitting the API servers directly upon user interaction (unless it is not a get - i.e. post, delete, update, etc). I usually have a bunch of jobs running on the background at different intervals, and store the data somewhere (DB, file, etc) and then make it available thru my own APIs. When you have 500 users logged in at the same time hitting the marketcap servers all the same time, you will quickly realize that it makes more sense to get the data once, store it, and access it as often as you need virtually immediately from your own servers."				
"To HanletEsca帽o Yes I would love to do that can you please provide some code? also, can you tell me how the data will be update in the db? like...it will call the api every x time? or something else. Also, i would like to get 3,000+ coins....so your solution can save me"				
"To Maduro I can't provide code, but the concept is quite simple. For every job that I have I save the response in my DB exactly the same way I get it (albeit I usually serialize/deserialize from/to JSON into objects and then move them to my DB). Then instead of calling the API every time a user wants this data, I get the data directly from my DB. The frequency at which you update your data is up to you and your needs. I have jobs that need to run anywhere from every 5 seconds, to once per day to once per month, it really depends."	API

OutputStreamWriter

"Why do you not want to code this in the controller (or service)? When it is done in a controller- (or service-) method, it is obvious (as in: has a lower cognitive complexity), easy to find and testable."	controller-

well usually you get this kind of access from your broker. They probably deal directly with the exchanges.	exchanges

"Concerning bonds, the market data are transfered via the FIX protocol directly from the brokers (as said Mario). Concerning equities, the market data providers gets the realtime data directly from the exchanges (via some specific API).  To acquire and use those kind of data, you need to find a market data provider (bloomberg, reuters, etc), buy them a licence, and use their APIs in your system.  i'm afraid this is some serious and expensive business"				
See To OMG's answer above.  They pay money.

"It doesn't ""thrown an error"". Rather it's a compilation error because a particular interface hasn't been implemented - make sure to ,read, and ,post, the actual error indicators (this is why I downvoted). If you make your ,own, events/event handlers, then you can specify whatever parameters are required (possibly none); but if you use ,existing, events, then you have to play by their defined rules."	existing

what? no getters? its a recommendation to MAKE object fields accessible ONLY through known places like getters!	getters

Those terms mean something completely different. You might want to clarify.	Those			
"Why not have both, since one is trivially derived from the other? (Mostly devil's advocate here, I don't know if the additional surface area is worth it.)"	other			
"if it was me I would have a map<String,Order> where String is the orderId, then get the order/orderId(depending on what you want to show) by using orderID."	orderID			
"To brso05 That depends fully on the implementation (maybe all the method does is: select * from products where orderid=order.getOrderId(). Talking API design, i would say go for the orderId, much more loosely coupled, and in many cases its easier to obtain just an orderid, then a whole order object. (for example, you would include an order id in a REST call, not the whole order object)"				
"On the other hand, your library doesnt have to know the Order class, that saves a dependency there (loosely coupled). You always have these kind of tradeoffs. In this case i would go for less dependencies, and an easier to call API by using just the value you need."	API			
"You've considered one case where they have a ,Map<Order, Product>,. What about other cases? What if they have ,Map<String, Product>,?"

"If you do a ""maven install"" or ""maven package"" on the command line, maven will download the jar files for you to your local repository and put them on the classpath while you compile. Modern versions of Eclipse also support maven builds, you only need to check whether your maven settings in the preferences are correct, and in some cases you may need to do a ""Update Maven Project"" after you change the pom.xml"	install

"""Making a copy of the argument collection in an array is safer."" perhaps I misread it?  (either that or, it is on the java.util.concurrent package)"	I			
"[I did edit the post.] Call c.toArray() should be as safe as the collection guarantees (for instance synchronised collections should do it synchronised). In the questioners first example, even synchronised collections could give inconsistent results."	c.toArray()			
"This leaves the set in an undeclared state if the added collection contains a null. Some elements are added, other not yet, and you abort with a collection. Paul Tomblin's solution was cleaner in that regard."				
"The collection is put into tmpSet so that if the original collection is modified it will not get a concurrent modification exception. This tmpSet is then checked for nulls, if there is one the method throws the exception. Otherwise the set with no nulls is added."	exception			
JWS (or a JWS configured applet in a Plug-In 2 JRE) will simplify this task in that JWS can install the natives.	applet

"Create the new interface. Deprecate the old one, but allow people to keep using it (for the sake of backwards compatibility). This might require a little modification in some places. In a couple of versions, remove the old interface."				
"In theory, the deprecated libraries you are using should be supported indefinitely.  However, the Google Play Store may at some point not support your API level, which means you might not be able to keep updating your app."	Google			
"Deprecation means it's no longer supported. If it stops working at some point, it won't be fixed. It might even be removed altogether eventually."	Deprecation

"And if you set ""Treat warnings as errors"" then it wont compile at all."	Treat			
Good note on using if/else condition for checking API level but backward compatible solutions already do this check so using newest methods and classes garauntees correct behavior on older devices as well. If the class is only for newer API then using if/else condition for checking API level may help.	if/else			
"If an API changes, the precedent is to deprecate the old version, but keep it for legacy code.  Then add the new version in parallel (maybe adding something like Java's ,To since, annotation to indicate which version of your library first introduced the API).  It's up to you to determine how long to keep the deprecated version.  I'm sorry that I'm not aware of a way to flag an API that may change in the ,future,, only of mechanisms used to let people know that an API available i the past has changed."				
"This is to be used when a feature is introduced into the API, but is not in a stable state. It may be updated in the next few releases before it is finalized. This will allow the community to speak into the finally look of the API."	This			
"github.com/google/guava/blob/master/README.md, might be relevant."	github.com/google/guava/blob/master/README.md			
"If you anticipate a lot of changes, call your project an alpha version until the API has stabilized."

I took a quick look. With JOOQ what happens to the autogenerated Java classes when the database schema changes?	autogenerated			
"You will have to re-generate those classes. If the change is incompatible (renaming of tables, columns, changing types of columns, etc), you will have compile-time errors. Ideally, the jOOQ source code generator is run at compile/build time."	tables			
Do you need to recompile if you only add fields?	fields			
"Adding fields is what I'd consider a ,compatible change,. Hence, you don't need to re-generate anything. Those fields will just not be selected."	compatible			
"Are you running a 32 bit or 64 bit JVM ? (32 bit application cannot address more than 2Gb ram on windows and some of those 2Gb is needed by the runtime, libraries, etc.)"				
"32-bit Java 6 throws this, 64-bit Java 7 does not."	this			
"On 32-bit windows, the limit is closer to 1.3 GB of memory. (You will find a similar limit if you run excel on a large spreadsheet) If you need to access more memory in a single application, you need a 64-bit OS. 32-bit Java on 64-bit OSes can access up to 3 GB, but you are likely to be better off using the 64-bit JVM in that case."	64-bit			
Which version of Windows is this on? You're going to struggle if this is still a 32-bit MSFT OS.	Windows			
I'm running a 32bit jvm. Have you then a suggestion about the way to use this api which needs at least 2GB ?	32bit			
"You simply cannot use more than this limit. If you have 64bits OS, then use 64 bits JVM."

those are the maximum possible values so the actual value may be less so you have to reduce it until it works				
"again, it's limited by how much free memory you actually have. Run your task manager (on windows) or top (on linux/osx) and look to see how much memory is free. Your Xmx value must be less than that."	windows)

"You're thinking of com.sun packages - those ,aren't, guaranteed to be stable.  The javax package is as stable as java - it's differentiated that way to let you know it's a ""newer"" library that came out with Java 2 (i.e. Java 1.2 as opposed to Java 1 or 1.1) - however that was the only time they've done that - lots of stuff was added in Java 1.5, but they didn't add a javaxx namespace."	com.sun			
Even prototype-based languages usually don't have multiple copies of the same method floating around. Objects normally share the methods of their parents.				
To Chuck: Presumably it would depend on whether the methods had been inherited or individually assigned though. That sort of consideration is precisely why I said you'd have to talk about specific situations :)

Notice that you don't have to thinks like this any more. Take a look at libraries like HtmlUnit and the usage of XPath queries to avoid painful iterations like the ones we are doing here.	XPath			
"So you want developers generate some HTML pages that contain reports? You might just use plain JSP along with HTML code completion and syntax highlighing within Eclipse (I'd say other major IDEs support that as well) - which also tells you whether you are missing a closing tag etc. To me it seems that with ECS you'd still have to have some knowledge of HTML and CSS, otherwise you'd not know what elements/styles to employ."	JSP			
"Yes, velocity and freemarker are dwefinitely a better choice, but unfortunately I'm not aware of any editor that supports completion/highlighting for html as well as velocity/freemarker. However, speaking of Eclipse, you might be able to use them and open the files in an HTML/JSP editor - which does provide HTML code completion etc. but lacks velocity/freemarker support - and first create the HTML parts. Then you could switch the editor to fill in velocity/freemarker specific parts."	freemarker			
"Intellij has a good support for at least freemarker. I'm just not very familiar with it yet and I'm still looking for the solution I want to adopt. I like template engine for very simple task, but once there is a lot of logic, I don't feel them very readable and maintanable."	Intellij			
"why should I ""Don't bother with object models for generating HTML."" ? GWT and other components based client API are successfully bothering with it :-)"	GWT			
"GWT, JSF, and the like synchronise state between the browser and the server, so they needs some kind of mapping between the DOM and the component model.  You are only generating reports in one direction (if I understood correctly).  I think it's an extra effort to build a tree just for that, and it's not worth it.  Templates are easier."	JSF			
"Very true. The thing I'm not comfortable with using template (and JSP) is that it can become quite a mess when there is too much logic in it. Then I can introduce a 'presentation model' to avoid complex templates, but this is extra effort too. The other thing I don't like is the maintenance problem arising when the object model change."

"You can implement this with ,Filter, and custom counters/monitors."	Filter			
"To SotiriosDelimanolis I won't go easy on this. While the ,Filter, will get before the servlet in the process chain, the counters won't be easy to maintain, remember that both filters and servlets are used in a multi thread environment. More info: ,How do servlets work? Instantiation, session variables and multithreading,."	servlets			
"To LuiggiMendoza Yeah. In no way is this easy. For OP, this type of data is useful in ,OAM,. You can either maintain (with all the problems of synchronizing) the counters in memory (bad) or do it in database and let it handle it."				
"There are two problems with the provided link: 1) It doesn't provide a counter per servlet instance (or URL) that supports multi thread. 2) To measure real time performance you must use ,System.nanoTime, instead of ,System.currentTimeMillis, since the former is more accurate."	System.nanoTime

"The problem with this requirement is that implementations tend to be ""provided"" in the context of a Maven build environment. Most APIs I know that split between an API and an implementation solve this requirement at runtime, so they manually check if an implementation is on the classpath and then log an error if there is none."	API

Why don't each user set use different classes? Then you can encapsulate the semantics better? In other words why only one API? Why not provide 3 APIs?				
"Create three interfaces and have a function that returns the appropriate ""level"" of interface?  This does have precedence in, say, COM; an object can present any number of interfaces, and you query for the interface you want."				
"Why don't you check the ,""level"", of the user in a single method and return appropriate result?"				
yeah. let all user access all the methods and throw an error if they are not authorized	yeah			
"To noti: Hardly.  You have one class masquerading as three.  Any time one of the three fake classes changes, that means changing the one real class.  What happens if those changes start interfering with each other?  Better to have an underlying type present one clear set of universal operations, IMO, and then split the level-specific functionality off into decorators (that can then be changed without changing the main class and potentially breaking the other decorators)."				
"Very important question. Who is using this API? Are they literally writing code to use this api? Unless you specifically say ""This code handles different user levels"" tell the person who uses your api that THEY need to handle user access levels."				
"Is there a reason you aren't using a tool like Jackson, which can serialize to both formats?"	Jackson			
"Ah, I see. Read too fast. The question is when to do validation, before or after unmarshalling. I guess I don't see the downside to #2. How is robustness/reliability affected by validating the DTO instead of the JSON/XML? You're creating one cheap object and then either throwing it out right away or using it for the rest of the request. I think you run a significant risk of the schema getting out of synch. And I don't think there are any other solutions - you have to validate, and it can be before or after unmarshaling."				
I guess there is always a risk about creating objects containing non-validated user provided input. For example it might make the app more vulnerable to DoS attacks. to E.g. someone would start creating requests containing huge values that would either cause overflow or memory leak.	input			
"Well, sure, but unless you're deserializing into a stream and validating as it streams out, you're still putting those huge values into memory."	memory			
did you find anything for this To Paul	Paul

"Nope, that's not a BOM (which is only 2-3 bytes), that's garbage.  There's something wrong with your download operation."

"#### You can create a wrapper entity and create a list like ,List<Wrapper>, .</br> ,data class Wrapper(     val records : YourEntity,     val report : YourEntity,     val itemType :Int ,</br>  1. put all records entity and report info into list, such as ,report - records -records -records -report -records -records ,, and you need to set ,itemType, in wrapper entity. </br>  2. use wrapper to override the itemType method.</br>  3. display view according to wrapper entity's ,itemType,,if ,itemType, is report ,you just need to get the report data in wrapper entity."	wrapper

What specific Portal API are you using?				
"I'm using the portal API that containts packages named like com.ibm.portal.*. The jars are wp.base.jar, wp.model.api.jar, etc."				
"the model api is pretty large, but if you are running the code from within the scope of a portlet it should already be scoped, like if you are using the model api to go over the content model it is already scoped to the current VP.  Now if you are trying to run it in a servlet that is outside the scope of the VP, like trying to create links or or something like that, you have to use objectids and the like to look for pages and what not.  And only parts of the model are VP scoped, like the portlet model is across vps.  we need some more details on what you want to do"

"I don't know if I've understood correctly, if not please provide some further explanation of your question. I would return a 0 for 0 events vs 404 error in that case. 404 would be more for they have the wrong url vs a 0 return value.	I			
"10.4.5 404 Not Found  The server has not found anything matching the Request-URI. No indication is given of whether the condition is temporary or permanent. The 410 (Gone) status code SHOULD be used if the server knows, through some internally configurable mechanism, that an old resource is permanently unavailable and has no forwarding address. This status code is commonly used when the server does not wish to reveal exactly why the request has been refused, or when no other response is applicable."				
This is from w3.org. I would think that since the resource is not there the api should return 404				
If you are doing PURE REST implementation then you should return 404. Be it wrong uri or resource (event) doesn't exist. In any case it should be 404.	PURE			
The resource is there. It's an empty bag of events.	there			
Doesn't it mean potential unnecessary code re-writes. Everytime the producer change version you need to change your package name and all import statements in all classes using that classes.				
"I wouldn't name packages after a target API version. Your project should declare a dependency to a given API version, and you would just version your project with its own versionning number, each time you want to target a different API version (i.e when you change the dependency version).Example : myproject version 1.1.8 uses theapi version 2.3.0 , myProject version 1.2.0 uses theapi version 2.4.6 ."	myProject			
"To Berger, that would work if the API is available as a dependency (i.e. maven) which can be checked. But assume, that is not the case (i.e. http, wsdl, corba/idl). It becomes especially tricky, if you're consuming parts of two API versions in the same application (this is not a hypothetical example, I've seen this in real life)"	corba/idl)			
"I know this is an old thread, but I'm here because I'm trying to figure out how to deal with supporting side-by-side versions of an API.  With my use-case, the vendor's API changes approximately quarterly.  Sometimes the changes are breaking changes.  My app needs to support integration to whichever version a client has in their environment, so I think I need to treat the version as a configuration option and provide some kind of switch to varying underlying logic.  Most of the client code can actually be generated, so the code overhead is not a major factor."	vendor's			
Work like a charm	Work

"I think the main problem is your use of ,Pointer(1024), for the compressed value.  Use ,Memory(1024), to allocate native memory.   Also ,BOOL, in Windows maps to ,int,. Any nonzero value is ,true,."	Pointer(1024)

"You say you generate the documentation. Is this done using the swagger annotations in your code, if so is the code in production annotated already? If yes then it is not strange that swagger generates the documentation on production based on the annotation in the code."	annotations			
No production version doesn't use swagger. My job is to create some documentation for the clients before we release the next version which will have full documentation.	swagger			
Springfox swagger scans annotation of Spring MVC to generate documentation (the swagger.json file). So if swagger springfox is configured in your production code base (not just the dependency) then the documentation will be generated automatically.	swagger

To teppic my goal is to use the given path to get the portion of the xml from the skeleton and then put the value in.				
"You can extract ,<model1></model1>, quite easily with XPath like ,data/model1[element1[id='1' and name='John']',. Thres an XPath API in Java (see ,this question,)."	data/model1[element1[id='1'			
"If you want it with ,<data><model1></model1></data>,, it's a bit more complex. You can put it together using DOM or apply an XSLT. There are really many many ways to achieve what you want. I'd suggest you checking the XPath approach first of all."	DOM			
"That's pretty cool. However, if the xml variable is like <xml ...>\n<data>\n<model1>\n<element>\n<id />\n<name />\n<address /></element>\n</model1>\n</data>  then would xpath still returns the subtree?"				
"In this case, the root node is no longer ,<data>, by ,<xml>,. So the XPath should be changed. You should use either ,""/xml/data/model1/element1"", to describe the complet path, or ,//data/model1/element1"", (two slashes) to select all the descending nodes. To asun"	/xml/data/model1/element1			
"Never use ,standaloneSetup,; it fails to set up the actual context in which a controller will be operating (JSON formatting for items such as dates is the notorious failure case). Use ,To SpringBootTest, and autowire your MockMvc. (As a side note, you're not using standard REST conventions, and I strongly recommend you do so. Name ,the resource,, which is ,member,, and ""view"" is already communicated by GET, so ,GET /members/{id}, (if you know the ID) or ,GET /members?username=,, which conventionally returns an array always because it's a search result.)"	standaloneSetup

"I copied it from the question. It takes the last digit and comares it to the result of calling the same function to the rest of the number. After that, it returns the bigger value. It's not optimal solution though. EDIT: I optimised the function a little ;)"				
"To DorianGray The last line is corrent, because untill n<10 you call all the time the same method . if n%10>f(n/10) so - return whats bigger.. this way, the number is losing a digit everytime and at the end when it has only 1 digit, the tail is going back up and than it compared between n%10 and the given number of(n/10) back up"

"Right. I have this dependency ,<artifactId>spring-boot-starter-data-rest</artifactId>,. I found the issue. It was not entering my custom controller method indeed. I just posted the answer with the details. Thank you."	issue			
I think you got confused with SpringDataRest. It's automatically exposing rest controllers for all your entities (including CRUD operations). as you requested the service with /person you actually called the automatically generated controller and not your method. The request with /Person called your method properly. You should remove this dependency if you don't want auto-generated controllers for your entities.	SpringDataRest			
the dependency you mention is spring-boot-starter-data-rest? I can't find SpringDataRest anywhere in the project.	SpringDataRest			
Yes exactly! you might have enabled this dependency at your repository interfaces with To RepositoryRestResource. When you remove the dependency you should also remove these annotations to not get a compile error	To

"To JoachimSauer ,GregorianCalendar, was a normal date until Java 8. That鈥檚 six years ago by now. It was always poorly designed, and fortunately it is now long outdated. I wouldn鈥檛 want to consider poorly designed and long outdated to be normal for Java. A normal date today would be ,LocalDate, from ,java.time, the modern Java date and time API,."

"To Fred I'm saying because they are different, you are getting that error. Obviously, your ,source,, which is a Class object for ,Start,, doesn't have an ,add(), method, so you can't invoke ,Start.add(),, however, since the class ,Component, has an ,add(), method, the source should be a ,Component.Class,."	Component			
"To Fred then are you sure when you call ,source.getMethod(name, overs).invoke(this, param);, that you are replacing ,this, with an instance of ,Start,? ,source, is an Object of type ,Class,, and ,this, needs to be an instance of that type."	source.getMethod(name

"Okay, that makes a bit more sense. I still think that ""SDK"" should die as a root namespace."	SDK			
"fair enough, updated to FrameworkSDK.  Is this still bad?  The original thinking was that people would just import FrameworkSDK for their code, but that's when I relized I may have the concept of sub namespaces all jumbled."	FrameworkSDK			
See my answer for what I'd suggest...	suggest			
"wouldn't that attact people to instead use using statements like  using SDK.CompanyNameLibrary?  And I imagine most if not all of the classes in that namespace should be internal or private, so as to limit confusion when importing the dll...  any and all help appreciated"	SDK.CompanyNameLibrary			
"Not really. If you're working with any kind of large-scale system, eventually you're going to have a multitude of namespaces to work with. I feel that the best way to deal with this is to choose your namespaces intelligently in such a way that they accurately reflect what they contain. SDK.CompanyNameLibrary.CompanyInternalAPI tells the implementer that they are getting the company's internal API for whatever library they are using. Although I would probably drop the SDK as it isn't really necessary."	SDK			
"So put everything into one namespace, and simply make things internal / public?  That means I'm going to have ~hundred classes all in one folder in the project, only maybe 25-30 of which are going to be marked public.  Is that really a good practice?  Seems hard to organize..."				
"Right, I figured one namespace for the public facing materials, and one for the implementation, which is the bulk of the work.  Also, that should have said ~100, not several hundred, apologies"				
"Even 100 suggests you should be able to break it down more sensibly. If these are meant to be replacements or enhancements to the normal BCL, I'd take the cue from that - so for example, a stream helper class could be in ,CompanyName.BclPlusPlus.IO, to match ,System.IO,."

"It's because your class' Context isn't valid yet, the first access you have to any Context method (in this case ,getApplicationContext(),) is in ,onCreate(),. This is true whether you're working with Applications or Activities."	Applications

"Ah, you're right. Looks like they didn't include methods for everything (which is strange). Looking at the code, you should be using the setStringCustomParameter() method: ,code.google.com/p/gdata-java-client/source/browse/trunk/java ,  I've updated the example."				
"Thanks! I thought about the first solution but it looked just wrong... The second one is tricky though, can you explain to me what does this annotation means? And thanks again for the fast response."				
"Arguments to an API method, by default, appear in the body (and are expected to be Java Beans). Named arguments appear in the query string (as a key/value pair), so they need a name like ""d"" and should be scalar types instead of Beans."				
"So I understand that the string inside the annotation would be the name of the parameter the would be displayed on the client-side, and the ""Double d"" is the type and name just used for the method itself?"	annotation			
Correct. It's treated as a normal method argument aside from the annotation.

There is no other API as far as I know. The JNI is your best bet.	TheJNI

"So, then the method size() is an abstract method. Once you implement Collection interface you need to override the abstract method, don't you? But there are more such methods."	size()			
"But there are more such methods., You mean methods with implementations? It can't be right? Interface (in general) can't have methods with implementations.. By default all methods in interface are ,abstract"				
Once you implement that interface you inherit those methods. Once that is done you can perform operations on object which is inherently a Collection. That fact bothers me cause those methods are not annotated as abstract.

"really? then they are different APIs. what I want to design is: when new API feature is enabled, if user call foo(a,b,c) or foo(a,b,c, false), foo(a, b, c, false) is called, if user call foo(a,b,c, true), then foo(a,b,c, true) is called; when new API feature is disabled, if user call foo(a,b,c), internally foo(a, b, c, false) is called, if user call foo(a,b,c, true/false), they get API not supported."	foo(abc)

"This is a nice accurate answer(+1). To SumitGupta I would also do a test with a software renderer (Java3D maybe ? ) or converting the 3d coordinates to 2d and drawing in 2d ? "To SumitGupta: You'll need at least a X11 server and drivers for your GPU installed. Depending on your distribution regular users may or may not permitted to start the X server. How to fix it is described here: ,x.org/wiki/FAQMiscellaneous/#index2h2, ; once a regular user can start the X server you can use ,xinit <full path to your program binary> <options to your program> -- <options to the X server>, launch your program running within the X server. If you have several programs that require X you may want to start some kind of session environment (DJB's daemontools work for that)."	X			
"To SumitGupta: Remember that the X server offers another attack surface so if your internet service gets hacked, it may bounce off the X server to elevate its privileges. So you should be security conscious about that."	X			
What part do you need help with? Google shows many examples; Oracles Java tutorial includes a fine step by step.	Google			
"I did find a few good tutorials (mostly for Android Studio and Netbeans) but they are platform-specifics, which makes sense but is limiting me. I need to be compatible with as many platforms as possible. Like a POJO '^^"	Netbeans)			
"The Java part of a JNI Library is the same on every platform, but the native code part has to be compiled separately for every platform you support. If you look at how the ""loadLibrary()"" method works, you'll see that you only supply the root of the library name, and Java figures out what the file name should be on each individual platform."	JNI			
"JNA, abstracts the native bits so that you can focus on writing ,only, Java code.  On most platforms, the jar file JNA profiles (,jna.jar,) knows how to unpack and load native libraries from the jar file itself."				
Thank you ! I knew it would have been something like that. But where to find the tools and guides to accomplish this much ? I need a stand-alone library. "From my experience I used Eclipse, and the problem is that the entry point is in java, so the debuggers must switch (there's a java debugger and a native debugger), and in Eclipse this was working very badly (more like it wasn't working). Notepad++ doesn't come with debuggers, I said that I preferred using Notepad++ rather then using Eclipse with C++ (auto-complete didn't work well, notepad++ is more lightweight,etc). You won't end up pasting code. You will have a C++ entry point when you are debugging on desktop and a Java entry point when you're testing on the real thing."				
"I dislike Eclipse. I just tried Netbeans C++ debugger (that uses gdb of course) and it works fine. Autocompletion to. Anyway, where should I write this C++ wrapper (the entry point) ? How come the debugger will be attached to the code ? Thanks for the help !"

"Thanks To Jerrod Horton , you mean to say that every time url changes from v1/products to v2/products we have to change the client ??  and how should i do support both versioning v1 and v2 ? how google,youtube,facebook versioning api works?"				
"No problem.What I am saying is that if you use the url to version and you roll out a new version, your clients do NOT have to change (provided you are supporting your previous version).Because the url goes from /v1/products (which is being used and still supported) to /v2/products, that means that people using the /v1/products will be unaffected by the new version you introduce for /v2/products. Now this is only true, of course, if the code you write for your version 2 does not cause version 1 to break.  How do you manage multiple versions of an API is a much broader (and trickier) of a topic"	/v1/products			
"To  Jerrod Hortan my point is cleared now ,but one thing i want to know is when we introduce  new version it means that there well be separate class for it to support new version with new version signature ?? If yes it means that if you have 5 different versions than there will be 5 different classes  for it ?"				
"Yes.  In my experience it is best to not only have 5 different classes for 5 different versions but, sometimes, it is even good to have completely separate projects for them.  The risk you run of having them all in the same project is that you might accidentally change something on a previous version without meaning to because of something you needed to add for a current version.  However, I would say to keep them in different classes at the very least."	them			
"Thanks, I did so and it solved the problem some how but there was another error saying : ,Uncaught IllegalAccessException: Class com.teamdev.jxbrowser.chromium.JSContext can not access a member of class RezRem.Events with modifiers ""public"""",. For this error I declared ,Events, class in another file with ,public, modifier and now there is no problem."	RezRem.Events

"Which IDE are you using? In Eclipse the first classes that are shown as code suggestions are the ones in the same package or in the imported classes (including ,java.lang.*,). Other public classes do appear, but they are shown after those."				
"I'm using idea. Since these classes are not intended to use in other packages at all, I am trying to make them not accessible by other packages. "This may be overkill, but as the application grows it can be easier to manage the code base with multiple projects. For example, each functional layer of the app is in its own project. This can include the util classes in its own project, where the util.jar simply becomes a dependency by the other projects which need it.  This helps avoid util classes becoming junk drawers since a developer has to intentionally go to another project to add new util classes/methods.  Depending on the build tool, this will also force util classes to be generic to avoid circular dependencies."	util			
So can I assume the package structure I have used is common and there is nothing wrong with it?	it			
"Your post does not contain enough details to determine your project structure, besides the package names. It is good practice to seperate a project into pacakges. You mentioned something about API? Are you trying to create an API?"	API			
"Just remember that, if anyone want to use your utils classes, then they have to import that package otherwise it will not be visible for them. So it kinda takes care of itself as long as they do not import your util classes."	utils			
"I took a quick look. It seems like your util classes are ""real"" util classes, they do not seem to be related to the remaining code. Good luck with your project!"	util

So how to test if a number is at least 200 but no more that 299?

"con.setRequestProperty(""User-Agent"", ""Mozilla/5.0""); Adding this line solved the problem."	problem			
"If the foreign key could be empty (or some unknown key) you need to check and handle that. For an empty or null key just don't do any lookup, for an unknown key check the lookup returned something. In both cases you'd not have a user to link your entity to so you either have to save it without that (make the relation optional), use some fallback user (e.g. look up a default) or report an error to the caller."	lookup			
"As per your problem statement it looks like you need to make your relation optional and column as nullable so in case you receive null from caller, you can check if null then set null otherwise fetch value and set."	caller

I dont know if its normal in java make this type of function every time"

I'm guessing you need to URLEncode your password (and possibly your username). URLs are limited in what they allow; good passwords often contain characters that are not valid in URLs.	passwords			
"A small improvement if you're using Java 10 or higher. URLEncoder.encode has been overloaded to accept a Charset instead of a String encoding. That overloaded version doesn't throw any checked exceptions.: ,URLEncoder.encode(username, StandardCharsets.UTF_8),."	Charset			
"Is curiosity you mentioned Charset instead of a String encoding from Java 10 or  higher. I'm using Java 11. so I got that problem and I needed to add URLEncoder, which contains characters not valid in URLs."	Charset

"does the new api endpoint respond with a 307 , 308, 301, or 302 redirect?  any of those might, and the first 2 would, mean that the POST was re-submitted"				
"They both respond with 200 every time according to the tomcat logs. The browser makes only one API call and it gets 200. However, the back-end handles 2 identical ones. Only for that endpoint. I google-searched this problem and I found, like, 2 questions. One of them was never answered since 2017, and for the other people were asking the person if they have used To ResponseBody and produces and stuff. I have been using these things for years which is why those answers did not help. That's why I asked the question myself here. If this is not solved in a week, we will lose all of our clients"	back-end			
Is there any timeout and retry logic for the calling code? I suggest if it possible for you add the code which calls this endpoint and Spring security configurations to your question.				
"no. There is no timeout. In the network tab in the Chrome DevTools we see the OPTIONS call first and immediately after that the POST call. Then it says ""pending"" for 3-4 seconds (for the back-end to do its job) and then we see 200. One API call. No timeouts or repeated calls in the browser. Only in tomcat"

"I'm really not sure what you mean by ""want to kick the spring context out of the REST wrapper"", and I'm also unsure of how you're using contexts. A context doesn't have to map to a package or an API, but can be any grouping of beans that embody an application. If you don't want to use package-scanning, then you have no choice but to define beans individually using XML or ,To Configuration,, and specify references between beans in that configuration or by using To Autowired or equivalent."	Autowired			
"Well that mainly depends on your implementation, if you can use lazy loading (initializing the classes only when needed), then you can initialize A without B and then Initialize B (use a setter) only when needed and so on."

"To Salmanmahmood ,populateNewArray, calls ,NewsReader.getNews,.  You can inject a mock which returns a (for example) ,ByteArrayInputStream, containing known JSON."				
"how will I make sure that the mock object is being called when testing, instead of the real implemetation(which does a network call)?"				
"Use dependency injection.  You can either do it manually or use a IoC container (Spring / Guice).  The key concept here is that you inject the NewsReader into your class.  For example, define a constructor in your main class that takes a NewsReader instance."	constructor

It doesn't chain but List has the method addAll. Is there really a need for this chaining ?	addAll			
"To dystroy: I didn't say there's a ,need,. Obviously Java is Turing-complete without it... I'm looking for a convenience idiom."				
"The problem is that in order to have a coherent language/framework, you would have to do this with many many functions. That simply wasn't how the standard lib were designed. I don't say it's good as it is (java verbosity is painful) but having chaining ability just on one method only breaks the coherency and doesn't help."				
"To dystroy: But I'm not asking about the standard libraries necessarily. Guava doesn't have something like this, nor does Apache Commons.Collections. I ended up writing a small method myself but that doesn't sound like the Right Thing to do."

"Thanks! that's very helpful. I believe that once I access the url, the lines are already split, is there any way in Java that I could just read certain lines? This should eb a sample output of the api: ,ip-api.com/line"	Java			
"Using lines, you can access the individual lines. So ,lines[0], will get the first line and ,lines[1], will get the second line and so forth."	lines[1]			
"Thanks To Chase. I'm curious though, is this the only way Java allows this to happen, that is, you must read all lines and then choose which to actually use in your program?"	Java			
"Pretty much. Any any language you have to read the contents in before you can access it. You could skip over data until you run into a ,\n, character. But that wouldn't be any less complicated. Just ignore the lines you don't use. You can call ,lines[4], to jump directly to access line 5, without having to look at the other ones first, then later you can look at line 2 with ,lines[1],."	lines[4]

"Well this servlet is actually within a portlet, I'm using ,PortalDelegateServlet, to publish the servlet within the portal context. Maybe I'm missing something pretty obvious?"				
"No need to go cross-context here. Just write a standard, classic portlet, e.g. an action- or resource handler and move the code there. If you use the resource-serving phase, this comes closest to a servlet. From that portlet you have all the portal/portlet context readily available and don't need to care getting everything you need. ,UserLocalServiceUtil, is also available."				
"hey there Olaf, thanks a lot for your help. Quick question thou, and this is where my requirement starts getting a bit weird. The reason I went for a servlet is because it could be accessed from the outside trough a public URL. Now if I go for a ,serve resource,, is there a way to access this method trough a public URL? Just as you can with a servlet? Thanks man."	servlet			
"well, yes you can. The only thing is that - in the portal world - the URL is generated for you by the portal. It might look ugly. However, that shouldn't be anything to keep you from it: You can implement a redirect/url-rewrite in Apache, offering a pretty URL on Apache that is forwarded to an ugly portal URL. Or you can implement FriendlyURLs if you want to stay in the portal world. There are Liferay APIs for this. Apache mod_rewrite is probably the easiest/quickest way though - a bit hackish, but very quick"	redirect/url-rewrite			
Not sure if it works like that either; you could try using one of the java riot-api wrappers

"That's a Maven repository. You shouldn't download and import random jars; they don't include dependencies such as JAX-WS. Use proper dependency management, such as through m2eclipse."	Maven			
"Thx, but I am not sure how it works, you mean Eclipse market place? I tried find dependency at mvnrepository.com, but I didnt find it."	it			
"You need to learn to use a dependency-management tool, and Maven is the default for most of the standard tools (though Gradle is mostly interoperable). m2eclipse is an Eclipse plugin (available in the marketplace, I think) that lets Eclipse use Maven dependency management. In a Maven project, adding the Neo4J dependency will also include all the jars it needs, such as JAX-WS."	Maven

Never ever expose api keys publicly				
"It appears you have a typo that is obliterating your HTTP response line: ,response = response = ""Date: ?;,  Notice the presence of two ,=, assignment operators.  (And then you obliterate the response line and all of the headers when your program executes ,response = """"Hi Hope you are doing good"""";,.)  Also, there must be ,two, ,\r\n, sequences between the headers and the body."""				
"ohhhh no I didn't. In that case I should have just gotten back whatever I assigned the response string was right? ,response = ""some string""; response.concat(""some more"");, should just return ""some string""?"	right			
"To mcdowellalex That would return ""some string"", yes. This is because Strings are immutable in Java. But your postman probably did not ""receive"" the response because it was not formatted correctly or missing some info."

"To RequestMapping(value = ""/login"", method = RequestMethod.OPTIONS)     public ResponseEntity<?> login(To RequestBody String data) { 	System.out.print(""entra""); 	System.out.print(data); 	HttpHeaders headers = new HttpHeaders(); 	headers.add(""Access-Control-Allow-Origin"", ""*""); 	headers.add(""Access-Control-Allow-Methods"", ""GET, POST, DELETE, PUT""); 	headers.add(""Access-Control-Allow-Headers"", ""X-Requested-With,content-type""); 	headers.add(""Access-Control-Allow-Credentials"", ""true""); 	return new ResponseEntity<>(headers, HttpStatus.CREATED);     }"	To

"To PhagunBaya yes, there is a chance that I can be be time consuming. If this is going to be a problem, what would you suggest?"	I			
I would suggest to track the process in some in-memory cache. Along with this you will need to send back the response to this API with a track id and client will poll some API to get back status of the process. Or you can use socket.io to send back the final response to client using the socket connection.	socket.io

Short answer: don't push it to GitHub. Keep it as a local configuration file.				
"I'm curious right now about something - without api key, app downloaded from github won't work, is it normal practice? What about people from let's say a job interview, who would try the app, are they just gonna look upon the code, or want to test it ""live""?"				
"It would be up to the person who downloaded the source to use their own API key to make it work. Publicly posting your API key potentially means the whole internet can piggy-back off your account, which is the quick way to get your account suspended/banned. API keys should only be distributed as part of final APK releases, and even then it should be obfuscated where possible using proguard etc."	proguard			
"So I can just make something like To blazer338 suggested, and push it into git, right? Well, I thought, I'm gonna have to hide it somehow. Good to know that. Thank you for help."	To

"Are you using try-with-resources anywhere in your code? As far as I know, that's the only Java 7 feature that will cause problems on older APIs. "The main reason I want to unit test this is so that if anyone changes my code, i.e. the way I've implemented the library into our product, they won't be able to break it. I also want to avoid actually running the methods I'm testing, because they take a long time to communicate with GitHub, which in a big project with hundreds of tests is not ideal. We use Jenkins and Sonar and all tests are ran automatically, when we push to the main repo. I'm basically looking for a way to reduce the time it takes for my tests to run by avoiding to wait for a response from GitHub's server."	Sonar

"I was considering if moving the ,createInstance(), as part of the interface declaration a good design approach or not. I would only define the method and not the actual implementation"	createInstance()			
Adding a abstract method in the interface to create a new instance assumes that the interface knows the constraints implementations (such as the required fields)  and it is not a good idea either because it couples the interface to the implementation. Only the reverse should be true.				
Then when I say that the interface defines something that is immutable that is not correct either? Thereby doesn't really matter if I add a setter?				
"The thing is that this works for classes that are aware of the ,ConcreteClass,. But my interest is for all uses that are aware only the ,Generator, reference"				
No there is no API for any of them	API			
Check if what you get in the response is identical to what you sent?	Check			
"You're saying the canonical string and string to sign in the error message is absolutely byte-for-byte identical to what your code is generating on these intermediate steps?  If you are certain that is true, that leaves only two meaningful possibilities: a copy/paste error in your secret key, or a quirk in API Gateway.  For any given request, there's exactly 1 valid canonical request; for any given canonical request, there's exactly 1 valid string to sign, and for any given string to sign, there's exactly 1 valid signature.  It's all very deterministic."				
"Understood , thanks for that"

As for the caninical all is the same apart from the signiture that is different. So if for one service it works than we have all query params values and order ok so what is different with the other service or host?"	error

"Most likely, you forgot to include the ,params, attribute in your mapping. Note that the ,produces, is nearly always redundant (Spring will content-negotiate automatically), as is the ,ResponseEntity, if the only thing you're doing is setting an HTTP status (OK is the default, you can annotate a status on the method, or you can throw an exception with an error status)."	params

"Side issue, this will cause problems: ,if(DBChoice==""delete""){, Don't compare Strings using ,==, or ,!=,. Use the ,equals(...), or the ,equalsIgnoreCase(...), method instead. Understand that ,==, checks if the two ,object references, are the same which is not what you're interested in. The methods on the other hand check if the two Strings have the same characters in the same order, and that's what matters here."

"To Haresh: They are part of Java 7. Like as those ,try-with-resources, statements. Perhaps you're still on long EOL'ed Java 6 or even older? Just upgrade to at least Java 7 (we're currently already on Java 8), or replace Java 7 code by older Java equivalents. E.g. an old fashioned ,for, loop writing a buffer from input to ouput."	Java			
setDoOutPut true was my issue which set my GET to a POST. Thanks	POST			
"If you are trying to write data to the outputstream you ,must, still set ,setDoOutput(), to ,true, otherwise an exception is thrown (even if you ,setRequestMethod(""POST""),). To be clear: setting ,URLConnection#setDoOutput(true), to ,true, implicitly sets the request method to POST, but setting ,httpURLConnection.setRequestMethod(""POST""), to POST does ,not, implicitly set ,setDoOutput(), to ,true,."				
"8 years later, ,setRequestMethod(""POST""), ,does, set ,doOutput, to ,true,."				
"I was just thinking the same. But it might also be nice to have a barebones/simple Java library that only uses URLConnection code as presented here that encapsulates the code to simpler methods to do an HTTP GET, POST, etc. The library can then be compiled & packaged as JAR and imported/used in Java code or the source class file can be included in Java project if external JARs are not desired. This could be done with other libraries like Apache, etc. but is more of a pain compared to a simple 1 file class library using URLConnection."	same			
"Further update: the module is out of incubation status.  It鈥檚 now ,java.net.http,, not jdk.incubator.httpclient."

"Thanks. Making a REST call will get a more ""general"" output in JSON format. But not a JSON representation of the rows. I'd expect something like the following (same JSON in bigquery web ui, or in ,bq, command):  The ,bq query --format json --project_id my-test-project ""select * from sandbox.employees"", would get the following result  ,[{""employee"":""peter"",""age"":""40""},{""employee"":""john"",""age"":""30""},{""employee"":""jack"",""age"":""50""},{""employee"":""michael"",""age"":""20""},{""employee"":""eric"",""age"":""60""}]"				
You would need to perform that transformation yourself.	yourself			
"Thanks. If I understood correctly, I can use both low-level REST API, or high-level BigQuery client libraries. But whichever solution I choose, I have to transform the query response manually to get the same JSON format as in web ui / export such as: ,[{""employee"":""peter"",""age"":""40""}, ...],. For now, there is no native support for such transformation, apart from using ,TO_JSON_STRING, function. The ,bq query --format json ..., tool uses REST API behind the scene but its' python implementation transforms ""manually"" the REST response to the json output we see  ,[{""employee"":""peter"",""age"":""40""}]"	TO_JSON_STRING

"401 response means that the request was successfully executed and the server returned that status code. This is not a problem with Retrofit, but in whatever authentication information you are including in the request that the server expects. If it works in Postman, then somehow you are misconfiguring Retrofit or not sending the same data."	Retrofit

"Your question is only about the Controller? What's it do? ... Also, this is opinion based, so your question is at risk of being closed"	Controller			
That would be a horrible way to handle versioning. You should have a single code base and version the output accordingly. Have a look at the GSON for versioning.	That			
"This is going to be opinion-based, but I've preferred grouping by version first (among other things, because those tend to be splittable into separate jars or microservices)."				
"Please, take a look at how HTML is versioned. That is how REST APIs should handle versioning as well as the media-type is the important thing actually. Any proprietary API that does only exchange generic JSON messages bear the danger of tight coupling in it which is what REST actually tries to fix"

Decision. I do make preparing a mailbox infrastructure: I created two folders in the test box.	mailbox			
Folder 1 - Contains the copied message. This message will be the benchmark for verification. In this message will replace the denami part of the content. This allows you to set up a benchmark message to check for a new incoming message.				
Folder 2 - Letters for verification will be sent to this folder. I configured filters for this folder.				
Software implementation: 1. Connect to the mail server. 2. Received a reference message from Folder 1.	Folder

"first of all ""org.json"" library was originally developed as a proof of concept for implementation of JSON in Java. But how do I make sure only my app can use my web service?				
To Sanguine you cannot. You need to build everything with that in mind. This is why you cannot let the front end app send SQL commands because you cannot know that only your app is sending them. Please tell us what you are trying to achieve				
Imagine logging in with a user account. I only want certain users to be able to access certain bits of data from the DB. Would I then have to send up their login details to authenticate every time they want to retrieve something?				
"To Sanguine yes exactly. For starters you could do that, remember the password and username on the app side and then send these again with every request (in future you should look at better techniques than storing the password). Remember: every request on your server must be treated as if it might be from a malicious person"	password)

"This has been covered quite a bit here. See ,Does it make security sense to hash password on client end,, ,stackoverflow.com/questions/3715920,, and ,stackoverflow.com/questions/6553363,. From the security standpoint, a client is a client, regardless of whether its a browser or an app. Apps are marginally harder to crack than client code, but still totally insecure."				
"Yes you should hash on both client and server side. There is no reason not to hash at least with a constant salt on client side especially for a mobile app as in your case. See ,medium.com/To harwoeck "	medium.com/To

"Have a look ,here,?"				
"Yes, To jeroen-heier, that was exactly the problem, that there are no language-specific demos, only a CURL example. I figured out what the problem was: a colon needs to be added to the end of the token before encoding it to base64, and then the encoded string can be sent as a request header:  encodedToken = Base64.encode((token + "":"").getBytes()); Authorization(""Basic "" + encodedToken)  This is an aproximation to code, I don't remember the exact syntax now Thank you."				
"Yes, that was the solution. Thanks a lot!"	lot

Tried to add a short explanation what was happening wrong in your code.	code			
"To Box a map is a key-value pair. Consider the key a unique identifier for the value you are interested in getting. If you were dealing with a database table, they primary key of the table will be the key and then every other column will be the value. 99.99999% of the time, the key will be a simple data type like a ,String,. Rarely (I don't recall ever seen a case) you will use something like a list as a key."	String			
"Can I suggest that if you are going to completely change the meaning of a question, that you ask a new question?"	question			
"You would probably have some sort of class in front of the ,ZipOutputStream, which would either synchronise or, for potentially better performance, queue file entries on to a dedicated (per-zip) thread."	You			
"To Tom: that's what I said didn't I?  (I can see that a dedicated thread might give better throughput ... if the application is I/O bound, but you'd get the same effect by increasing the number of worker threads creating the stuff to be written.)"				
"To Stephen: No. You said one synchronized method call. Tom pointed out it is possible to queue file entries. OP doesn't ask for high-performance, just for concurrency-compatibility."				
"That solution has terrible performance impact. As I understand it, Romam wants to write chunks of characters in one stream, not multiple entries..."				
To Viliam: it is not possible to know what the OP really wants.  I suppose it is possible that he/she sants to write multiple chunks into a single ZIP file entry.  But then the answer is the same as for any output stream or writer ... and why would he/she bother with a ZIP stream rather than a plain stream or a stream with better compression.				
To Viliam: your first solution won't work.  You need to do the putNextEntry/write(s)/closeEntry in a single synchronized call.	putNextEntry/write(s)/closeEntry			
To Stephen C: No. Romam needs to write chunks of characters asynchronously. Not multiple files. Putting putNextEntry/write(s)/closeEntry into a single sync block would ruin that completely.	putNextEntry/write(s)/closeEntry			
To Viliam: OK ... so that is a plausible interpretation of the question.  But I really don't think that is what he/she means.  Why would he/she be using a ZIP stream rather than (say) a plain stream or a stream with a better compression algorithm?	question			
"To Stephen C: That's because the question has been changed! :) The first version asks explicitly to use ZipOutputStream, this one (edited after the answer I post) is only about OutputStream. That's live I guess..."	ZipOutputStream			
I think it has more to do with class loaders				
Are you sure that the listener you provide as parameter has the type Listener that you declared and not another Listener implementation existing in the class path (check your imports)?	imports)			
"To Eyal, no. It's not the same Listener. This is the point. My ,addListener, method takes ,Listener,s from my interface and I want to give to the ,addListener, and instance of the Listener class declared in the external software."				
"But Listener will be provide by an external class (which I do not write). So, I cannot force Listener class to implement my interface. I have no control over the Listener class from the ""external"" code."	Listener			
"In any case, your ""Listener"" parameter and the 3-rd part listener that is actually past in the function must be of the same ""type"" in order to be accepted by the VM. So either you declare a 3rd part interface as parameter (and you need to add the 3rd part library to your project build path) or you declare you're interface and then 3rd part developer will have to implement it to work in your application..."				
You may need to fully qualify references to the third-party listener if you also have a local Listener class/interface which is not a placeholder.	third-party			
"First approach seems reasonable to me but for second may be i am not able to understand it,since the mail templates will be with in the application and they will not change a lot so i am not able to see the relation of this with Filters or Wrappers"	Filters			
this is just a proposal and not yet finalised.But since we are using mainly using JSP for all presentation so may be they have some prefrence for JSP.bu from my side i want to go for best one if they allow me 100% freedom  :)	JSP			
"Possibly, can you try running your program without this waiting. Perhaps its not needed."	Perhaps			
"If this is a standard GUI app, one should generally not wait (for lock, network activity, or whatever) for any ""substantial"" time in the main GUI thread, as this ""locks up"" the GUI and results in very poor ""human interface"" behavior (and sometimes can result in the OS killing the app).  It's generally OK, though, to wait for a brief time -- less than a second.  In your code it appears you might wait 3 seconds, which is a bit on the long side."	(and			
To PeterLawrey Locking is necessary as multiple applicatons can use this api.				
"(And if LockManager is a class defined by the user, it should include a tryLock type method that encapsulates the above logic into a single tidy call.)"	LockManager			
Peter's answer is probably the simplest approach to do this. But my first instinct would be to see if there's a way to refactor your code to avoid the need for a private enum value.

"One nasty gotcha with ,equals, is that class objects of mutable types may be used either as values or entities, and references to such class objects may either encapsulate their values or their identities.  To know whether two references should be considered ""equal"", one must know what they encapsulate, but there's no standard way by which instances of a class objects can be told what kind of equality they should use, nor for collections to know what kind of equality to ask for in their contents."	equals

"I'd recommend using Google's Volley library. It's asynchronous and works quite well. You might also want to consider preloading/caching your data to make the app appear as responsive as possible. Finally, using a ProgressBar as you have is considered by some to be bad practice, especially if you don't allow it to be canceled. Why not load the info in the background so the rest of the app can be used during loading?"	ProgressBar

"An example of a more standard approach to UI design for what you want is: when certain conditions are met, if the user presses close button show a message (dialog box or something like that) informing them that until those conditions are met you can't close the window. "If you want to learn the ,String, class, read the ,String, API docs. Nothing inherits from ,String,, it's ,final,. ,String, has a single superclass, ,Object,. ,String, methods take very few argument types, most are ,String,, a primitive, or a ,CharSequence,--and ,String, implements ,CharSequence,, so you can use those methods with a ,String, argument. Which part is impossible?"				
"The API's are really not a good place to go if you want to expand your knowledge. They should always be treated as a big ole' reference, because thats what they are. If you really want to expand your learning then grab some free lance type projects and start working on them. Nothing expands knowledge like necessity."	API's

Use Java generics to solve this	generics			
"Just be careful about over-engineering this.  Clients use your library; events happen; there are data associated with those events.  All you need to do is define an interface that passes the client that event data and let them define the implementation they need.  Then allow the client to register for the event.  In that sense, To CodeLionX 's answer is a little more accurate for your situation.  IMHO, using a string to determine an action is not as clear as a specific interface method for that action."	over-engineering			
"Not without getting into reflection and annotations, which you've ruled out.  Besides, those techniques add a lot of complexity and risk of defects on your part for a small benefit on the client's part.  Registering implementation instances are a pretty standard thing in Java and Android.  I don't think it's unreasonable to require an API client to add a couple extra lines of code on their side in order to get the benefit of your API."	Java			
I have to admit that your third criteria is not met by this approach.

"It work fine but I want to get error as an object. ```  if(response.code() == 422)                   {                                           try {                           Log.d(""#####"", response.errorBody().string() + """");                       }                       catch (IOException e)                       {                           Log.d(""#####"", e.getMessage() + """");                       }                        ,output, ```  {""error"":true,""message"":""User Already Exists""}```"				
what this solution does is that it allows retrofit to read the 422 response code as a success and not a failed request which will then allow it to be parsed by your code correctly
