"Side note on code quality: please study java coding guidelines. You don't use ""_"" within method names. Never. Ever."	_			
"Returning an appropriate status code can be more useful than a String message in JSON. For instance, most developers will know what 404 means, whereas ""Not Found"" as a string message won't be as apparent."	String			
"I've been working a little with the Instagram API, there is a brief description here: ,instagram.com/developer/endpoints, They always feed a ,meta, property which contains a ,code,.  That code looks like it is always an HTTP status code.  If it is not 200 then they provide error message as well.  Do you think this would be OK?  All the code and error msg is inside the json formatted string?  Not sure if you are implying that it is possible to send an http response code beside the json output?"				
To jeffery_the_wind: Am guessing you've got your answers by now. Sorry I wasn't around yesterday	now			
"Well yes thank you, I realized I didn't quite understand as much as I need to about HTTP responses in general, and how sparkjava handles those."	sparkjava			
"Would it be acceptable to feed the codes back inside a json formatted variable?  Like for example in the instagram API they always provide a ,meta, property which contains a ,code, property (http status code).  ,instagram.com/developer/endpoints"	json			
"To jeffery_the_wind If the client requested a resource that could not be found, return a ,404 Not Found, error in the HTTP response. Along with it, you can return a JSON that contains the ,404, HTTP status code too. But keep it consistent: do not return ,200 OK, as the HTTP status code and ,404, in your JSON."	it			
"Thanks a lot for helping me out.  I think I understand after dwelling on it for a little while.  I think I need to read more about how sparkjava is delivering the http responses.  I think what you're getting at is that in my GET method, it is returning a string, in this case JSON formatted, but by simply returning a string, it is giving a 200 HTTP response, but the msg is error.  If the user isn't authenticated, I issue a ,halt(401, ""{\""error\"":\""Please Authenticate.\""}"");,.  This way is probably more accurate, since I give an error code, then my custom message."	sparkjava			
"To jeffery_the_wind My advice is: stick to the standards and return the most appropriate HTTP code for each situation. For example, don't return a ,200 OK, when you are requesting a resource that doesn't  exist; a ,404 Not Found , is much better. Don't return a ,200 OK, if the authenticated user has no permission to access a resource; a ,403 Forbidden, is the right response for this situation. Along with the ,4xx, status codes, you can return a descriptive message or the error. It will help the client to understand what was wrong with the request."				
To jeffery_the_wind Let me know if you need any further clarification :)	)

"Because you overflow in ,2_147_483_647 + 1, which is evaluated before you call ,Math.incrementExact, on the result"	Math.incrementExact			
A method call cannot change how an expression whose result is passed to it is compiled.				
"There's only ,one way, to resolve these kind of disagreements."	way			
"I hoped there would be some rational, engineering-like way to make a table on the board, list the pros and cons, and get to an unavoidable, unique solution - I'm still naive after all those years ..."				
To Frank - yes you are naive :-)				
One counter-example is the black magic that frameworks like Spring do to turn text into values when wiring components.				
And also extensions built on top of Java like Groovy which provide weak/dynamic type systems.				
"One of my counter arguments is that ""black magic"" is not necessarily desirable. Sometimes, it's nice that things are simple and straight and you don't have to wade through the source to figure out what is really going on - of course, comments are supposed to be there..."	black			
"I accept that argument for widening values for the primitives, but providing an interface that accepts ,Number,s and a ,String, is misleading. I would point out the ambiguity of how far will the internal processing go to finding the right answer for you (e.g., will it parse hex numbers)? And, more importantly, why on Earth should such an interface be held to the whims of what boils down to input. The provider of that data should know its format, and it should be validated where it comes in so that it can be corrected closest to the problem. A conversion framework could be stood up in parallel."				
"To pickypg ""will it parse hex numbers?"" -- You've missed the point of the principle.  The point being that in the future it would have the capacity to without a signature change.  I agree with your point, keep your contract tight, and call a spade a spade, but I can't count on one hand how many times I've had to retrofit code to accommodate a document ID, an invoice number, a serial number or similar that was ,supposed, to be an integer for all eternity to something alphanumeric."	principle			
"To jonathan.cone I didn't miss the point so much as disagree with it. Rather than having a bunch of do-nothing methods, or at the very least unpredictable ones, I'd much rather have the tight contract. After all, if you need to convert it to fit the contract, then you can write an adapter. If you need to completely change the meaning of the interface, then the meaning of the API has changed anyway, and changes should be acceptable. Anything more is really just over engineered."	it			
"Yes, the debate sounds funny to me, because we are in a strongly type environment, yet people want to weasel their way around that type system. I would err on the side of keeping the type checking too. And isolating the conversion functionality, if any, as you suggest."	me			
"I see... Yes, it may depend on who is doing the search using the browser... Ok, thank you for the answer!"	browser			
Thank you. Can you get the search results in a file instead of the browser?

"""to ultimately have an AST representing the program"", as far as I understand AST isn't used to present a program. It is used to represent the parsed data tree. Also, the AST library is designed for internal usage. It's not part of the API."	AST			
"To BartKiers If you know a way to output a CommonTree it would help a lot. To explain what the user input is you should know that I'm building this language to automatically generate behavior for networks of sensors/robots/etc. Hence, the ""input"" is to specify what kind of individuals a network consists of (for example: are they able to move? What kind of radio's do they have, short range, long range?) This kind of input decides what the individual is capable of, and hence what can be used in the generated program."				
"To BartKiers Also, the ""functions"" an individual has should be expendable, but because I'm using Grammatical Evolution (a technique in Genetic Programming) these functions should be a part of the grammar. Is this answer sufficient?"	Grammatical			
"To BartKiers Hi Bart, maybe it's more clear if you look at the template file for generating the ANTLR file: ,code.google.com/p/snowdrop/source/browse/trunk/src/ANTLRTest ,, in which you can see that (among others) the static properties, and dynamic properties that an individual can have are A B or C, also, the number of different values for integers and floats are restricted by only putting in a few in the generated grammar (which has to do with restricting the search space for the genetic algorithm), so that is also a user provided parameter."				
"See: ,stackoverflow.com/questions/4931346 , how to create an AST contrary to a simple parse tree (especially the line ,CommonTree tree = (CommonTree)parser.parse().getTree();, in the ,Main, class). If that ,is, what you're looking for, you can remove this question, since it's a duplicate in that case. HTH."

"I know separating layers and minimizing dependencies is a good pattern, but isn't it a lot of more work to have two separate domain models."	dependencies			
"Yes, it is more work, but only for you, not all the clients that depend on the output of your service. For them it's far less work, and they don't have to understand your data model to use your results. Data models have totally different requirements, for persistent storage and recall. Domain models conceptualize the problem into something clients can understand. It's the same thing as saying making a UI instead of just giving SQL access is ""more work""."	UI			
"Thanks for your answer Chris. It makes me realized that we really need a new set of classes so that the domain model can change without changing the public API. Googling with that in mind, I found what I was really looking for and I was able to answer my own question."	Chris

"It might be not clear in the question but my semantics need to be accessed remotely. Hence, ""...Providing a remotely accessible API over REST is completely orthogonal to your concern ..."" is not accurate. Do you have any specific suggestion or just a general statement about ""just put a layer of abstraction..."" which does not contribute much (IMO)?"				
"I would suggest forming the question more clearly and in greater detail if you want a specific answer. What is the API's purpose? Who are its consumers? For example, if the API needs to cater to varying types of clients, I would choose REST. If all clients are Java, and I'm willing to lock myself in and deal with the pain of re bundling binaries for clients when I change the API, I could opt for Java RMI. These choices are contextual and must be taken carefully. I gave a general suggestion to nudge you in the right direction and get you thinking about the problem."	REST			
i edited my question to emphasise the fact that my semantics need to be accessed remotely and the API is CRUD. I believe that now you can be more specific in your answer as well.	API

What is the reason the API jar must be obfuscated?	API			
I believe the consensus was that your cannot avoid piracy with obfuscation in Java. You can use the license and calling back to a mothership to do stuff instead.	obfuscation			
"Its not purely to make piracy harder, its a way to say ""modify this, but not this"" I suppose. I don't understand the last sentence, could you clarify?"				
"There is nothing wrong with providing a ""foo-api.jar"" along with ""foo.jar"" and friends, instead of going for obfuscation (where it is unclear to me if this is a customer requirement or you are just investigating on your own).  Regarding the mothership: If you make your application depend on being able to reach back to your servers to do some important calculation needed for further processing, you can provide that only to those with a valid license-"	foo-api.jar

"Look into ,Interfaces,. In a simple model, ""extensions"" will implement one or more interfaces which will in turn consume one or more ""host"" interfaces. That is, the internal logic is not exposed directly, but only through defined contracts. By using interfaces the code is generally free to pass around either the ,actual, objects (hidden behind interfaces) or proxy/facade objects (that also implement said interfaces) - between the host and extension, however, there are only the interfaces/contracts."				
"So I should write my own implementations/behavior as one of many possible behaviors, and allow plugins to specify their own implementations and extend my classes? What if there is behavior regarding one component I want to guarantee, but also allow plugins to extend?"	implementations/behavior			
"It's all about determining exactly ,what, should be extended, and ,how,. Is it adding a rule to the end of a series of rules? Is it adding a new dispatch/handler for a certain condition? Is it supplying default values? Is it supplying a replacement component? Is it reacting to/overriding events?"				
Only those 11 values can be valid matches?  You'll need to create a few RegEx patterns.				
"Note the ,(?i), flag in the first pattern.  In Java this will render the pattern case-insensitive.  ,a-z, means all lower case letters where ,A-Z, is for uppercase."				
"Codehaus is no more. Check out ,enunciate, instead."

"I'm slightly confused by your explanation. Is the service demanding basic authentication? If so the credentials need to be passed within an ,Authorization, header whose value starts with ,Basic , and followed by a base64 encoded version of ,username:password,. You should further check if your internal tool is sending the credentials preemptively which your postman might not. If the credentials, however, are required in the body than basic auth will not work."	Authorization

"I think, I didn't word my question correctly. No this is not a problem of sync or async. It is more of a API design question - How would structure your code/API?"				
"Yes, I think your update is more relevant to my question. The downside of having a single method is, that this single method would have to effectively return the output. But let's just say that there are multiple outputs. So for instance, my algorithm is probably creating two lists. Your suggestion would require me to create a class that will hide these two lists and my method would have to return an instance of this class. Well, now if you think about it, this return class is anemic in nature. It is serving as an empty container. Not quite useful? Reminds me of the anemic VO/DTO pattern."	It			
"Well, sadly Java lacks a ""Pair"" or ""Tuple"" class, which makes returning 2 values always a bit odd. Still, if the ,end, result is 2 values, that's what you should return (in a ,Collection, for example, that way it's not locked into just 2 values). If the logic works so, that the first value is calculated in ,method1(), and the second one in ,method3(), (hypothetical parts of your algorithm), then there might be a different way about it, but not necessarily any better."	Java			
"Ok, lets say, they are not return types of same data type? One is a String another is a List."				
Then that's already a complex enough data type to warrant its own class. I mean classes are cheap and they just make the code more easy to understand.				
what if doExecuteMySpecialAlgorithm throws an exception which I expect the caller to handle? it wouldn't really look nice if all your getResult methods also throw this exception up?	doExecuteMySpecialAlgorithm			
"If you go this way, I would make the ,doExecuteMySpecialAlgorithm(), private and rename ,getResult(), into something more descriptive. Make the caller unable to call the algorithm at all, and rely on the result giving method."	doExecuteMySpecialAlgorithm()			
"To Jay; I aggree with To Kayaman, hide as much of the implementation as possible, and no it wouldn't look nice to ,catch, everywhere you call that function, but it's also not particularly 'nice' to have to 'catch' as much as I do with the normal Java API's (put a ,throws, at the end of a function in some base class and strict compilation rules and watch the fun ensue of the number of ,try,'s you'll implement..) .. it goes with the territory of writing an API. Just think; how would YOU use this API? If YOU wouldn't like using the way you'd implement, then implement another way :)"	To

"To Java1 Yes. You were not allowed to declare ,static, methods on interfaces in Java 7 (nor default methods in fact)."				
Can the static method be called on the interface or only on classes implementing the interface?	interface			
To Java1: In a static interface method you can call other static interface methods as well!	well			
"To Java1 The containing type, be it an interface or a class, of a static method is just a namespace for it. There is nothing wrong with allowing a static method to be qualified by an interface name."

"I think the question is clear. This error message: ""Missing URI template variable 'courseId' ..."" for the path: ""/topics/1/courses/1/marks"" tells us that Spring was unable to populate the ,courseId, parameter of ,MarksController.getAllMarks,. The reason for this is that the annotation on that method does not declare ,{courseId}, instead it declares ,{id},. The names of the placeholder parameters in the To RequestMapping annotation must match the names of the parameters to the annotated method. There's a similar error in the POST method so I mentioned that in the answer too."				
"you can start the activity in ,onPostExecute(), if it's an inner class or use an interface ,stackoverflow.com/questions/18517400 ,  the code continues to run while the task is running, hence ,asynchronous"	onPostExecute()

"Note that this method just flags the document for encryption. Once it is flagged, encryption is automatic when you save with the current id file, and decryption is automatic when you open with it.  Also note - the fact that you signed the agent with a given id is insufficient. It's the actual current id that counts, so if you sign it with ServerA, but run it on ServerB, it will be ServerB's public/private key pair that is used for encryption/decryption. (The reason being that a signature does not give the agent access to fhe id file conttainging the key pair.)"	decryption			
"Ah, it's starting to come back to me... The documentation for this method is talking about using secret encryption keys, not public/private key pairs - but you can do it. I wrote an article about this many years ago. I can't find a link to its original location on notes.net, but fortunately, it has been copied elsewhere. Here's a link. ,gcc.upb.de/WWW/WI/WI2/wi2_lit.nsf/KPoolThemes , My sample app in the article actually lets you toggle between both secret key and public/private key encryption techniques."				
Thank you very much for these answers. I will try to implement these recommendations.				
"To RichardSchwartz: That seems like a life saver. Unfortunately, notes forum is offline, too. Waybackmachine holds at least the solution which will be:  PublicEncryptionKeys will not be recognized by NotesDocument.encrypt unless you first specify NotesDocument.encryptionKeys = <your secret encryption keys>"

"Sorry, but I have not done any further investigations on this topic. I am not even sure that saving the document with an agent would work. But I think that the Domino back-end simply takes the Names-field for a Directory lookup to get the public key and encrypts the field with it."

"To AbhaleAmol response appear to be correct. Your stacktrace displays the following: "" Cannot deserialize value of type ,java.util.ArrayList<com.example.demo.entity.User>, from Object value (token ,JsonToken.START_OBJECT,)"". You have an exception in deserialization in the first place. Probably you have an interceptor for RestTemplate that is returning the null. The solution is to create the wrapper class ass suggested in the answer. The problem is that in JSON, you have an object that contains a property named User, that property is an array. So you have the wrap the object in first place."	wrapper

"This works well except on the MapR version of Kafka (MapR Streams).  The offset there is the actual byte offset of the start of the record and not the ""increment by one"" offset used in the original Kafka... So taking the difference between earliest and latest only tells you the sum of the messages (and not even that, really) with mapR."				
"You're correct about that that.  The question was about ""real"" Kafka, that's why the +1"	real

"The name of the parameters are stored by the bytecode, I think, but reflection does not give you a way to get at those. You can parse the bytecode yourself, or better yet use a library like ASM."	ASM			
"To nathan the argument names are only stored in the byte code if the code was compiled with the javac debug flag turned on. And yes, asm allows you to access parameter names"	asm

"This is what I have today, but consider the case where the client as a Customer entity in hand and wants to get an order.  Should that be a new finder on the customer service or should the client invoke the query you already have on the order service?"				
"If the View that has a Customer entity generates an event that requests an order by customer, what difference does it really make which Class fulfills that request?  The View shouldn't need to know how that happens, and the Service shouldn't need to know where the request originated or what else the requesting object knows about the situation."				
"OK, so you are saying that the entity type returned dictates the service it should go in?"				
"Yes exactly, you request an order no matter what parameter needed then it is an order request, when you request a customer you are interested in returning a customer no matter what query inputs needed."

"thax, it's work great... but can you tell me what the different between your  id attribute and mine ?"				
"ListActivities simply look for a ListView with this particular id. The ,To android:id, prefix means that this id is part of the Android namespace, in order to find the Android ids you must use ,findViewById(android.R.id.xxx),. ,findViewById(android.R.id.list), cannot locate a View with the id ,R.id.list,."				
"You didnt mention where your server S1 is located (external/internal), and wether it needs access to the services provided by S3."	S3			
"To AlexanderYastrebov, have a shared secret between the two servers/apis that are supposed to communicate. The client uses this secret to compute a MAC that will be verified by the destination service. See ,this,. Your question is a possible duplicate of the question"

"The $ is to declare a variable replacement. The curly brackets are just to define packaging, etc. So it will go through and replace ${build} with the variable ,build,'s content."				
As you see there are many ways to define it. If I were you I would start by looking at the file where you encounter them.	it			
"At the very top of the file is the line: <dirname property=""build_dir"" file=""${ant.file.calendar}""/>      So this would mean that there's a defined property somewhere called ""ant.file.calendar""? I can't find it anywhere. I did find the build property in another xml that was being imported, however."				
"If you go to the base directory of your project, you could try to find it with grep. ,find . -type f | xargs grep ant.file.calendar"	grep

"Note to self - 1) the comment above is helpful because it states what the identifier is for. You don't have to go to the top of the html page to see what entity the ID is for.  2) The presence of a redundant comment with nothing interesting is a stronger signal that there is no gotcha, than if there is no comment at all (analogous to ""nulls in relational database tables could mean many alternative things"")."	nulls			
"You should add to your list ""What guarantees are there on the values of the ID? Can it be ,null,? What would ,null, mean?"" I've started using JSR 305 annotations.  Writing ,public setAge(To Min(0) To Max(120) final int newAge), or the corresponding ,getAge, accessor automatically populates the Javadoc with useful information."	newAge)			
"Okay, those two extremes I agree completely. What about that grey area in between where you work in a team of people, perhaps remotely distributed geographically, but outside your team no one uses your API? I'm guessing there is no absolute right or wrong practice, you have to treat every case individually?"				
"I my code, I usually don't document getters and setters and methods that are self-evident even from their name, but ""routine"" methods usually deserve it, as that what you will see in a tooltip in your IDE. But I guess that's all about personal taste and what you think is right."	tooltip			
"Fair enough. Back to the public library extreme - what is the ""official"" reason you would document ""obvious"" for the html documentation? Is it because your audience may include very inexperienced programmers? Is it a user-experience enhancement to please the marketing department? Or that html documents are meant to be read as prose more than as code?"				
"It's for the sake of consistency, I guess. When you are reading a generated docs page, it'd look kind of unprofessional to have undocumented methods there, particularly because there can be some catch to them, like that they return null in some situations, can throw a runtime exception, or just some implementation details and usage tips. If you have only the name and parameters there, you might wonder if it really does what you think."

"To sai_ana: You'll likely need to use a language that allows inline assembly like C or C++ if you want to learn to reimplement a system call like file API without any of the nice wrapper functions. I haven't checked OpenJDK source code, but it probably just uses the nice wrapper functions in C++ standard library or OS API rather than reimplementing it from scratch. But if that is what you want, it's worth it to check out the source code for glibc. A system call is an entirely different beast than a pure function like strlen()."

"To Ankit Yes, of course. Each key appears at most once in the map, so two Entries will have two different keys. Different keys may be mapped to the same bucket of the map, in which case their respective entries will belong to the same linked list."	map

"PUT/PATCH/POST , all go through the same assembler. The point is if somebody wants to disassociate the site from the cable, he can send a {""siteID"":null} . How do I now make out that the siteID was sent or not. For e.g. of the input json now is {""description"":""changed desc""}, then in both the cases I get siteID as null. In the latter case, the siteID should not be disassociated from the cable."	siteID			
"This is why PATCH method is preferred if you want to change only part of the entity. Your {""description"":""changed desc""} in PATCH will not overwrite siteId. In the case of PUT you should specify existing siteId value (as well as other values) to not miss them: {""description"":""changed desc"", ""siteId"": ""currentSiteId"", ...}."	PATCH

"Thanks for the answer, but I don't get it. If it is a singleton and everyone uses the same object. How can the object manage multiple requests at the same time? I don't understand this"				
"Exactly - you can always make concurrent calls to one and the same object. Why not? Your webserver takes care of initializing request threads and managing a thread pool for those request executions. The major question with this: Is your singleton ""thread-safe""? And that's totally up to you. Store request-related state in your singleton, and you won't and you will get random errors as soon as you receive concurrent requests. Dont store request-related state and you are fine - your singleton would be ""thread-safe"" which means ""safe to use in multi-threaded environments""."				
"I mean, I can understand that you can modify an object, add information or extract it concurrently. But I cannot understand HOW you can make an object execute the same function concurrently."				
"I get error message ""Cannot resolve symbol 'RequestParam'"	'RequestParam'			
"Yes it's pretty strange but it seems that he doesn't use those ""wrappers"". The problem here is probably that attribute names doesn't match (JSON vs Java). When your serializer will look for an attribute with the name ,Borrowers,, it will not find it as you called it ,borrower, in the ,CreditComplex, class. Review your code in this way. And please, do not start attributes names with upper case, it's unreadable. Edit: Didn't pay attention to the first model. According to what akortex91 said, it's too complicated and it doesn't match your java model structure."

"If you're talking about ,equals, you need to override that method since the default implementation would return ,false, for two different instances. Explaining the answer to the question poster should be much more helpful to them				
"While this code may solve the question, ,including an explanation, of how and why this solves the problem would really help to improve the quality of your post, and probably result in more up-votes. Remember that you are answering the question for readers in the future, not just the person asking now. Please edit your answer to add explanation, and give an indication of what limitations and assumptions apply."

"""what should be the data class name?"" -- it can be whatever you want. ""and if toasting is not a good way to make sure if final json is what i need so how can i test it? "" -- the problem is not the ,Toast,. The problem is that you appear to be just calling ,toString(), on the object. ,toString(), does not create JSON, XML, CSV, HTML, etc. If you have configured Retrofit properly, it will convert your object to JSON for you."	toString()

This will largely depend on the code in the controller. By default if you do not specify what to render it will attempt to render a view by the same name as the method under the directory within the views matching that of the controller name. Post an example of your controller method and we can help you understand what your options are.	controller

"Hi To Chinez. I am very happy to hear that the answer was helpful. Of course, please, see the edited answer: to remove the AM/PM part from the date string you need to change the pattern ,hh:mm a, to ,hh:mm,. Having said that, please, consider use the ,hh:mm a, pattern instead of manually add the AM/PM afterwards in your code. Regarding the ,temp, field issue, you can follow a similar approach to the one provided for these dates but, according to the ,API documentation,, I think a better approach will be to provide the ,units, parameter."				
"With the appropriate value, something like: ,api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/onecall?lat=,{lat}&lon={lon}&units=metric. Pay attention to the units ,metric, value. It will return the information directly in Celsius degrees. I hope it helps."

I hav found good stackoverflow explanation				
"""In very simple cases like adding a column for example, Hibernate will work very well because it's a non breaking change. On the other hand, if you want to delete a column for example, it becomes more delicate. In this case your java entity will not know about this column anymore, but in the database it will still exist."" from ,stackoverflow.com/questions/66921191 , . It seems to be your case"

"To JVersty, You should only export the interfaces/API you don't intend to change. This leaves you free to change the implementation. If you change any exported class, you must unload every module which uses that module."	You			
"The short answer is because it is more specific than a Graphics and thus is not a valid override of the method.  It can be equally or less specific, but not more specific."	Graphics			
It's not a valid override of paintComponent which JPanel has specified as (Graphics g) on it's method?	paintComponent			
"There was actually a question that talked about this in depth recently.  Look through the answers on ,stackoverflow.com/a/9950538/567864,.  It should explain why you can be equally or less specific but not more specific when overriding a method."				
"Ok, I think I get it now, wish you put this as an answer, that link pretty much answers it for me. Thank you. ;-)"				
"I went ahead and wrote it as an answer along with a little explanation that's specific to your case.  Also, as far as I know, it's always safe to cast the Graphics instance to a Graphics2D inside of a Swing component.  It is because of the inheritance tree (and historical reasons) that it must accept a Graphics and not Graphics2D."	Graphics			
So this is because it's defined that way by JPanel?	JPanel			
"Yeah, when you define your method as you are doing it now - with Graphics2D, you are simply overloading it, but it is not being called by your JPanel."	Graphics2D

"Just to pick a nit, OutOfMemoryErrors probably aren't transient; if you've got some data that requires more memory than your JVM is configured to use, retrying the job isn't going to help."	nit			
On a server a OutOfMemoryError occur in the most case because there are temporary to many clients requests. Some seconds later this can look others.				
"If you are getting OutOfMemoryError because of load, you need to throttle the load somehow (queue the requests or just refuse them).  OutOfMemoryErrors can occur ,anywhere, as a result of memory usage elsewhere.  You can't just surround one part of the code with try/catch."

"Writing variables in ,ALL_CAPS_LIKE_THIS, is for ,constants,. ,final, does not mean ,constant,. ,ALL_CAPS, is appropriate if [A] it is final, ,and, [B] it is ,static,, ,and, [C] it is ,not, a reference to a mutable thing. e.g. ,static final List<String> ITEMS = new ArrayList<String>();, is still not correct - an arraylist is not immutable. ,static final List<String> ITEMS = List.of(""A"", ""B""), would be appropriate - ,List.of, returns immutable lists. You need all 3."	List.of			
"Check the 'wire' - but here's my guess: Given that the naming is all-caps, retrofit thinks its a constant and therefore doesn't send it. What possible point is there in sending constant info? (See my previous comment that explains what a constant is. It's not just something marked ,final, - it's something whose value is known at compile time, essentially), and therefore it doesn't send it at all."				
Use Retrofit with a GSON serialization adapter and then make your object a GSON object. It's pretty much a standard in the industry for Android.

thank you very much. it helped me. but appeared new question. now I receive requestDTO. I need to create new user account object and map fields from dto to it and map role. is that a good practice?				
"Yes, it is, using Entities in your Controllers as response or request should be avoided at all costs. See your entities as the core of your business. These are the classes you use in your services and while doing some serious business logic. All the other classes (so-called DTOs) are used to get data and send data to the consumers of your API. This also means that you decouple your public model from your domain model, meaning that you can change any of those without having to modify the other (of course the mapping needs to be changed, but that is hidden from the consumers of your API)."	Entities			
Thank you! I finally understood how to build the consumer tests. Do you by any change also have an example of how to verify the provider with the API in the next step?	API

"Please don't post junk in your question and don't ask for a solution ""quickly"". The site requires that you post sufficient text with your code so that you adequately ,explain, your code and your problem. Trying to get around this by posting junk will invite close-votes and down-votes to your question because you are seen as not putting in effort to help make your question easier to answer."	down-votes			
Investigate your problem so that you know which bean is not being created. Then look at your code: How are you creating that bean? Can you think of any reason why what you are doing might not work? Then ask a specific question about that bean -- the error message tells you what type is the problem.

"I assume for the nomenclature, you are using Spring.So I think, in this case, you forgot consumes (ex.  ,consumes = ""application/json"",) annotation in ,RequestMapping,, because your are passing to the REST method ,exportConfiguration, data is not already supported."				
"And can I set that consumes = ""application/json"" somehow from the request side? Sorry for possibly foolish question."	application/json			
"something like this: ,To RequestMapping(value = { ""/export"" }, method = RequestMethod.POST, produces = ""text/plain;charset=UTF-8"", consumes = ""application/json""),. But it is only an example, I do not know if you consumes json ;-)"	To			
"Yes, it should consume json. But just now I checked - there are other functions that have not that 'consumes' in the Spring header of the function, too, look the same, but don't return that error and reach the breakpoint in the body of the function."				
"I think it is not only what consumes the spring rest method, also what accept the lombok query, it is related to accept header in the http method"	accept			
"And can I turn on some my checking, in order to put there the breakpoint? For I have not the file DispatcherServlet in the project."	breakpoint

"To JimGarrison, appreciate your insight. What do you mean by API is broken ? As in it is interpreting the request differently or something else?"	API			
"As in the API is GZIPping the data but then sending it through a UTF-8 encode.  Also, what package/library is the ,Response, object from? Where can I find Javadoc for it?"	API			
"There is your issue.  You are converting to ,String, at one point, which tries to interpret the incoming byte stream as UTF-8.  You must ensure that the bytes that were originally received for the response body are passed through untouched."				
"HTTP status code 404 is ""Not found"". This means your request doesn't match any of your registered endpoints. Make sure your GET request is pointed at localhost:port/movies."				
"Could be that he does not have ,To ResponseBody, annotation in his controller method."	annotation

You cannot get there by putting breakpoints in your own code because that code is never even reached. You have some kind of security Funktionality i assume its Spring Security. If you only want to debug to where the error is thrown you will have to put breakpoints in the Spring Classes. This will not be that benefitial. If you want to change the Funktionality of you Security you will have to alter the SpringSecurity Configuration. Im not quiet sure what it is that you want to achive by debugging there when you know that the request itselve is the error.

"It is extremely unlikely that ,DataOutputStream.writeBytes, is what you should be using here, as that will write a buffer prefixed with four bytes of the length of the buffer. Have you tried writing directly to the OutputStream of ,con.getOutputStream(),, or better yet, wrap it in an ,OutputStreamWriter, and get rid of your intermediate ,StringBuilder,, instead writing directly to the stream."	DataOutputStream.writeBytes

"More precise one could talk of API as the part of a library that specifies the behavior, so interfaces and documentation for example. Having that you could have different implementations of one API specification that all fulfill the same overall result."	API			
This concept doesn't apply to just Java	Java			
"To Zabuza: thanks for your comments. So the answer to my first question would be ""yes""? What would you say about the second question?"	yes			
"I would say an API consists of the whole set of classes and functions, together they form an API. But more precise the API is just the description of the input and output, it does not necessarily declare ,how, one must implement this description. This perfectly matches the concept of ,interface,s. So you could for example have someone that creates the API by just creating hundreds of ,interfaces, and their ,documentation,. Then another team could write implementations for example."	API			
"If you need only the Player list, why dont you return the list directly? Since the caller already knows the team."	team

"Thats because ""2001-01"" doesn't match ""yyyy-MM-dd"" the day is never specified in the JSON, you are most likely using a different format when adding and when retrieving"				
"To OughtToPrevail If OP used Jackson for both building and parsing the JSON, there very likely wouldn't be a problem like this. "To hyperfkcb The ,data, will be a query string by default and you could extract it as a request param . JSON.Stringify(data)

Also, this is a case where you ,must, use the ,List, interface instead of ,ArrayList, for your ,orders, so that Hibernate can insert its own managed ,List, implementation. "Dwarsaw, I've taken the liberty of editing out the data.fixer.io API key you included in your request. Most likely this is accidental, but you should take utmost care to NEVER publish any API keys to any service anywhere in public. This includes in Github source code and in Stack Overflow questions. Leaving such AP?keys publicly exposed can allow others to make requests in your name and potentially cost you A LOT of money in service costs."	data.fixer.io

Is creating a member variable essentially just creating a variable global/static to GUI.java?	GUI.java			
"To Dwarsaw Yes, in the sense that I believe you understand the task, but no, in the sense that your language is wrong (Java has no globals, and 鈥渟tatic?means something else); but yes, creating a variable in the scope of the GUI class body."				
"So if I got this right, there is no global variable but you can have public variables which can be referenced by other classes correct? And static is specific to the class and quite literally ""static"" in a sense correct?"	And			
"I can鈥檛 really go over all the details here, but yes, public member variables exist in the scope of a class or object, and are visible to all other code. 鈥淪tatic?members (public or not) are scoped to the class, and shared by all instances of that class, while non-static members belong to each individual instance. Avoid public and static both, unless you actually need them."	(public

"You say that you will send POST requests, but how are these requests initiated? Do you receive the request from another application, or you invoke POST based on some different business logic? I'm asking this because if you expose your own api and than pass it further i don't think it's a good  idea to do the get pooling on the same thread as you may end up with way to many threads active in the same time."	POST			
"Yes, I will receive a request from another application, then I have to modify that request a bit and  make a new POST request towards the third app. So my application will be in the middle of that chain."	POST

"Well that doesn't compile either, there is an ,else, without ,if,, but if it did it would certainly decompress this response's ,Content-encoding: gzip, correctly and give you back the JSON it is stated to contain. So what's your question?"				
"The issue is that it doesn't do that all, it simply either provides back the same garble of characters as I provided above or it provides non information like ""[BTo 307f6b8c"", which I know is not a correct response due to examples provided in API documentation. "No, the issue is that the code you posted doesn't compile, but that decompression code can never provide ,[BTo 307f6b8c,, which is the result of calling ,byte[].toString(),. The behavour you allege is impossible. Post the real code: and in particular post the code that is printing the response."	byte[].toString()			
"This is a good solution. The error in your original code was converting raw bytes into String and back to raw bytes - as this is usually not a loss-less conversion, unless the bytes do represent a string and you know which charset to use. It would have worked had you used ,ofByteArray(), instead - but of course, at the expense of buffering the whole gzip'ed content in memory."	ofByteArray()

"Why do you need multiple versions, typically you can do a lot of mutations to an API and maintain backwards compatibility. You often see the API version in the URL,  /v1/exampleapi/sayhello, you then use an adapter to upgrade older messages to the newest version, to avoid code douplication. Another possibility I have seen is to have one endpoint and include a version header."				
We have multiple clients to our api. Not all of them agree too move to new version. I want that at any point of time we can support any version without breaking or impacting existing functionality. Versioning through header or url is fine but i am looking for a solution that helps me maintain code behind the api's with minimum duplication.				
"Most of the time you try to upgrade the older messages to the newest version. I have done something similar with an internal setting protocol, which changed for every release, and sometimes even in hotfixes, so the server had to be able to talk to 5+ different client versions. The trick is to have simple converter which can upgrade only to the next version. When the client says he wants to talk version 3, you convert your version 5 message down to 4, then to 3 and upgrade from 3 to 5 when receiving. This way adding an extra version only requires converter from the previous to current version."				
stackoverflow.com/questions/4805168	stackoverflow.com/questions/4805168

"In fact, the bug is from the line 74 : ,github.com/OfficeDev/ews-java-api/blob/master/src/main/java ,. It's strange because it works well when i call the same method create ""normally"". But when i call it from another web-service, it doesn't work. Any idea if a web-service can call another web-service ?"				
"I suspect that what's happening is that in the context where you call the method ""normally"", this web service is actually running some internal setup code that puts itself into a correct state which is leveraged to call the downstream service. However, when you call from another web service, the intermediate web service doesn't put itself into the correct state and run the necessary preliminary code. The only thing I can say is debug both paths to figure out what is going on, which may take a while. :-/"				
"As for your question, absolutely! One of the key benefits of web services is that they act like functions in that they can call each other as needed."

"This doesn't work. I'm not inheriting. Let's say package ,org.sirix.node, with node implementations and ,org.sirix.access, for API implementations of transactions. Then, in a perfect world within org.sirix.access the node package should be visible but not from the outside."	transactions			
"a Protected constructor can access from package too, u don't need to inherit!! i think you have to use one package for both classes and make the constructors of node package protected and instantiate them from access classes."				
"No, for instance in a tree-structure, nodes should only be created from within a transaction. Using the node-constructors is really pointless as the nodes are not viewable from within any transaction and not persitable, but it is possible to instantiate nodes because the classes have to be ,public,, as the transaction-implementations are in another package."	tree-structure			
There's not much you can do if they need to be instantiated from a separate package. Sorry. Unless there is some way to have the nodes be a protected class and make the class that needs to instantiate them a friend class. But I have no idea if that's actually possible and friend classes open up other potential issues...

"To Johannes - Composites are generally built using Builders.  So as long as the tree structure is viewed as a composite object rather than as a document or single datasource, it's worth considering.  The idea is to abstract the construction to a director so that you're guaranteed proper creation."				
"I don't really know, but I think then it's more a document or single datasource. For instance one can import an XML-document into a database which would be a single resource in the database. Furthermore we store snapshots (after commiting transactions). So you open a specific revision of the resource (the tree-structure) and you can manipulate and persist the changes. But every kind of tree-structure is possible, besides a few constraints for sure (ElementNode cannot be a child of a TextNode...). Ah you are referring to the composite pattern. But no, our nodes have to be unique (unique ID)."	XML-document			
"Even then, I would still try to find an abstraction where you can replicate process.  The more reuse you can make, the better."

Thnx for reply it did work . So did you mean  Indexing - Thread.sleep(60000) and Search operation works fine ? what is the unuseful side of manual refreshing ?	Search			
"Thread.sleep works but is not that elegant... the downside of manually refreshing is performance, a new lucene segment gets flushed, if you index a lot of documents at the same time and you refresh after each index operation...well your throughput is going to suck :)"				
"That said refreshing during testing is fine, in production just let the search be near real-time, that's it."				
"While this solution works, it implies that you should ,refresh, your indices manually.  As I'm sure To mconlin knows but hasn't said, refreshing manually for testing purposes is fine, but would have a performance impact in production if done on every request. better to let Elasticsearch do it automatically in the background."

"How do you do your search (I refer to ,getHitCount(), method)? Are you working with raw ,Term,s or just parsing the query?"	getHitCount()			
"To mindas The author uses a Term object to create the search string: ,protected int getHitCount(String fieldName, String searchString) throws IOException   { 	DirectoryReader dr = DirectoryReader.open(directory); 	IndexSearcher searcher = new IndexSearcher(dr); 	Term t = new Term(fieldName, searchString); 	Query query = new TermQuery(t); 	int hitCount = TestUtil.hitCount(searcher, query); 	return hitCount;   },. The TestUtil class only contains a single line of code ,public static int hitCount(IndexSearcher searcher, Query query)   { 	return searcher.search(query, 1).totalHits;   },."				
"Great, parsing the query with the QueryParser and using the WhitespaceAnalyzer did the trick. I was aware that the analysis step must be the same at index time and at search time, but I somehow thought this would happen implicitly. Thank you very much!"	QueryParser			
"Assuming the floor is supposed to be transparent, you need to sort it into the middle of your cubes. Since it has different dimensions, it would probably be easiest to just make separate Models for the cubes above and below the floor. Then submit the three models in order from far to near. But if your floor is opaque, then you just need to draw it before you draw the transparent stuff. The trouble with transparent stuff is that you can never rely on depth testing...you have to draw all of it from far to near. Can't go back and insert something in the middle."				
"If the floor is intersecting multiple layers of cubes, you might need to break it up into six individual rectangles and break up the cube layers into more models so you can adequately draw them in order."				
Lets forget the transparency for a bit now. All the cubes in the video are fully opaque. They are sorted every frame just the way you said to. If I understand depth testing at least a little bit correctly I think that no depth testing is happening somehow. In the video some cubes should go half way through the big plane. And you can't see that happening they are either drawn fully in front of the big plane or aren't drawn at all.				
"This line I gave you: ,new DepthTestAttribute(false), turns off depth testing. You have to turn it off if drawing transparent cubes."				
Ahh totally missed that. Finally fixed things in my game to look the way they were before i tried to batch things up... yay!I turned the depth testing on. Without depth testing things looked good but when with shadows they messed up again a little bit. Depth testing plus sorting worked great for my games case. Thank you very much! You helped so much.	that			
Thank you very much for your answer. Things got a lot better. I noticed one more problem though. I updated my question. Could you take a look? Also would you like me to add a bounty before accepting  your answer?

To gstackoverflow First install Oracle. Then configure Oracle. Then connect to Oracle. Use whichever type of driver you prefer. The type-4 is always recommended. The type-3 and 2 drivers are stop-gap solutions for when your platform doesn't have a driver.	type-3

"What type of request are they resending? POSTs to create resources? Do you have a single database, or are they clustered also? You could possibly use a conditional header like If-None-Match to address the issue."	If-None-Match

"Well, if your system is fully load balanced, then you need to add a single gatekeeper somewhere .. may as well be a cache in front. I'm not sure what you're looking for by way of design pattern. Get a request, cache it, and fire it forward. Ignore later requests to that particular URL/request body pair for as long as your business logic dictates."				
"Thanks , Yes this looks like a good option, But I wanted to know if there is a standard design pattern in APIs to address this issue."	APIs

"Yup, but you didn't say ,how, you'd imported the class. Now that you've provided the code, it's clearer - it's because you've got ,import java.awt.*"				
"Because you've basically said ""When I say Rectangle, I mean exactly java.awt.Rectangle."" I would suggest avoiding the default package though, at which point that aspect is irrelevant, and you just need to consider conflicts between classes in different packages."	Rectangle			
"""java also always imports classes from System, String, Integer, Array, Float,etc."",, you mean classes of the package ,java.lang,."				
"Btw your answer currently misses the following part: ,""However, I then placed my own Rectangle class in the default package (i.e. no package names declared), and imported the java.awt.Rectangle class as before. At compile time, the compiler used the Rectangle class that was in the default package, not the one that I had imported from the java.awt package."",. I think Jon is right here, that OP uses wildcard imports. If not, then he would need the qualified class name (like in your example)."	Rectangle			
"Well in Java ,language, terms, imports only affect what names mean. It sounds like the Blackberry platform was doing some very odd things - if you're going to base any part of your answer on that, I would be very explicit about it. It's also unclear what you mean by "" java also always imports classes from System, String, Integer, Array, Float from the java.lang package"" - that makes it sound like System is a package too, etc. It's just that the compiler imports ,everything, from the java.lang package by default..."	everything			
Thanks. Makes sense. I appreciate you taking the time to answer.

"I dont see a reason for having a custom exception if you actually encounter and want to report an IOException. What you can do is to chain your exception to give a better message: ,catch (IOException ioe) { throw new IOException(""Cannot read settings file="" + name, ioe); }"				
"To eckes OP means that you should wrap this ,IOException, into a custom exception that extends from ,RuntimeException, so your client code of your API is clean about using try-catch blocks."	try-catch			
To LuiggiMendoza OP was not mentioning RuntimeException. Besides having unchecked exceptions is only in some circles regarded as good design for APIs.				
"No such rule or best practice of wrapping in custom exception in APIs. When developing APIs you need to evaluate what makes more sense to the client of the API, whether original exception or custom exception."	APIs

"General rule: ,First, complete your application, ,then, worry about its performance, ,then, determine where the performance is actually lost, and ,then, do something about it. "The klient could be anywhere. Say that the server monitors the water level. You would like to check that the water lever every thrid second on the client. Then the client must send a request to the server every third second. The client could be on a phone or on a computer in another city. However the server could write a copy of each request to a log locally, to monitor the requests. Then both the client and the server would have a copy of the data."	data

"Pretty good answer. However I would add that in general key to avoiding verbs is imagining actions and properties as objects. The best example of this I've seen: instead of POST(or PUT) to /rocket/launch use PUT(or POST) to /rocket/launches/ to ""create new launch object property of the rocket"". In more general case of isValid checks of exisiting objects you can try to get validity property (GET /accounts/{id}/validity ) or use it as property of returned object from GET /accounts/{id}"

"JsonHttpResponseHandler looks like a Guava future. If it is some sort of future, you probably need to block on it because there will be a race between the future completing and you checking the contents of the outer class."	JsonHttpResponseHandler			
"If it's the android-async-http JsonHttpResponseHandler, you'll want to either map it to some flavor of future or have a ,CountDownLatch, in ,setContent, that you set in the callbacks, then ,await, on before ,setContent, returns."	setContent

"You can save your results to different files in some custom format so that each thread will save its own result. Then after all threads have finished, you can compile those files into a single report so that you won't spend time on test execution phase."				
"So, the only advise I have: obviously you have to see how you can ""shard"" your data, so that you can process it in parallel to then ""join"" the results in the end, to ideally turn that into a single sequential calls to excel. Writing to excel in parallel would most likely end up with corrupted data."	data

"Have you tried to see if there is a ""required"" attribute in the parameter annotation that you can set to false? I know there is one in To RequestParam, I don't know this annotation though"				
"It is because your underline query will be based on ,And, condition and other 3 parameters would be null(or empty). for e.g. ,CloudAndRegionAndCustomerNameAndSfSan, Your response would be returned only when all parameters would be non-empty. I'd suggest you can implement custom query by using ,To Query, annotation on your JPA definition. Perform validations to check which parameters are non-empty and accordingly call your relevant JPA. Alternatively, Try this ,findAllByCloudOrRegionOrCustomerNameOrSfSan"	ToQuery			
To MatteoNNZ Thanks for your comment Matteo. In the controller I tried setting the RequestParams to false by doing this: To RequestParam( required=false ). But it doesn't seem to work properly because I get a 500 internal server error.	RequestParams			
"From a pure design point of view, they are two different models from two separate services and your service make a bridge between the two. You have no guarantee that one day one of the two services doesn't change the model (it may even change the service itself), so to me it makes perfectly sense to have them duplicated (they are two different DTOs), even if they happen to be very similar, practically the same, in this exact moment in time."	(they

"Teacher, I have one more question. "When deciding to use an off-the-shelf product, one should always consider that there may be scenarios that can not be covered by it (i.e. either impossible or very expensive to achieve). Keycloak is very extendable (by developing custom plugins or themes), but still it may not give you the freedom to do whatever you need in a way that you want. I don't know what you mean by self-authentication, but regarding the terms and other stuff, we have done similar thing by implementing custom authenticator in the login process or registration process."	off-the-shelf

"Resources are nouns; in this case, the resource is a game, or a hand within the game. These are not resources (URLs), they're state changes that go along with a single mutation (POST) endpoint."				
"JAXB is simple if the XML is simple and if it doesn't use mixed content (for example, simple configuration files). It can get horrendous with some of the industry-standard XML vocabularies that have 1000 element types in their schema, and it's best avoided if you're handling ""document-oriented"" rather than ""data-oriented"" XML."

"You can't reach your PC using localhost.  Localhost always refers to the machine itself.  If you're using an emulator, you can use 10.0. 2.2 instead of localhost.  If you're using a real device, you need to use the actual IP number of your PC.  And if using a real device you need to ensure your wifi network is set up to allow traffic to your PC from other devices."	2.2

So when you try for example ,builder.setName(event.getString(""name""));,, you are trying to call a method that does not exist. This is the reason for your error message. Add the methods in the ,ItemBuilder, class."	builder

I doubt there is an universal answer to such a vague question. What kind of service are you offering? Does your API have an order in which actions should be processed? Do you want to simulate real use cases to find bottlenecks? Or do you suspect a specific endpoint to be a bottleneck and want to troubleshoot it?	endpoint			
"My api is connected to mongodb and hyperledger fabric network for anchoring transactions. The main goal is to find how much load this api can support, mainly how many tps. The main api endpoint works like this : the user posts some information, the api does some computation and then saves data in the database and calls the blockchain to anchor the data. Finally the api sends a response. The is that blockchain transaction verification takes time. Therefore another api endpoint sends the transactions status (validation time is required too)."	blockchain

so RESTful web service and REST API are same. right ?	REST			
"Correct, just different terms for the same thing. Programmers are always renaming things... It's just what we do :) We love to refactor"				
"No, this is not correct. API is very generic term. Every Web Service is an API, but not every API is a Web Service. Programming languages have their APIs themselves. API is just every set of rules to communicate with an application."

"Your question doesn't make sense.  You don't refresh an HTTP request.  Do you mean you want to make continual HTTP requests until you get a response?  That's probably a bad idea.  Or do you mean you want to wait for the http request to finish?  Which makes a lot more sense, but isn't generally what you want to do-  you use multithreading with a callback or observable instead."	sense			
"Yes, I want to make continual HTTP requests unit I get desired response if it is a bad idea then what else I can use?"	HTTP			
"Why would you think a second request to the same API will get you different results?  Generally it would return the same thing.  If you're waiting for some data to change on the back end, you're better off using some form of push notification."	API			
"So, I鈥檓 grabbing some data which can available anytime any second so that鈥檚 the reason I鈥檓 refreshing it."	it			
"Then you should be using push notifications.  Grabbing it constantly will drain your device's battery, and will also use up their data allowance at a horrific rate.  Not everyone has unlimited, and even if they do they may get throttled after a certain amount.  If this is your backend, it will also cause you to have an INSANE transactions per second rate and overload your servers and databases.  If its a 3rd party API, its a good way to get your app blocked.  Possibly even you sued, because that behavior is indistinguishable from a DOS attack"

Setters are for Deserialization of a Json string to an object. They make non-public fields deserializable. Getters are for Serialization of an object to Json. They make non-public fields serializable	Setters

"Java / Retrofit is more sophisticated than that; eg. ,Call<AirPollutionResponse> api,, ,Callback<AirPollutionResponse> callback,, ,Call<AirPollutionResponse> call,, ,Response<AirPollutionResponse> response, ...where ,AirPollutionResponse, should wrap eg. ,ArrayList<AirPollution> data,, as transfer envelope. Even with only 1 item, it's generally desired to have some kind of standard message envelope."

"As for me url like ,example.com/api/v1/items?fields=id,code, implies that use can define list of fields at will. Suggestion of second problem is physical separation but my goal is to solve it in code."	example.com/api/v1/itemsfields=idcode			
"Yes, the idea was that the user can define a list of necessary fields. If you want to maintain an API, this might save you from extra versions of the API just for a different set of fields.  If you keep all versions of your API in one big lump of code, it will quickly turn unmaintainable. Usually you would only switch the version in that manner when you are introducing changes that are not backwards-compatible."				
Are you sure the output has more than one line?

"Does this answer your question? ,In Kotlin, what is the idiomatic way to deal with nullable values, referencing or converting them"	nullable			
"What you probably want is to do ,val idValue: String = iDRepo.findByIdOrNull(email) ?: return null, (note the type of ,idValue, is ,String,, not ,String?,), then you can create and return your model ,return IdModel(idValue),. See the example in the docs ,kotlinlang.org/docs/null-safety.html#elvis-operator,. You can also throw the exception if you want, ,val idValue: String = iDRepo.findByIdOrNull(email) ?: throw IDLookupException(...),, and then the return type of your function is non-nullable, ,fun lookupIdValue(...): IdModel"	IDLookupException(...)

"Jackson can already read strings to Map objects, so why is your utility needed?"	needed			
I mentioned Jackson as the first option. My utility simplifies things for many cases. So OP can use jackson or my utility. For example for Jackson you need to include 2 dependencies - minimum and sometimes 3. My utility wraps it up all in one and provides very simplified methods that actually cover majority of the cases. So if your use cases are simple use of my utility makes it simpler code and code mantanance	Jackson

How can we send JSONObject along with the file to web service	JSONObject			
"You can include the JSON as a second multipart form field with another field name. You'll get a second ,To RequestParam, in the REST controller. Just pull that file  stream throug an ,ObjectMapper,. Because you're using multipart miletype, you cant use the ,To RequestBody, to get the JSON converted to a POJO. If the JSON data you want to combine with the file is really simple, consider flattening the data and include it as separate form-fields which contain the property values istead of a file..."	JSON

"The ,To RabbitListener, on the ,To PostMapping, is not OK. Do you really expect to listener for the HTTP request and AMQP queue in the same method? The ,body, is indeed a request body, but which param is for an AMQP message payload? Also return ,String, is going to trigger a reply message process. Queues can be declared automatically when they are beans and there is an ,AmqpAdmin, bean. But again: the problem you describe has nothing to do with your code. It is just a fact that there is no connection to your RabbitMQ broker."	Queues

"FYI... We provide classes like ,JsonSlurper, which simplify parsing data from JSON without necessarily having to map to a custom type like the ,Car, class mentioned above. "A more common way to get a NullPointerException in practice would be forgetting to explicitly initialize a member variable to something other than ,null, before using it, ,like this,.  With local variables, the compiler would catch this error, but in this case it doesn't.  Maybe that would make a useful addition to your answer?"	it

"To RuchirBaronia A debugger allows you to step through a program line by line to see which methods are called and how variables are changed. IDEs should have some tools to do this. See ,vogella.com/tutorials/EclipseDebugging/article.html, for example."	debugger			
"To RuchirBaronia You set breakpoints on the methods around any NullPointerExceptions as seen in the stacktrace, and check the values of variables against what you expect them to be. If you know a variable is null when it shouldn't be, then you can set breakpoints around any code that changes the value. There are also conditional breakpoints you can use which will tell you when a value changes."	stacktrace			
"i suggest also static analysis  tools, like FINDBUGS   ,en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/FindBugs"	FINDBUGS			
"If we give System.out.println(a.length()); // NullPointerException will be thrown, to skip this we can handle with try catch block. thank you"	System.out.println(a.length())			
"Keep it simple, I like this answer, add this if you consider correct - Access to uninitialized attribute of an object"				
To Emiliano - simply accessing an initialized attribute does not cause an NPE.  It is what you >>do<< with the uninitialized attribute value that causes the NPE.	initialized			
"""A NULL pointer is one that points to nowhere"", I disagree. Null pointers don't point to nowhere, they point to null values."				
"In j2ee projects,Nullpointer exception is very common.Some cases reference variables got null values.So You should check the variable initialization properly.And during conditional statement you should always check that flag or reference contains null or not like:-  if(flag!=0) { ur code that uses flag }"				
"It is worth mentioning that some IDEs (e.g. Eclipse) offer automatic nullity analisys based on ,customizable, annotations (e.g. ,To Nullable, as listed above) and warn about potential errors. It is also possible to infer and generate such annotations (e.g. IntelliJ can do that) based on existing code structure."				
"First thing should do is before using a nullable object, you should check whether is it null, using ,if (obj==null),.If it is null then you should write code to handle that also."	nullable			
"IMO, it is preferable to avoid returning null objects in methods when possible and use annotation when null input parameters are not allowed in order to, by contract, reduce the amount of 麓if (obj==null)?in the code and improve the code readability."	annotation			
"Read this ... before you accept these ""best practices"" as truth: ,satisfice.com/blog/archives/27"	practices			
"While this is a nice example, may I ask what it adds to the question that isn't already covered by all the other answers?"				
"It is simply inappropriate to use the word ""uninitialized"" here.  The example you shown is in fact ""initialized"", and it is initialized with null.  For uninitialized variables, compiler will complain to you."				
"Or use exception capture: such as: try { 	yourRef.someMethod(); } catch (NullPointerException e) { 	// TODO }"				
To Shomu: At what point do I even suggest that it should be caught?				
"Have you read the Maven Starting Guide: ,maven.apache.org/guides/getting-started/index.html"	Guide			
"The non-Maven equivalent: Find all libraries that you need and add them to your project's build path (lib directory). ""All libraries that you need"" = resteasy-jackson-provider-1.1.GA.jar (2.3.0 is the current version...) plus all dependencies. ""All dependencies"" is what Maven does for you (in this situation). I guess you are not getting DataIntegrityViolationException in your controller. Don't catch the exceptions also you can check the Exception type in Controller.	DataIntegrityViolationException			
"Another approach is to have separate endpoints.  From the user perspective, they might be pressing a single button, but the back-end could make 2 calls (1 to create the new email and 1 to remove an old email).  This will avoid collisions with another concurrent user.  Making 2 calls will obviously be slower, but those 2 calls be done concurrently."				
"Another approach is to notify the other user the resource has been updated (callbacks, webhooks, topics, websockets, etc.), and update the other user's UI, along with their pending changes."	websockets			
"Another approach is to return a resource token when the resource is fetched.  When submitting an update, the token must be included in the request.  If the submitted token matches the actual resource token, then the update is allowed, and a new token is assigned as part of updating the resource.  The other user attempts an update and is blocked since the other user submitted an old token.  This is easier than updating the other user's UI mentioned in my other comment, and might be acceptable if resource collisions are expected to be rare."				
"Thanks for your advice, but in this case, I just want to show id and name of the Province instead show all the properties in the entity"

"Yes, you can call external APIs from Lambda. No, you don't need API Gateway (which is for inbound API requests). No, it's not a VPC connectivity issue (because you can successfully call other external APIs). Add additional logs to your Lambda function, before sendRequest and after it (just to check that this is the actual code that is running), save and deploy the changed code, then re-run your test, then go to CloudWatch Logs for this Lambda function. Does it help? If not, include the logs in your post (be sure to remove any sensitive info first)."

"It looks like you have some Parameter in your Controller that expects to be passed through the request body (something like ""To RequestBody Metrics metric""), and your Postman request does not include any However, it's important to add all relevant information in your question. Without seeing your Controller, or your Postman request it's impossible answer the question"				
Aniket Sahrawat I have added the method signature in the description				
"To Shreya ,GET, request must not contain a body. Although it should not have any effect on the working, it's not a recommended practice because you don't know which application might be stripping the body off. Make sure to rename ,To GetMapping, to ,To PostMapping, and your request body should look like: ,{ 	""id"": 0, 	""name"": ""some name"", 	""success"": {}, 	""failure"": {} }"	GET			
"To Shreya You should also consider reading ,stackoverflow.com/a/983458/6099347"	stackoverflow.com/a/983458/6099347			
You can send API_VERSION's variable in method's parameters	API_VERSION's

Worst case, hit the official website in your code and see what response you get."

"What is the response headers and content for that Groovy request? When you use the browser, what is the response? You haven't shared any relevant information about what the server actually responds with, other that status 202 (Accepted). Perhaps it sends back an ID and/or a URL that can be used to query the status of the submitted request, but how would we know, when we don't know the server or what is in the response?"				
"Hand-wavy answer - an API that returns such a response generally provides a way to get the eventual response. Probably by polling with some other request. There may be some entity in the 202 response you need to include in the follow-up requests to identify what you're asking about.  For Groovy in particular, I can't say anything."	There			
"At this point, using Wireshark to figure out how the browser does it would be useful."	Wireshark			
"open devtools / network in your browser, there you can check all the request/response  headers. only api developer could answer you if there is a response for code 202."

"Ah, I see it now: ,pData.setValue(pList);, - don't do that. You're basically returning the entire list if you have a match. Instead you need a second list that only receives the matching elements. You could do that with streams but I'd suggest you try it the ""traditional"" way first (create an empty list, add matching elements and after the loop you call ,pData.setValue(yourNewList),)."	pData.setValue(yourNewList))

"""Due to a bug in previous versions of Android, the system did not flag writing to a TCP socket on the main thread as a strict-mode violation. Android 7.0 fixes this bug. Apps that exhibit this behavior now throw an android.os.NetworkOnMainThreadException."" - So some of us haven't hit this until recently!  ,developer.android.com/about/versions/nougat "				
So this running network operations on main thread is only problematic in android not in standard java code(code written in java but not for android application).??				
This is a good solution and it saved my time!	This

"Perhaps worth stressing the point that if you use a Service you will still need to create a separate thread - Service callbacks run on the main thread. An IntentService, on the other hand, runs its onHandleIntent method on a background thread."	Service			
you should not use an AsyncTask for long running operations! Guidelines specify 2 to 3 seconds max.	AsyncTask

This is a really bad answer. You should not change the thread's policy but to write better code: do not make network operations on main thread!				
"Anonymous Runnable is NOT the best way, since it has an implicit reference to the enclosing class and preventing it from being GC ed until the thread completes! Also this thread will run at the Same Priority as the main/US thread, contending with lifecycle methods and UI frame rates!"	enclosing			
"To Gavriel it creates duplicates of everything you annotate, whether it's a method, activity, fragment, singleton etc, so there is twice as much code and it takes longer to compile it. It may also have some issues due to bugs in the library. Debugging and finding errors would become more difficult."	It

"To abdv19 it's hard to improve my explanation since you didn't clarify what exactly is unclear in the current. URL is just a string representing web (in your case) resource, not a globally locked link between the resource and your application, so you can established hundreds of independent connections to the same resource identified by single URL within same application. Therefore when you open connection ,A, and apply some modifications (add header) to it they don't affect connection ,B, which is opened later in your other code unless you reuse same connection."	URL

"As I commented, I think is wrong to use ,POST /audiotracks/{trackId}/albumcover, if the albumcover is a data of the same entity (,AudioTracks, in this case) you are coupling the API call structure and workflow to your datamodel representation (i.e. you are forcing to do, and to know! many calls when only one is required). IMHO."	POST/audiotracks/{trackId}/albumcover			
"(i.e. if tomorrow you have multiple albumcovers you MUST to change all the api calls and workflows, using my approach, only who and when want to use multiple albumcovers simply must to change whatever set the albumcover ,mytrack.albumdata.cover = xxx,, no changes on calls, workflows, ...)"

"You say you're trying to stream, but you're not ,streaming,. The code is building up the entire response in POJOs in ,recordsResult,, then mass-converting to JSON at the end. The point of streaming is to send the data as it is being collected, so you ,don't, build up memory, and so you start sending sooner, thereby reducing the amount of space needed and improving the performance."
