"You're button is a ""submit"" button, so it will submit the form. Make it ,type=button, instead."	You're			
"Instead of inline code like ,onclick=""invokeGET()"", you should do ,document.querySelector('form').addEventListener('submit', invokePOST);, (Note that you should move your script to the end, right before ,</body>, or it won't find the form.) This way you can use ,function invokePOST(e) {, to be able to access the submission event, then call ,e.preventDefault(), on it to stop the browser from submitting the form. Now you can run your AJAX code."	e.preventDefault()			
"Thank you! I have changed it to a ,type = button, now but I am getting a 400 errror. I think I am having difficulty in binding the values to the right property? To Pointy"	type			
"You're passing the string ""age"" for the ,age, property, but the server seems to want that to be a number (it's an ,int, in the Java class)."	age			
"You aren't reading the form values, just passing literal strings. Provided you followed my advice, you can use ,age: Number(this.age.value), and ,name: this.name.value, etc to actually post the form values."	Number(this.age.value)			
"Is that 50k ,concurrent, requests? In what time frame? - What you might need to think about is scaling out, e.g. running multiple instances of your APIs to handle that. Alternatively you might need to rebuild your API or at least employ patterns like ,bulkhead, or ,circuit breaker,. Some form of caching might also help but it's hard to tell without having way more info - and that might be totally out of scope for SO."	bulkhead			
Thanks for the response. It is a 50k sequential request as per the client's requirement.  The time frame is 2.5 hours. The patterns you have mentioned will be helpful to me.				
How long does it take to fulfil a request like those? 50k in 2.5 hours (or 9000 seconds) is only about 5.5 to 6 requests per second on average - this is fairly low. You might need to also address the way requests are fulfilled.

"No, there isn't. The behavior of the PayPal page will always depend on cookies in that fashion. But if you want to always show a black ""Debit or Credit Card"" option, use the in-context flow"	PayPal			
"Make two routes on your server, one for 'Create Order' and one for 'Capture Order', documented here: ,developer.paypal.com/docs/business/checkout ,  These routes should return only JSON data (no HTML or text). When a capture response is successful, store the successful payment details in your database (particularly ,purchase_units[0].payments.captures[0].id,, the PayPal transaction ID) and perform any necessary business logic (such as sending confirmation emails or reserving product) before sending your return JSON"				
"What is ,decoder,?"	What			
"The problem with depending on a third party api is that when it fails you have little recourse. Here however, you ignore whatever response code they send if it is not ,200,. You should see what value you get. Perhaps it is a redirect. Next, you ignore the response body and assign the value ,""error"", yourself. That is not great. Read the response body and print that too."	yourself

"Read this first,. Then you should understand that you cannot return the client side Response as the server side Response. You need to extract what you need and recreate an outbound response."				
Removing the return statement and setting the function to void isn't correct ?  I might need a code sample to understand	I			
"Did you read the link. You need to understand that there are two types of ,Response,s. One is on the client side and one on the server side. You cannot treat the client side one like the server side one like you are trying to do. If you want to return on the server the response from the client, then you need to extract that data from the client Response first, and then return ,that, as the entity of the server response."				
"response.readEntity(),. That's how you extract the body from the client request. You need to pass a class to the method."	method

"I think you need to supply an example, your question doesn't make much sense.  If you import a library and extend a class, only ,YOUR USES, of that class get extended (and overridden methods) the library remains unchanged.  If you want a default implementation, use the default class."				
"If you subclass e.g. ,ArrayList, and override the ,get(int index), method to do something different, then all other methods that you haven't overridden are handled by the ,ArrayList, class code. --- You should however be aware that the result can be weird, because if you make ,get(int index), return something that isn't in the list, then someone who iterates the list will be baffled by the discrepancy. So ,beware, what you're doing."	ArrayList

"Copy and paste ,this dependency, and refresh your project to force the download of the dependency. How it works is that there is a central repository for jars (dependencies) and you declare them in the pom.xml, and they get downloaded (if not already in your local repo). If it's already in your local repository, it gets the dependency from there. Your local repository is in ${HOME}/.m2/repository. Brief summary of how it works."

"It only gets the name property given a class with get... and/or set... methods. "It is actually a GET API, I cannot do requests.post()"	It			
"It should be the internet speed ,and, the speed at which the server gives you the information. Each of these can vary, so you'd naturally be using the ,lower, speed of each. If your download speed is 100kb/s but the server only gives you 80kb/s, then you'd be downloading at 80kb/s. And vice versa, if server is giving you 200kb/s you'd be capped to your download speed of 100kb/s. If you're on a shared connection and/or there are other bandwidth consumers currently, your download speed can vary second to second."	each

To atmin My question is that I'm able to access environment variables.   The question is how am I able to access them when tomcat docs state that env variables cannot be accessed.	env			
That's completely impossible. Tomcat is started in the Java VM. The Java VM does not know anything about e.g. $PATH unless You pass it explicitly when booting the tomcat.	e.g

"First yea comments can't be accessed individually. Second your example with posts and users is evident but what about one level deeper, what about comments related to my example?"				
"To 0x1C1B what do you mean by ""comments related to my example""?"	comments			
"/users/{userId}/posts/{postId}/comments/{commentId}, is this not allowed? If it is how to deal with it to validate the URI existence? Your example is evident just a once nested route isn't a problem... But what about n nested routes?"	URI			
"To 0x1C1B Any URL you specify for your API is valid. Following the rule, since comments are not suppose to be accessed individually, then they should be accessed by their parents, which is ,Post,. ,User, is not parent of ,Comment,, and since comment and post have relationship, checking existence of post record when adding new comment, has the same scenario of user-post relationship. So `/user/{userId} for the comments is unnecessary and redundant. In times when an entity has more than one parent or relationship, simply send parent/relation IDs in DTO, rather than in URL"				
"What does it mean to my scenario? Should I've an additional route ,/api/posts/{postId}/comments/{commentId}, with omitted user prefix?"				
Yes and I changed the API many times but does not work till now	Yes

"Your data structure -persisting holidays - should not be in memory only (you will lost all data after app restarts). You could work with holidays in a in-memory map, but keep their copy in a local file. Persist the file after each holiday is added/removed and  read file when app starts."	in-memory

"To VinayakSatapute I inserted a ^LH command in my example program, this command sets the label home - maybe this helps. If not, try a few other values for the ^FO (field origin) command - sometimes a combination of other settings places the barcode completely outside of the label. Make sure your printer is set up to use ZSim as printer language. You might also try to use DPL instead of ZPL II; I think it's the more native language for your printer."	DPL

"As mentioned, HttpClient is ""the better alternative"". You can in fact do everything with ,URLConnection,, you yet has to know and understand the HTTP specs. By the way, don't try to compare PHP with Java. It's like apples and oranges. To avoid self-troubles/confusions, rather forget about PHP and put a fresh view on Java. It's a language with an entirely different ideology. PS: I do both, so I tell from experience."	PHP

"This exception simply means that your JVM does not accept the certificate of the HTTPS endpoint. You should check that certificate, and either not call the endpoint, or add that certificate (or better, the root certificate) to the truststore - i.e. the file ,cacerts,."	endpoint

"try loan.setDisbursementDate(""\\""\\"""")"	loan.setDisbursementDate(\\\\)			
"To AmitVyas That would be a syntax error, right? The backslashes are escaped, so the second quote ends the string, meaning all the stuff after that isn't supposed to be there"	right			
"In java you escape "" by \"" and the same goes for JSON.You need to escape \ as well...:   try loan.setDisbursementDate(""\\\""\\\"""")"				
"If you are working with a json serialization library, no need to do anything, just use an empty string, pretty straight forward."	json			
"To Enterman probably is on the right track here. You are using a ,library, to write the JSON. You want the value of a field to be an empty string. So, just give the library an empty string, and let the library do its job. Don't try to tell the library what an empty string is supposed to look like in the JSON file. In fact, don't try to tell the library what ,anything, is supposed to look like in the file. Just give the library the names and the values, and let it do its job."	library

"Because CouchBase transforms your DateTime into a timestamp, which a number. This is its default storage for a DateTime type"

"""so rather than 1 ""file"" as you put it with 2 records in there, you have an object per record."" Does that mean if i have 100 POST request, i will have 100 objects stored in S3? Then the next time, I do a DELETE request on 50 of the records there, then 50 of the objects stored in S3 will be deleted?"				
"In general, yes.  When you store an object in S3, you provide a unique key and you use that unique key to manage it further, i.e. overwrite it, delete it, read it, etc.  It's a powerful general purpose (object) storage service that has alot of features.  Read up on it."				
"thanks for sharing your knowledge, to answer your question, the reason why he wants to change the data store is because he said ""dynamodb is more cost effective, thats why we are moving to s3"""	s3			
"I assume you mean ""s3 is more cost effective"".  While that may be true for storage costs, all bets are off if you're making millions of read and write requests, since you'll start running into S3 API costs."	s3

"I see few issues here.  JWT token should tell what role user belongs to, not like user selects the role and request for token for specific role. Token based auth are based on ""access-token"", ""refresh-token"". Refresh token is used to request new access-token. Validity of ""refresh-token"" is generally kept longer usually 10-15 days or even 30 days. When you make api call and find that access token is expired then use refresh token to get new access token and use that in API request."	access-token			
I got the solution. I developed a specific service to get the Bearer token with required Inputs	Bearer

"Cross-origin requests require agreement from the remote server, by it actively supporting either JSON-P (involving a modified response) or CORS (involving modified headers). If the API you're trying to reach doesn't offer these, the request won't be able to made directly from the client."	response)			
"I don't think the OP owns ,flightstats.com, domain, so enabling CORS is not an option"	OP			
"cors-anywhere works by being a proxy for the actual request and having CORS response headers in the response - this can work, but depending on the API, may have limited success - I know any API I write that does not allow CORS would also prevent such shenanigans - if I don't want my API accessible  directly through client, I would actively prevent it"	cors-anywhere

"It doesn't really matter what characters you put into the URI. Any advice given is only an opinion therefore. What matters more is that the URI is given a meaningful relation name (like in the Web where a URI is annotated with a human friendly text given the link some useful meaning). A client should never need to interpret the segments in the URI to determine the intent of it nor should a client think of an URI (or the resource it points to) to ,return a specific type"	URI

I think it is the default spring behaviour, its philosofy is ""depends on abstractions and not implementations"", its a dependency injection principle. I really don't know why it does not work, but I think it is a good thing, no? :-)"

"Hey Daniflipers, I would follow practices brought about by the standardized Http status codes. For example, if the api does not authenticate you correctly, returning a Forbidden 403 or 401 Unauthorized. There is a good list I have found over the years: ,httpstatusdogs.com, Its always good to give the user a little more info, even if its just through a status code! Hope that helps a little more!"				
"One more note, Its also good to use the standardized codes through http status codes, because they often denote where the error has occurred(Ex: http 500 errors mean there is a problem with the server)"	server)

"Android ""knows"" about your class types because of the manifest file. You never instantiate your service type, Android does that for you based on your (or others) intents. It never has to know about your instance because you don't have an instance."	file			
"We could also create our own classes that extend specific Android abstract classes, but they will not be called in the manifest file. If i dont have an instance, how it could instantiate it for me ? Sorry, that i dont understand."				
"With regards to your specific example of extending the Service class, you must declare services in your manifest file. There's no way around that. What Android abstract class were you thinking of?"	Service			
"Yes this is true that we need to declare the Service class in our Manifest. But for example, extending AsyncTask and adding specific implementation for the doInBackground abstract method is maybe a more suitable example."	Service			
"For AsyncTask, yes you extend and instantiate your own instance. But you then invoke the execute() method on your own instance. In this case, Android didn't have to know about anything. The magic of OO programming called your version of doInBackground(). If you look at the source code for execute(), you'll see where the abstract method doInBackground() is eventually called."	anything

"Check the string you are sending into server first. I.e. headers, I think header format should be ,name:value\r\n,. ,W3C"				
"The Delphi code you have shown is fine, as far as preparing the POST params list. But your Java code is also optionally setting HTTP headers, which your Delphi code is not doing. You can use the ,TIdHTTP.Request.CustomHeaders, property to add any custom headers that are not already covered by ,TIdHTTP.Request, sub-properties. For instance, authentication credentials/tokens.  Also, something else to keep in mind - some servers are sensitive to the ,User-Agent, request header, so you might need to set the ,TIdHTTP.Request.UserAgent, to mimic what ,HttpPost, or a real web browser would send."

"Unclear what specifically you're after, but you should probably start with generics."	generics			
Even using generics it doesnt mean it's type safe? The idea is to make sure all the key value pair are of one type				
"Of one type, or of the same type?"				
Please be more precise on what you want to make more type safe. Do you want to get rid of type Object for key and value?				
of the same type.	type			
but why is this type safe? How do we know we don't have instances of various objects being put in the cache? Where is that check being made?				
Because the type T is fixed when you implement this interface in a concrete class. For example when you do this: public class InternalCacheServiceImpl implements InternalCacheService<Integer>. In this case you fix the type T to be Integer for class InternalCacheServiceImpl. The compiler will then be able to check that the key and value are of type Integer.	InternalCacheServiceImpl			
Thank you! I appreciate it.				
I've extended the answer above with the example of type Integer. In this case the client who is using your cache via the interface is only able to put objects of type Integer into your cache although the data structure CacheElement theoretically could store any Object type.	Integer

"Well, in general when the api has methods like ,GET_DETAILS_BY_XXX, then I'd expect the response to be the same no matter what ,XXX, is. In that case you could also use a more complex object that describes properties of what you want to get and use the information in that request object to determine the actual call (e.g. one could pass a range of ids as well as a pattern for the name and get all students whose id is in that range and whose name matches the pattern - or you just pass a range like [x,x] to get one specific id only)."				
"To Thomas, Response for each API is specific because returning all the details would slow down API (API can return thousands of rows which could increase I/O if we get all the fields)"				
"Well in that case I'd not use the same base name because that indicates the response is the same. If you want a generic api you could let the caller pass information on the wanted data as well and build your response accordingly. It would basically be something silimar to ,GraphQL"				
What does the resulting JSON look like (I see you print it to Log)? Is email present as a JSON parameter in it?	it			
yes . email is present as a json parameter.	parameter			
"{     ""status"": ""0"",     ""userData"": [         {             ""regiment_number"": ""reg001"",             ""rank"": ""rankl009"",             ""name_of_cadet"": ""raman"",             ""email"": ""ramanasht786To gmail.com"",             ""mobile"": ""8130814255"",             ""father_name"": ""Mr. Ramesh"",             ""exam_type"": ""A"",             ""unit"": ""unit1"",             ""ncc_group"": ""gr1"",             ""state"": """",             ""district"": """",             ""town"": """",             ""directorate"": ""dr1"",             ""membership_status"": ""ncc""         }     ] }"				
"Ah ok, well the problem is that the information you want isn't in the root of the JSON object. So, in this case, you will need to get the userData array (something like jsonArr = json.getJSONArray(""userData""). Then get the object in that array (is it always just one?), JSONObject innerObject = jsonArr.get(0) for example. THEN finally you can do email = innerObject.getString(""email"");"

"Your method accepts ,application/json, but you are sending ,application/x-www-form-urlencoded,."	application/json			
"To BackSlash i m sending accept: application/json also as you can see in the code and i also mentioned that if i don't send content-type, i get Request Method: OPTIONS Status Code: 403 Forbidden error"				
"Sending the ,accept, header from client just tells the server that your client is able to understand ,application/json,. ,Content-Type, tells the server what kind of data you are sending, ,Accept, server-side means that the server can understand that language. So, if ,Accept, from server and ,Content-Type, from client don't match, you'll get a 415. It may also happen that you get a 415 from a deserialization error (i.e. body cannot be parsed to ,AdminLogin,), but it should generally fire a 400 instead."	accept			
"To BackSlash, i have tried this also  headers.append('Accept', 'application/json'); headers.append('Content-Type', 'application/json');  in this case, i m getting 403 forbidden error and requests header goes like this  Access-Control-Request-Headers: content-type Access-Control-Request-Method: POST Origin: ,localhost:4200, Referer: ,localhost:4200/pages/auth/login,  and i get response like this  Invalid CORS request"				
"Then you should investigate server-side why this is happening, likely you'll have logs somewhere."

"No, you don't hash client-side. Authentication is a solved problem, I urge you to look into auth services, like ,Auth0, perhaps."	auth			
Is there a reason you want to hash the username and password at the app ? hashing is meant to protect the password at the server side. since you are passing username and password only the first time the user logs in  and from there on you use token or api upon successful authentication by the server . you don't need to worry about hashing the password at the client side. this will complicate things since the server has to know the hashing key of the client all the time.	username

Hello To M.Deinum I'm reading some articles about Apache Shiro. What do you recomend to me?	Apache			
"I'm biased towards Spring Security as it integrates reallly nice, but Apache Shiro also has Spring integration."	Shiro			
"To M.Deinum is basically right, but expressed technical detail in a way easy to misunderstand about AspectJ: ,Spring AOP, is based on dynamic proxies. ,AspectJ, however, about which the OP was talking (hint: modified class files) is not, no matter if used via compile-time weaving, as M. Deinum said, nor via load-time weaving, which is the usual way Spring users apply AspectJ and is described well in the Spring manual. So with LTW you can keep your original class files (even though I would argue that the AspectJ compiler does not ""obfuscate"" them) and have the full power of AspectJ."	files)			
AspectJ when used with Spring still uses the same Spring AOP infrastructure. AspectJ is applied the same as regular aopalliance interceptors. It will only change if you yourself configure compile-timeweaving OR loadtimeweaving. The latter isn't enabled by default and all AOP is thus by default (regardless of the way of expression the AOP) by proxies.	Spring

"You can use the repositories of JPA for that and in CustomService you can handle as a transaction, putting ,To Transactional, on the method that will do 4 actions on one, you can take a look ,spring.io/guides/gs/managing-transactions"	JPA			
To JonathanJohx That won't help. Spring will commit the transaction after each REST call - resulting in three separate transactions.				
So you want to commit one only on several requests? Because from controller enters to services ypu can manage the curremt transaction in order to do create/update/delete on the same transaction by using several commits.	curremt			
"interesting situation. Correct me if I am wrong but you probably need to actually perform each request/operation in order to track somehow user's actions (case in which you can just create a separate api for this). Otherwise not sure why would you choose not to perform only the final result, ex: create 1,2 delete 1 --> create 2"				
"To dskfdskjgds you need to execute everything in one transaction. Since you cannot perform the deletion and then perform the update, an error will occur during the update, for example, due to the uniqueness of the fields. To avoid an inconsistent state"	deletion

You're trying to send the parameters of the GET request as its body. They need to be in the URL.	GET

"No, you're not. Read the javadc: ,docs.spring.io/spring/docs/current/javadoc-api/org ,. It says: ,requestEntity - the entity (headers and/or body) to write to the request,. You don't want to send any body. You want the parameters to be in the URL."

"Thank you. This lead to it working.The other issue that was causing a problem was that Retrofit had an issue with my base url ending with a forward slash. So i found out that when retrofit is having issues connecting to the API, investigate the forward slashes at the end of the base url and at the begining of the specific request url. Thanks for all your help To AbhayBohra"

QueryRequest testsetRequest = new QueryRequest(""Test Set""); testsetRequest.setFetch(new Fetch(""FormattedID"",""Name"")); testsetRequest.setQueryFilter(new QueryFilter(""TestSet.Name"", ""="", ""TestSetName"")); QueryResponse testSetQueryResponse = restApi.query(testsetRequest); System.out.println(String.format(""\nTestSet:%d"",testSetQueryResponse.getTotalResultCount())); StringTestSetref=testSetQueryResponse.getResults().get(0).getAsJsonObject().get(""_ref"").toString(); System.out.println(TestSetref);"				
"Thank you! Why should I use 'code'(ReponseEntity<T>)? Also, any spring libaries I should look into for the interface implementation and handling if the google call times out or fails?"	'code'(ReponseEntity<T>)			
"Returning the interface seems totally wrong to me.  What do you expect a client to do with that?  If you use ResponseEntity, Spring will take care of the translation to the MIME type specified by the user.  It'll translate your response object to XML or JSON depending on what the client wants.  The HTTP client should handle the timeout.  Your interface should throw exceptions if you want the controller to handle it and inform the caller."

"I agree with ScaryWombat's sentiment. Can I do this in Selenium and if yes, what should be the approach?"	I			
"Selenium automates what a manual user would do in a browser environment, coping with html and Javascript. If your process can be handled this way then yes, Selenium would probably help you out. As for the approach, too little information is provided to advise properly. Is this transaction a one-off? Is it meant to be repeated? What is it triggered by? Back to my initial comment, please provide code and examples."

"Whois itself -- and therefore anything built on top of it -- contains no such information.  Whois contains information about ,domain registrations,, not about any services or web sites running at those domains, with the exception of domain-name services.  I've no knowledge of any public database containing the kind of information you're after."

"function xhrPostCall(jsonInput, postUrl){   xhrPost.open(""POST"",postUrl, true);   xhrPost.setRequestHeader(""Content-type"", ""application/json""); 	xhrPost.onreadystatechange = function() {       if(xhrPost.readyState == 4 && xhrPost.status == 200) { 					msg=""Environment Succesfully Added!""; 					alert(xhrPost.status+jsonInput+msg);           console.log('posting succesful:'+jsonInput+msg);       }			else{msg=""Environment Unsuccessfully Added!""; 				alert(xhrPost.status+jsonInput+msg); 				console.log('posting unsuccessful'+jsonInput+msg); 			}   }   xhrPost.send(jsonInput); }"

"do you have to set the content-type before sending? That is frequently an issue when sending to a web API. If you look at the return code received from the site, it may give you a hint."				
"Unfortunately pretty much every class has API methods in it, as the entire project is an API, and like I said, I would still like to have the checks so I don't want to just suppress everything. I could migrate the methods all into one class and then reference them from other locations, but that seems excessive to me. Maybe there's an To interface in java that already has this functionality?"				
"IntelliJ IDEA 2017.2 will have some improvements in this regard, for instance, entry points will not be analyzed for unused/visibility/same return value. Keeping API in a separate package seems to be a good solution, or keeping implementation classes in ,impl, subdirectories and using the inspection scope to analyze only classes in ,impl,."	2017.2			
"Thanks for the advice. For now I ended up just adding all of the methods as entry points, going through each warning to make sure they were all correct, and right clicking each section from the ""analyze code"" and batch adding the suppress warnings. It shouldn't be too much of a hassle if I do this before I push each major update, but I'm still looking for a simpler/cleaner solution. I took a brief glance over the the 2017.2 update summary, and it looks like you're right, hopefully it will be solved soon."				
"I honestly think the best solution would be a way to link the other projects to it. That way you could still have all of the checks work and you wouldn't have to label anything as being an API. Normally I would just add them as a module of the project, but it's a pain with Maven."	it

"This can be one strategy to deal with, however, I do not want to remove a known behavior of the verb, avoiding unexpected responses of error from the API. The idea is to increment, expand the verb's ability to create a flexible / dynamic API."	verb			
"I don't think it is proper REST interface. For the same verb you want to use different type of nouns. They need to be separated by different URLs. For example do ,POST, on ,/car/, that returns single id object and ,POST, on ,/cars/, that returns array of id objects. You can always have your REST interface to accept and return String type and you have to do parsing on your side to deal with different content."

"I think you never make any attempt to retrieve the position data from the ,DBObject, returned in the cursor. There simply is no such call make like ,emp.get(""position""), which is what is needed to actually get the data. For some reason you are calling ,PositionService, when the data is already in the ,emp, object. The data is already there to use, but you're not using it. Just take the list from the existing object from the cursor."	PositionService			
"Hi Neil, I am trying to do that. ,emp.get(""positions""), returns a BSON object right? If I cast it to DBObject and assigned to a variable called ,pos, how can I add it to the ,employee.setPosition(positions), which accepts a ,List<Position>, type argument"	emp.get(positions)			
"I'm actually wondering why you are doing any of this really. The driver supports using ""typed"" queries that marshal the BSON data in and out of your defined classes out of the box. So you seem to be trying to re-invent the wheel here. I think you should look at the documentation further. As for ""how to do it in this context"", then just 1. get the list. 2. Iterate the list and ,.get(), the properties, and feed them to your class, then append to a list of class. 3. Take that list of ,Position, and add it to the ,Employee,. No need for another query."	typed

Here is a benchmark did using JMH that compares the performance of the most popular json libraries in java: ,github.com/fabienrenaud/java-json-benchmark,. See my post below for some more info."	JMH

"It's amazing that this is a question with such complex answers. Really symptomatic of the Java environment. Pretty much every other language on the planet has a simple built-in JSON parser that can usually be used by calling ,JSON.parse(<string>), (JS, Ruby, Python, Golang, even C# and php). Only Java makes a mess of it."	php)

"To StaxMan I would choose ,org.json, over other libraries for simple JSON parsing without even looking. It is the reference library that Douglas Crockford (the JSON discoverer) created."	org.json			
"org.json is amongst the worst json libraries. One should look at the feature set and performance of available json libraries before choosing. Here is a benchmark I did comparing jackson, gson, org.json, genson using JMH: ,github.com/fabienrenaud/java-json-benchmark,. jackson is the clear winner here."	org.json

"It's not a workaround. According to the spec, JSON text needs to be a serialized object or array. The easiest way to have Jackson output an object is by returning a map, the easiest way to have it output an array is by returning a list."	Jackson

"Well, PopularTrack doesn't match the structure of your JSON object at all. The JSON object has a property named toptracks, which is an object with a property named track, which is an array of objects having a name property. PopularTrack doesn't match that at all. It just has a name. So it could be used to map a JSON looking like ,{ ""name"": ""foo"" },."	toptracks			
"Can use ,jsonschema2pojo.org, to generate propper object structure"	jsonschema2pojo.org			
How do I go about creating a class which matches my JSON Object?				
The JSON has a toptracks property. So you need that in your top-level class. Its value is an object in the JSON. So you create another class to model this object. The toptracks JSON object has an array named track. So you add a track property to this second class. The array contains objects. So you create a third class to model this third kind of JSON object.	track			
"Please see edited code using ,jsonschema2pojo.org,. My problem now is that it is not outputting 'Best I Ever Had'. Do you know where I am going wrong?"	jsonschema2pojo.org			
"First: Why do you want to save the image? Second: I think you need to define where you want to save it by providing a callback to ,takePicture()"	callback			
"I actually don't want to save the image, but it was for testing purposes. I made an API that takes a Base64 encoded image. So what i actually want to do is Base64 encode the image and send it to my api. I'm a rookie at android so i don't exactly know what you mean by providing a callback, could you explain?"				
"Wow thank you so much for the answer, i'm going to try it now and let you know. Maybe a stupid question, but how does it know it should run onPictureTaken, because you don't define that anywhere?"				
"You HAVE to define it. Basically somewhere in the takePicture method, there is a piece of code which check that you've provided the callback. If it's the case ,onPictureTaken, is called otherwise nothing happen. And remember that this call is asynchronous. It means that your ,onTap, method will maybe have finished to be executed when ,onPictureTaken, will be called."	it

"If the ,onFailure(), is called the problem is probably not that the server doesn't accept your request. It's usually a fundamental problem. It could be that you can't connect to the server (wrong URL? no internet connection?) or that your converters cannot parse the request/response. You should check the error in the onFailure for more information. See also: ,futurestud.io/tutorials "

"DO NOT INCLUDE CREDENTIALS IN THE URL PARAMS OF A GET REQUEST,."				
"There are two kinds of tokens - access tokens and session tokens. Access tokens should not expire - the user should authenticate and request a token; that token should then be included ,as a header at least, with every request. It is a Bad Idea TM to send credentials as URL params. In an ideal world, authentication is by client certificate - that way TLS itself handles authentication. A REST application should be stateless, so session tokens should not be used."	tokens			
"Further ,?action=XXX, Is not REST - It鈥檚 鈥淛. Doe鈥檚 magic API? REST would require a URL mapped to a resource and a HTTP verb to carry out an action, for example ,GET /token, would create a token and ,DELETE /token, would invalidate a token."	/token			
"And your final question, it would be ,PUT /vet-clinic, with the JSON definition of the clinic in the request body."				
"Hi. thanks for the answer, I changed but still doest work.. same error. maybe this instructions from bitfin site will help you in checking what i am doing wrong:"	bitfin			
"The authentication procedure is as follows:  The payload is the parameters object, first JSON encoded, and then encoded into Base64 payload = parameters-object -> JSON encode -> base64  The signature is the hex digest of an HMAC-SHA384 hash where the message is your payload, and the secret key is your API secret. signature = HMAC-SHA384(payload, api-secret).digest('hex')  send (api-key, payload, signature)  These are encoded as HTTP headers named:  X-BFX-APIKEY X-BFX-PAYLOAD X-BFX-SIGNATURE"	HTTP			
Could this be deflated? Can you try with an InflaterInputerStream?	InflaterInputerStream			
That was exactly right! The content-encoding header indicated it was gzip when I checked response headers. Thanks much!	much

"unocoin.com/apidoc#getting-started,. This is their official API. If you call an unofficial api, I presume is because that you are not supposed to call it with a bot. Qn api can be consumed if the one owning the api agrees to make it public, especially unauthenticated. Think if you would start hitting their api 1 million times with parallel bots running? You would probably make their website very slow or even worse, make their site go down, which would be illegal and considered a DDoS. I repeat, send an email ti them and ask them if are okay to be crawled"

"Are you on Windows? On this line ,fileHitbox = new FileInputStream(new File(""hitbox.json"")), you open the file, but you never close that stream. Try closing the stream before deleting the file. Also note that you don't need to store JSON content to the file first, you can use ,IOUtils.toString(response.getEntity().getContent(), ""UTF-8""), directly to get a JSON string. (If that response is guaranteed to be small enough)"	UTF-8)

"You could always build a JIRA Plugin to have it generate the report for you from within JIRA, then you wouldn't have to use the REST API and convert items to and from Objects."	JIRA			
"I may suggest the plugin route if we decide that the chart I made needs anything further.  The hope was that I could quickly throw together a simple web service and page to make a burnup chart using the JIRA API.  However, it ended up being a few days worth of effort due to 1) inconsistencies within the JIRA API, and 2) the JRJC libraries being 2 major versions out of date (v4) compared to JIRA (v6)."				
"It turns out that the JIRA REST Java Client is woefully out of date - currently 2 major versions behind the actual JIRA API.  I have converted it to use JAXB, cut out the client code (I only wanted the XML representation), and dropped all external dependencies (except javax.*).  However, I only updated (from API v4 to v6) the few areas that I was using.  If anyone has interest, I can probably provide my source code."	v4

"Okay, so just use an access token for the ""resource owner."" As I said, you only have to authorize an app once. After that, the app can keep using the access token. From the tutorial you linked to: ""The access token is all you'll need to make API requests on behalf of this user, so you should store it away for safe-keeping (even though we don't for this tutorial). By storing the access token, you won't need to go through these steps again unless the user reinstalls your app or revokes access via the Dropbox website."""	Dropbox

You have a legacy application which run on it's own authentication service, and you need to build a different service as a RESTful API and you need to authenticate both, right?  If that's the problem you could find a way to authenticate the RESTful web service, via your existing web application service. If you need to authenticate both, you could write an API who does the authentication and implement it in the web api and on the RESTful service."				
"I wouldn't call it a legacy application, as it will still need to function/run while/after the api is being built. The application currently does use REST (mostly, but not completely) for handling data requests, but it's not completely locked down. Most of the authentication that occurs for the application is via a user login. I suspect that it will be difficult to maintain and secure the existing REST services within the web app, hence the question."

"If calling the ,tweet, method multiple times in a short period isn't expected usage, you will need to check for rate limits on the server side. Many APIs do this, limiting clients to a specific number of calls in a certain time period. You could also build logic to handle multiple ,tweet, calls from a single client and construct a single call yourself."	tweet

"First of all: you need xdebug installed on your production server. Having xdebug running (even if it does nothing) makes your code 2-3 times slower. Anyway: ,xdebug.remote_autostart = 1, -- will attempt to debug every single request; ,xdebug.remote_host = xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx, -- your IP (where IDE is running); Then use ""phone handle"" icon in IDE so that it listens for incoming debug connections. ,P.S., You can always try to simulate API call via built-in simple REST client .. or via some browser-based REST client (e.g. Postman for Chrome)"

"Yeah ,ResponseHandler<String>, is just a fast way to get a string from the response (html page in my case, but can be some json or xml string, depending on the page.). I think yes, you will need some server running, because you don't need code from file api.php. You need it to be executed and give you some result data.  ,http://localhost/project/..., or something like ,http://localhost:8080/project/...,, depending on you server config. If it works in browser, then it is the url you need."	http//localhost8080/project/

"To hd1 - Doh! The strategy is: 1) use a function to parse the time string, represented in a well understood format like  ISO 8601, and convert that into a 'universal' form, seconds from a fixed, known, point (e.g. start of epoch for UNIX is 1st of January 1970, 00:00:00). Then 2) use a function to build a string (again in  ISO 8601 or similar) for the local time zone."				
Maybe the data is in JSON format (there is no 'javascript' data format)

"Arrays in Java (and most programming languages) are zero based. In the construction you give it the size e.g. ,[11], and then you can index it by using ,[0], to ,[10],. This fits nicely with the arithmetic modulo function e.g. ,11 % 11 == 0,. Visual basic was 1 based, but this changed when they added it to the .NET spectrum."	[0]

"HttpURLConnection, does not support this,, probably because ,that sort of structure was somewhat out of spec back when Java was first created,. I am uncertain if any library supports this. You would need to open your own socket connection and manually communicate with the server. This may not be pleasant."	HttpURLConnection

"HTTP GET with body is not supported, and the reason for that is that is idempotent which means calling this method several times should not have any side effects. So please don't go against the standards. Use a method which support request body."

"It is good to decouple but it would depend on your details. I think it will be introduce complexity to put in one more API (""glue""). If you expose your data via a Rest API together with some API key then shouldn't that be good enough? One more API is one more thing that can go wrong.... You might want to put in another API without forcing everyone to use it though. It is architectural decision for the architect."	It			
"For background: we have a system with albers coordinates. Instead of converting to gps every time for each asset we access, there are 4 projects each taking the coordinates for every object they need access to (such as all computers or all routers) and storing them with gps coordinates in the database for their application. Would it not be better to have an api to access that database with an option to retrieve as gps? this way it can be pulled when needed instead of stored 4 times?"	albers			
"I thought duplication of data was bad. Wouldn't having 4 data stores with the same data be a waste? For instance, we have a list of devices in use by the company. Why would we want 4 duplicates of that list? We would need the source db to feed all of them wouldn't we?"				
"I think you misunderstood it, I never meant to have the data all duplicated but to have it split in boundaries, each application is responsible for its boundaries and that's it. If another application needs this data you request that to the application you never access its database directly."	it

"Generally if you ask: ""Are there easy ways to do this ,established crazy way of working no sane person would ever do,"", the answer is regrettably: ""No"". Why would one write a framework to support an exotic way of working that has virtually zero use cases, after all? You can get java parsers and rewrite your code. These tools are extremely complicated. javac is GPL without classpath exception, so you can't use it unless you foss the entire thing, and ecj is fast, MIT-licensed, but very had to understand and use. What you describe would take weeks to months."	javac

Simply: it can't.	can't			
"Have you read about TargetDataLine.read(byte[] b, int off, int len) method? Documentation says you can read any portion of internal buffer. For example, internal buffer can contain 1000 frames but you can read 10. It will be first 10 then, i.e. from 0 to 9. Next you read 10 frames it will be from 10 to 19 and so on. Since you cannot control reading position, it is controlled internally. Also the ""tail"" should be known internally. Hence TargetDataLine is FIFO for bytes. And this means that frameposition may refer both head and tail of FIFO. Whichever is unknown from documentation!"

"What ,count, was the ,CountDownLatch, created with? The number of heroes? If so, you need to call ,countDown(), once for each hero, so the call should be made from within ,onResponse, ,and, ,onFailure,, otherwise the count will never reach zero."	countDown()			
"The ,await, call in the ,onClick, callback is on ui thread which means you are potentially blocking ui thread which can lead to ANR.  Seems  much simpler to post result to view in ,onResponse, using a looper post (to ui thread): ,stackoverflow.com/a/25250494/2711811, .  You will need to the view."

If you're new to programming maybe don't start with a stack that requires years of training and learning. Create a Java command line application first and learn the problems and solutions for this before starting to jump through the next big hoops that require you to not only understand programming but also HTTP communication and more. Tutorials might be a nice way to get things starting but they mostly don't help you understanding things left and right of their very reduced scenario.	Tutorials

You spring boot api is just endpoints that you could call. for example if you have and endpoint like this  /searchdata/{id}  you have to connect to your sping api from your java program and then call the endpoint by passing parameters (here it's a path parameter 'id). As I said in my answer there is a couple of java api allowing you to do this.	endpoint

"RestOperations, is an interface implemented by ,RestTemplate,, and you have auto-wired a ,RestTemplateBuilder, for ,creating, ,RestTemplate, objects, so why do you believe you can auto-wire ,RestOperations,? "To user2607744 Why did you wire in a ,RestTemplateBuilder,? Why did you believe you needed to wire in a ,RestOperations,? Why did you create a ,RestTemplate, directly? The 3 actions seem to all be for the same purpose. What weird tutorial have you been following? Recheck your source material to see how it ,should, be done."				
"Or just ,read the documentation,, i.e. the ,Spring Boot Reference Guide,, section ,33. Calling REST Services with RestTemplate,, which shows that you wire in a ,RestTemplateBuilder,, use it to build a ,RestTemplate,, and then use that to execute a REST call."	RestTemplate

'Z'

"If you want it request scope, which means that with every request new service bean is created with default State variable  initialised to 0. When you first call /foo a new bean of service is created and the State is increased to 2. Next when you call /foo/status new bean with default State 0 is created and returned"	2			
Is there a workaround for this? Without removing the Scope.	Scope

That's not very scalable....	scalable			
If you just want to sync your app with latest data then you can send triggers from your back-end server and in app when you get that trigger update the data via api call. This way your app will be synced with latest data and you don't need to call api in every 30 second. (Calling apis from mobile in every 30 second will effect your app performance as mobile resources are limited.)				
yes that's why i am concern about calling api every 30 seconds. To AbhishekIppakayal what should i implement web sockets or by using FCM for this scenario?	FCM			
thank you To AbhishekIppakayal for your suggestion.	AbhishekIppakayal			
yes you are right. thank you for your response.				
There's reasons (battery life among them) that you should not do this with networking calls.  Sending a network call every 30 seconds at all is a bad idea.				
You really shouldn't share your access token publicly.	publicly

"Hey! You got it well the problem is that a session system works well in a website environement but since I have no php code, so no serverside code, I can't assume that the database will be accessed only by the client I wrote. I know it's LAN for the moment, but I don't know if it will change soon, so I'd rather have a good security from the start. Therefor, having some kind of access restriction on the server side."	it's			
"Making the code in a Java SE application from the beginning, since it is connected to the database, is a problem, since any decompiler will expose the credentials of your database. Taking security into account, if you still want to make the application in Java SE, it is best to make an API on the server, and make your Java App connect to that API, without ever giving Java SE your BD credentials. You can do the API in Java EE for example, or in PHP if you have knowledge and you will add a security layer that you could not allow if you connect your client app to the BD"				
"Yes that is my problem, if It gets decompiled, the database is exposed. So I have to go with my first idea and do an API to consume the data on the server? I thought there was a solution like connecting to an auth api and access the data if the user connects to it."	It			
"Another simple solution, although not the best, is that you create a Login based on real MySQL users. Each user would have to create a MySQL user, and he would log in to the app with that username and password, providing the JDBC with the credentials it needs. By creating the user in MySQL you would give the only necessary permissions. Although honestly this is not a professional solution, and would not apply if you have more than 15 or 20 users"	MySQL			
"You would have to parse it. How exactly you do that depends on what ,Response, is."	it

"Your ctronller needs ,To Validated, to have those annotations be effective. What you see currently is the exception from constructing a ,PageRequest,."	PageRequest			
"No it isn't, you can enable it if you add ,To Validated, to the bean and register the post processor. Drawback is that you will get a 500 instead of a 400, which could be circumvented by a dedicated ,To ExceptionHandler, for this case."

"No, 3-Legged OAuth requires you to get a 1) request token, then 2) authorized request token then 3) access token. 2-legged OAuth requires you to get 1) request token and then 2) access token. After all, you need an access Token to do API calls."	OAuth			
"To Adam: Also, since this is a Job Posting, how do I POST Job XML data in the Request in the above article?  Posting of XML data is not given here."				
"To Gnanam: Try and do some searching... "Eureka!! guys, when including the jars for your project : take those from the ReportEngines/lib directory and those from the plugins directory that you need (e.g in our case : ,chart, jars)"				
"Never mind : just use the RCP report designer to create your report document. Copy ReportEngine/lib/*jars to your /WEB-INF/lib; also create a platform/ directory under WEB-INF/ and copy BIRT ReportEngine configuration/ and plugins/ directories under the newly created WEB-INF/platform/ folder. Now with the *.rptdesign file that you have created in your BIRT RCP designer tool, you will have to use the BIRT API which will allow you to interact with your report..."

"Your URLs look like parameter lists but lack the ""?"" separator... seems like an odd thing to do. Why not use regular REST URLs like ,/session/{sessionId}, and then map the parameters via ,To RequestParam(),? E.g. URL would be ,/session/1?p1=a&p2=b,."				
you are quite right. I am using the To RequestParam and it is working well for me now. Thanks.	To			
Could you give me more details why I can not do that?	I			
"It takes the first one that is a match.  Nothing says 'b&p3=c' isn't a perfectly legal value for p2, so it doesn't keep trying more to see if there's a 'better' match."				
It is configurable btw if you provide your own implementation of org.springframework.util.PathMatcher	org.springframework.util.PathMatcher

"I am assuming this is on early stages (MVP probably). So, for your translation service you can use Vert.X. You can choose whom should request the translation: the client (android application) before sending/receiveing it to/from server; or the chat server (before sending the message to destination). I dont know if you already have your chat server designed, but you can use Vert.X as well. The communication between those players would be through a java client API. Java client: ,square.github.io/retrofit, Vetr.X ,tutorials.jenkov.com/vert.x/your-first-vertx-application.html"	Vert.X

"UserInformation.this, can u guide what is this"				
"It is the context of that activity. Context  is context of current state of the application/object. It provides services like resolving resources, obtaining access to databases and preferences, and so on. An android app has activities. It鈥檚 like a handle to the environment your application is currently running in. The activity object inherits the Context object. For more information refer the link  : ,simplecodestuffs.com/what-is-context-in-android"	Context

"No.  It is not ,reasonable, doubt.  It is completely ,unreasonable, doubt.  It is a plain fact that ,toUpperCase(), actually works for ,millions, of Java programmers.  So, if you have a ,theoretical, argument that it shouldn't work, then the ,reasonable, conclusion is that your argument is incorrect ... because there is something about Java that you don't understand."				
"What do you mean by ""We didn't pass a value to the method""? Is your concern that ,s.toUpperCase(), has no information about what instance it was invoked on (here held by ,s, reference variable)? If that is the case then you need to know that this code will be compiled in something close to ,String.toUpperCase(s);, (first argument for non-static method is reserved for instance of class which method belongs to, so ,toUpperCase(), method is behind the scene more like ,toUpperCase(String this){...},) and inside it you can communicate with object represented by ,s, via ,this,)."	non-static

"If you see ,static,, then the method can be used with the form ,<classname>.<staticmethod>,. Otherwise, the method is an ,instance, method, and can only be called from an instance of that class ,<objectofclass>.<instancemethod>,. Well, in Java, you can call static method from an instance of the class, but it is discouraged, since it makes the code harder to read."	<classname>.<staticmethod>			
You seem to mixing up implementing a method with invoking it...  When you write a method body of Applet.init you're implementing it and creating your own applet.  When you invoke String.length you're using somebody else's implementation.	invoking

"Anything's possible. Just depends on how you design it. For example, what I would do in your situation is put my database interaction logic in a service, and then let that same service code be invoked either from my web layer (via REST or other API) and my CLI."				
"Thanks. Is there any standard way to design APIs in that  service ( which is responsible for db interactions, as you suggested) that will be used in/called from both web layer and CLI ?"	APIs			
"Your API should be hosted on a server that is always running you cannot host it on Github (Github just hosts the code). From there, you will be able to make calls to the API from any other machine, including the same one. The node.js app is the server in this case.  Next you can create a client app/script to interact with the server. First you need to create an express route that allows your API to send the data you would like to send to the client. Next you If you want to use python to make the calls look into this tutorial: ,realpython.com/python-requests"	API

"To rzwitseloot ,This can be faked, trivially?, Do you mean that the data sent from the client to the server might be faked? or do you mean that the people who are handling the server can tamper with the data sent from the client?   I asked this question because I could see there are APIs that are getting compromised. I could clearly segregate them based on the applications and IP addresses. But, IP change dynamically but the client is familiar with the application that they feel comfortable with like JAVA. I could have a conversation and understand that the API requests are not made by them."	This			
"Yes. Whatever is in the data that makes your server conclude: Ah, I see, the 'java SDK' application sent this information! Can be trivially faked by a non-java-SDK application. No, the server is under your control. Even then there is no way to tell. You can segregate on IP addresses (also fakable but that's quite difficult), there is no point attempting to segregate on client app. Segregate based on the key you distributed to them."	non-java-SDK			
"Take a look at ,stackoverflow.com/questions/8071363/calculating-powers-in-java,, it might answer both of your concerns."	stackoverflow.com/questions/8071363/calculating-powers-in-java			
"The results of power computations are often irrational numbers that can only be approximated, and double provides the closest approximations with fast compact arithmetic."				
"Math.pow has also many corner cases one should be aware of: ,octoperf.com/blog/2018/03/16/java-math-pow"	octoperf.com/blog/2018/03/16/java-math-pow			
"When is an integer to the power of another integer ever irrational?  ,Fractional, results (i.e., for negative exponents) ,are, an issue, though."	When

It鈥檚 worth noting that variables having disjunct scopes may share the same slot on byte code level. And a practical example for synthetic variables: the for-each loop generates such variables.	for-each			
"That is true, however only if they are of the same type. You could not reuse the spot of two ,Object,s to store a ,long, in another scope."

Thank you Nick for the example. I did take a crack at it but was running into a couple issues. This helped clear them up.				
"""NetworkOnMainThreadException"" probably you're running your network operation on the UI thread. Do it for example in an AsyncTask or anyway not on the main thread."	AsyncTask			
"here, give me some advice plz"				
To fasteque how to fix it?	it			
"In API level 11, the default is to crash if you try to access the network on the main thread. In previous API levels, it's a bad idea, but it doesn't crash. The reason it's bad is that it freezes your entire app while the network operation happens. And if the network is slow, your app freezes for a significant time. Do your users a favour and fix the problem that Android is now making obvious (by performing network access on a different thread)."				
"Your code is recommendable to use during testing phase not in final code, because it forcefully runs it in Main thread."	Your			
"As said for another answer, this is a not a very good idea. The correct design is to avoid network IO on main thread and not changing the policy to avoid system's check."				
Now check my Edit Answer Please	Please			
"Thanks your code, it's running but somebody said it not good for my code, can i use it?"	code			
"Please use an AsyncTask, don't change the policies ;)"	AsyncTask			
It's more a hack or a workaround this solution because the correct design is to never run networking operation on the main thread and not bypassing the check performed by the system :)				
don't. do. that. ever.	ever
